DOC.TEXT: Snow fell on upstate New York early today, rain pelted parts of Texas and freezing temperatures were recorded in every region of the country as a massive cold front held firm. The weather was forecast to begin warming across much of the West by afternoon before the arrival of a new cold front next weekend. But across the South, East and Midwest, cold weather showed no signs of dissipating. More than 125 cities set cold-weather records for Christmas Day. Highs weren't expected to rise above zero along much of the Canadian border today, topping out at the 20s in the Northeast, the 30s and 40s in the Mid-Atlantic region, the 40s and 50s across most of the South, the 50s and 60s in the Southwest and the 30s to the 50s in the Pacific Northwest. Florida was expected to get highs in the 60s and 70s. Most of the state has been spared from the cold wave, although lows have dropped into the 20s in some northern areas. DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Information Minister Dead at 80
DOC.TEXT: Mohammed Sidiq Shanshal, the first information minister appointed after Iraq became a republic 32 years ago, has died, newspapers reported today. He was 80 years old. The newspaper reports said Shanshal died Tuesday; one paper gave the cause of death as ``old age and poor health.'' Shanshal was a key civilian figure who helped the army topple the monarchy in a coup in July 1958. He was then leader of the Independence Party. After the coup, Shanshal was appointed minister of information in the government the army formed under Gen. Abdul Karim Qassim. He later broke with Qassim and resigned as minister of information over the general's Arab policies and his relations with Egypt. Shanshal, like many other pan-Arab politicians in Iraq at the time, favored close ties with Egypt. Shanshal refused to take part in subsequent governments. Information about his survivors and funeral plans was not available.

DOC.HEAD: Examiner Says Body Not That of Helen Brach
DOC.TEXT: A woman's body exhumed from a pauper's grave earlier this month is not that of candy heiress Helen Brach missing since 1977, according to local authorities, but a federal agency says the case is still open. Cook County Medical Examiner Robert Stein said that he, a forensic ornithologist, an anthropologist, a radiologist and another medical examiner studied the body. ``It's definitely not Helen Brach,'' Stein said Monday. ``As far as we're concerned the case is closed.'' Mrs. Brach, heiress to the Brach Candy Co. fortune, had an estimated net worth of $17 million when she disappeared in 1977 after checking herself out of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. She was 65. Her estate is now valued at more than $50 million. She was declared legally dead in 1984. Most of her money went to the Helen Brach Foundation, a charitable trust. An unidentified body was found in a suburban forest preserve in 1978. Stein ruled then that the body was not the missing heiress and it was buried. But the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms developed information during a racketeering fraud investigation that led them to request a new examination of the body this year, said ATF spokesman Jerry Singer. The body was exhumed Dec. 11. The bureau still considers the case open and is awaiting results of forensic tests, including DNA, before reaching any conclusions, Singer said. ``We have to refrain from commenting because all the tests have not been finished and there's no timetable as to when the examinations will be completed,'' Singer said.

DOC.HEAD: Relative Says Fire That Killed 7 Started By Lights On Tree
DOC.TEXT: An overheated Christmas light bulb started a house fire that killed a suburban Detroit man and six of his nine children, a family member says. Meanwhile, police in Wayne County's Canton Township said Tuesday that more than $30,000 has been raised to help Debbie Dell'Orco, whose husband, Martin, and children were killed in Saturday's fire. Fire investigators initially said the tree fell over, broke a bulb and started the blaze. But Martin Dell'Orco's brother, John, said the tree was tied to the ceiling and couldn't have fallen over. Martin Dell'Orco, 38, died of soot and smoke inhalation in the Saturday night fire along with his children Bonnie, 11; Sara, 9; Katie, 8; Megan and Michael, 5-year-old twins, and Robert, 4. Debbie Dell'Orco, 36, survived the fire with son Adam, 6. Two older children, Jimmy, 16, and Kelly, 14, weren't home. ``He was screaming, `Call 911,'' John Dell'Orco said of his brother. ``Debbie said she ran into the room and the tree was standing. It was erect and on fire and flames were shooting out the top of the tree.'' Debbie had bought a new strand of Christmas lights for the tree and had noticed one of the bulbs was hot before she decorated the tree, John Dell'Orco said. But she and her husband dismissed it, he said. In addition to the cash donations from across the country, people have offered apartments, clothing, food and funeral services. ``It's more than just caring,'' said Wayne Swanson, a neighbor. ``It's coming from so deep down in the heart, it's unbelievable.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Die in Christmas Morning House Fire
LaserPhoto CO1 of Dec. 25
DOC.TEXT: Two children and three adults who were killed in a Christmas Day fire had planned to celebrate the holiday at the home of the children's grandmother, an aunt of two of the victims said. The early morning fire, apparently started by a smoldering cigarette in a living room couch, claimed the lives of India Hamrick, 25; Ronina Hamrick, 30; Gerald Givens, 39; Rashawn Hamrick, 4; and Natasha Hamrick, 10. All of them lived in the 2{-story brick house that burned. India and Ronina Hamrick were sisters. Ronina was the mother of the two children, and Givens was the former husband of India and Ronina Hamrick's mother, Barbara Cosby. Ms. Cosby owned the house but lives in another neighborhood. Jeane Bell, India and Ronina Hamrick's aunt, said on Tuesday that the victims had planned to spend Christmas at Ms. Cosby's residence. ``Everybody was going to come over (to Ms. Cosby's) for Christmas morning,'' Ms. Bell said. ``When my daughter told me they were all dead, in my mind I said, `Let me be dreaming.' ``The whole family's close. It's like a terrible nightmare.'' A visitor to the home, 29-year-old Todd Allen Qualls of Columbus, said he awakened to the smell of smoke and escaped through a window, cutting his bare feet on the glass. He said he climbed down a ladder put up by firefighters. ``It all happened so fast, I don't really know what happened,'' Qualls said. Fire Capt. Bruce Sutton said all of the victims died from smoke inhalation. Arson experts helped investigate the fire. ``We believe it was caused by a smoldering cigarette, but we took all kinds of samples from the house and have sent them to the lab,'' Sutton said. He said it would be at least Thursday before the lab report was completed. According to Sutton, the 3:15 a.m. fire apparently started at the end of a couch in a first-floor room. A firefighter was treated at the scene for minor burns to his left ear.

DOC.HEAD: Report: School Bus Contracts Go to Companies with Ties to Mafia
DOC.TEXT: The city has consistently awarded the nation's most expensive school bus contracts without competitive bidding to companies linked to organized-crime figures, a newspaper reported today. Contractors and law-enforcement officials told The New York Times that unions influenced by suspected organized crime figures control the costs and hiring practices of many of the bus companies the city employs. One company that transported disabled children in Brooklyn was run by a man who has admitted to being a Mafia hit man, the Times said. During the 1989-90 school year, the city spent an average of $1,701 each to bus 136,000 pupils. Of those, 39,000 are handicapped; the rest do not live within walking distance of their schools. According to the Times: - Robert Bering, who has admitted to participating in Mafia murders, obtained about $2.2 million in contracts. - Julius Bernstein, an official in the Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 1181-1061, which represents most of the city's 3,000 school bus drivers, acknowledged in an interview that he had met with men identified as leaders in the Gambino and Genovese organized-crime families. He said the meetings were unrelated to union or school bus matters. - Frank Dapolito, described by the FBI as a captain in the Gambino family, is the personnel manager for a group of companies that have $12 million in contracts this year. - Edward Lino, another reputed Gambino captain who was slain last month, controlled a company that received $8.2 million in fees. Stanley Litow, deputy schools chancellor for operations, said problems relating to mounting bus costs and organized-crime influence were ``certainly disturbing.'' He told the Times that methods of awarding and supervising bus contracts were being re-examined. Local 1181 President John Ambrosio disputed allegations that his union has driven up the cost of bus contracts. ``We have not got a stranglehold,'' Ambrosio told the Times. ``We have stabilized the industry by putting every contractor on an even keel with the same contract terms.'' Large-scale competitive bidding for school bus contracts has not occurred since 1979, the report said. Instead, the school board renews existing contracts with cost-of-business increases. New York City school officials said bidding is unpredictable. The Times said New York pays more per pupil than any other large district in the country and in many cases spends almost twice as much as nearby suburban school systems. It reported Los Angeles had the second highest per-pupil cost at $1,639, but that officials there said 70 percent of the buses are used for integration and that some round trips are up to 80 miles. Milwaukee, with competitive bidding, had the lowest big city cost, at an average cost of $683 per pupil per year. The lowest cost was $333 in Fairfax County, Va., which has its own fleet.

DOC.HEAD: T-Shirt Saying Angers Anti-Rape Group
DOC.TEXT: A Dorothy Parker pun has angered members of an anti-rape group who say the remark printed on T-shirts lacks sensitivity for those ``working in the sex industry.'' ``You can lead a horticulture but you cannot make her think,'' was printed on a $15 shirt to benefit the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust and The Benedum Center. ``It is insulting to women who earn or have earned their living as prostitutes, implying that they are unintelligent, unthinking, unappreciative of culture,'' said a recent letter signed by 24 members of Pittsburgh Action Against Rape. ``It wasn't our intention, and I don't think it was Dorothy Parker's intention, to insult prostitutes,'' said Holly Van Dine, the trust's marketing director. She said the quip ``shouldn't be taken literally.'' Parker, a poet-writer who died in 1967, ``was lacking in consciousness for people working in the sex industry,'' said Anita Mallinger, who signed the letter. ``There are women in professional positions in this city who have worked as prostitutes.''

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Communists Consider Reforms as Election Approaches
DOC.TEXT: Albanian Communists held a national conference today to debate radical changes in their hard-line policies before elections in February, when they will face opposition candidates for the first time. More than 1,000 delegates from local branches of ruling Albania's Labor Party gathered behind closed doors at the parliamentary presidium in the center of the Albanian capital, Tirana, local journalists said. During the one-day meeting, delegates were to hear President and party chief Ramiz Alia propose reforms to the party platform, the journalists said. The reforms were to include opening up the flagging centralized economy, removing restrictions on religion, and improving human rights standards. The Feb. 10 elections would be the first multiparty ballot since the Communists took power in 1944 and plunged the Balkan nation into decades of political and economic isolation. Alia reversed 46 years of hard-line policy earlier this month by allowing the creation of non-Communist political organizations. The move came after student protests over slum-like dormitories led to riots and full-blown demands for democracy in Europe's last bastion of Stalinism. Gramoz Pashko, a founder of Albania's newly formed opposition Democratic Party, said the Communists were trying to win support and stay in power by promising reform. But he said even sweeping changes within the Labor Party could not reverse the harm done by decades of Communist rule. ``If the people support the Communists they will do even more damage to the country and to themselves,'' he said in a telephone interview from Tirana. But he added the opposition would welcome U.S. diplomatic relations with Tirana ``as soon as possible ... given the new realities in Albania.'' ``The United States and all Western governments should have ties so they can press the government to make political pluralism real, not just on paper,'' he said. Pashko said the Democratic Party would continue pressing the government for a postponement of the elections to allow the opposition more time to prepare an effective campaign. Communist authorities on Monday rejected the opposition calls for a postponement. Alia was expected to propose ``a new, radical platform ... that will take a critical stance toward the past and try and open up for the future,'' Shkelqim Beqari, a journalist at the Labor Party daily Zeri i Popullit, said in a telephone interview from Tirana. He said the delegates would then debate how the party should campaign for the elections. The first opposition party, the Democratic Party, was legalized within days and is planning to contest the elections. But although statues of the late Soviet dictator have been removed across the country as Alia moves cautiously toward reform, the Communists still control virtually every sphere of public life, making effective opposition difficult. More than 200 of the hundreds arrested in the rioting were tried and at least one of more than a dozen people sentenced was given a 20-year prison term. Some others received 15 years. The government on Monday rejected the new party's request to postpone the elections for several months to allow it more time to prepare a campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sentences 40 to Up to Seven Years Following Riots
DOC.TEXT: Forty people convicted of rioting during a general strike earlier this month were sentenced by a court to prison terms of one to seven years, officials said today. The sentences late Tuesday night were the most severe handed down so far in dozens of trials following the Dec. 14-15 clashes that left at least five people dead during a general strike in several Moroccan cities. The 52 people on trial were charged with rebellion, destruction of property, carrying arms and attacking the liberty to work. Twelve people were acquitted. Fez, the spiritual and intellectual capital of this North African nation, was the site of the most extensive violence. Soldiers and police intervened as rioters attacked hotels, post offices and a police station. The government says five people were killed in Fez and 127 people injured and that security forces did not fire shots. However, the two unions that called the general strike claim that about 30 people were killed. The court in Fez postponed until Jan. 8 the trials of 33 other people. On that date it will also continue the trial of Mohamed Titna Alaoui, head of the Fez branch of the General Moroccan Workers' Union, which along with the Democratic Work Confederation called the general strike. A Tanger court on Friday sentenced 28 people to three- to five-month prison terms, and a court in Sidi-Kacem sentenced nine people to one-year terms. In Rabat, two opposition parties, Istiqlal and the Socialist Union of Popular Forces, demanded the government publish the identities of those hurt and killed in the violence and the names of foreign powers the government has claimed were interfering in the unrest. The Moroccan government, meanwhile, continued this week its negotiations with unions and employers on ``priority measures'' promised after the disturbances, the official MAP news agency reported. Among the measures under consideration are increases in minimum wages and in social allocations.

DOC.HEAD: Army Promises Interim Pre-Election Govt, But Intentions Unclear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to ADD new announcement, scene from Paramariibo, rights not violated. Pickup 7th, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: The army leaders who seized power over Christmas pledged allegiance to democratic principles and promised to govern in consultation with the elected National Assembly until elections can be held. Surinamese stayed home from work today, a regularly scheduled national holiday. Their only information on the coup came from radio and television broadcasts. Newspapers do not publish on Christmas Day or the day after. Leo Morpurgo, editor of the morning daily De Ware Tyd, said there were no apparent restrictions on the press or on civil rights following the bloodless coup in this Georgia-sized nation on South America's northeastern coast. In a Christmas Day radio address, the acting army chief said the military regime would set up an interim government, hold elections within 100 days and relinquish power. ``The army is not bent on having and keeping power,'' said Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst, who heads the military police and is No. 2 in the military chain-of-command. He said a ``non-political'' government Cabinet would be appointed within a week. The United States and Dutch governments condemned the Christmas Eve coup in the former Dutch colony that toppled the 3-year-old elected government of President Ramsewak Shankar. The coup's mastermind was thought to be Cmdr. Desi Bouterse, who resigned as army chief just hours before Shankar was toppled. Bouterse and Shankar had been engaged in a long and bitter dispute. Bouterse has not been seen or made any public statements since the coup. He ruled this nation of 400,000 people for eight years after seizing power in a 1980 military coup and has wielded considerable power behind the scenes since Shankar's government was elected by a landslide in November 1987. Appearing on television Tuesday night, army spokesman Hubert Eersel said the army would adhere to five principles. He said the army would be guided by the constitution - approved in a plesbiscite in October 1987 - recognize the National Assembly, and seek the legislative body's guidance on economic matters. He said ``the democratic and constitutional state will be the guiding principle for all proceedings,'' and that all treaties signed since independence from the Netherlands in 1975 ``will be respected fully.'' It was not immediately clear how the coup might affect an insurgency that has crippled the mining of bauxite - a major export used in producing aluminum. A peace agreement between guerrillas and the ousted government was opposed by the army. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Sondra McCarty urged restoration of the civilian government. ``We condemn this violation of constitutional order in Suriname,'' she said. ``We call on the Surinamese military to restore power immediately to the democratically elected authorities of that country.'' The Dutch Foreign Ministry said it ``sharply condemns the undemocratic seizure of power by the Surinamese Army.'' The military notified the government that it was taking control while Shankar and his Cabinet met late Monday night in emergency session at the presidential palace, according to a government official. The official said the president and the other officials decided to go home and offer no resistance, thereby avoiding bloodshed. Not a single shot was fired, the official said on condition of anonymity. Reached by telephone Tuesday at his home, Shankar said he and his ministers were not under house arrest and had complete freedom of movement. ``I'm free to go wherever I want to,'' he said. Bouterse, in his resignation statement, cited differences with Shankar, whom he described as a ``joker.'' The final straw, Bouterse indicated, was Shankar's alleged failure to intervene when Dutch authorities denied the military leader visas and refused to allow him to be interviewed by reporters on three separate stopovers in the Netherlands this month. Bouterse announced his resignation Saturday on his return from his latest trip, to Ghana and Switzerland. Bouterse and Shankar, however, have been at odds ever since the 1987 election in which Shankar's three-party coalition, the Front for Democracy and Development, easily defeated the military-backed National Democracy Party. The military leader bitterly opposes the government's attempt to negotiate settlement of a costly insurgency by Suriname's Bush Negro minority, who seek better living conditions. Bouterse's former bodyguard, Ronny Brunswijk, launched the guerrilla war in July 1986 that closed bauxite mines in the eastern part of the country.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Henry obit in Deaths package to CORRECT day of death to Saturday, sted Monday, ADDS background on career.
DOC.TEXT: James T. Henry, a former city commission president and Ohio's third black mayor, died Saturday at age 80. No cause of death was given at the hospital where he died. Henry was first elected to the City Commission in 1952 and chosen as commission president in 1963. He became the state's third black mayor - after Robert Henry of Springfield and Carl Stokes of Cleveland - when Xenia city commissioners elected him in 1969. Henry also was a retired chairman of the earth science department at Central State University and had taught geology and geography there.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS age to 72, sted 82.
DOC.TEXT: William F. O'Hara, who survived 88 days on an ice cap in Greenland after a bomber crashed during World War II, died Monday at Mercy hospital at age 72. The cause of death was not immediately available. He was the navigator and one of nine crewmen on a B-17 Flying Fortress that crashed Nov. 9, 1942, while searching for a missing aircraft. Two crew members and three would-be rescuers died before the survivors were saved Feb. 5, 1943. O'Hara had both legs amputated below the knee as a result of the ordeal, which was the subject of Col. Bernt Balchen's book ``War Below Zero.'' After military service, he went on to serve as register of wills in Lackawanna County for 12 years and held a seat on the state Public Utility Commission for 11 years.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BUCHAREST
Former King Deported Hours After Return From 43 Years In Exile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with king's arrival in Switzerland. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `He was...' Edits to TRIM.
DOC.TEXT: King Michael, Romania's former monarch, returned to his Swiss exile today after being expelled by the Bucharest government less than 12 hours after he had arrived o a surprise visit, his first in four decades. The 69-year-old former king returned to Romania exactly a year after the execution of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in a popular revolution. The monarch had been forced into exile with the Communist takeover 43 years ago. The Romanian government, already facing mounting strikes and protests by an opposition that accuses it of being a Communist regime in disguise, apparently feared the visit by Michael might stir up unrest. It unceremoniously threw him out on the ground that he had not secured permission to visit. After Ceausescu was overthrown, the former king had announced himself ready to return from exile as head of a constitutional monarchy ``if my people want me to come back.'' The National Salvation Front, which took power during last year's revolution in Romania and won subsequent elections, extended no invitation for him to visit, and had refused to grant him a visa. In June, the former king accused the Front of leading the country back toward Communist dictatorship. Before being put on a Romanian-chartered flight to Switzerland this morning, Michael termed his expulsion ``a rather sorry state of affairs.'' The plane carrying the former monarch and a small entourage landed at Zurich airport today, airport officials said. The king was traveling by connecting flight to Geneva, where he lives. Michael had arrived on Tuesday night at Bucharest's Otopeni airport on his private plane from Switzerland. He was accompanied by his wife, Ana de Bourbon-Parme; his daughter, Sophie; and several journalists and aides. They were met by another daughter, Margarita, who was already in Romania on a visit. Michael was to have attended a Mass there today and leave Romania tonight. But soon after the group arrived, the Interior Ministry issued a statement saying the three family members had arrived without visas and ``crossed the border fraudulently.'' Sophie insisted that Michael had received a visa. ``My father received a visa just like this one,'' she said, displaying her passport with a separate stamped visa document. She said officials had taken her father's Danish diplomatic passport. Michael also said he had a visa. Danielle Maillefer, a spokeswoman for Michael, said Premier Petre Roman had ``strongly advised him not to come, but did not give a firm yes or no.'' She said Michael ``felt he has a role to play in Romania,'' and so decided to ignore Roman's advice. The former king, who is of the house of Hohenzollern-Sigmaringen, ruled Romania twice for short periods. He first succeeded his grandfather, Ferdinand, in 1927 as Michael I, after his father, Carol, left the country. After returning in 1930, Carol acceded to the throne and ruled for 10 years. Michael was then crowned again and reigned until he was forced to abdicate when the Communists took power in 1947. He later declared the abdication invalid. During World War II, he ruled briefly under Gen. Ion Antonescu, who was allied with the Axis led by Nazi Germany. Michael is seen as important in the 1944 coup that removed Antonescu, allowing Romania to change sides and support the Allies. He helped install a government with a token Communist presence. The Communists rigged elections in 1947 and forced Michael to abdicate.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Vessel Boarded Outside Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to ADD more comment from Neuhart, Navy saying the ship carried 800 tons of sugar, CLARIFY that only U.S. sailors were involved in the fracas. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Navy sailors boarded an Iraqi freighter in the Arabian Sea today and fired warning shots in a fracas with the crew and female members of a peace mission aboard the vessel, a U.S. military spokesman said. In the 30-minute confrontation aboard the 11,333-ton Ibn Khaldoon, the sailors also fired a smoke grenade and a noisemaker grenade ``for crowd control,'' said a U.S. Navy spokesman, Cmdr. Mark Neuhart. The vessel, en route to the Iraqi port of Basra, carried 800 tons of sugar, Neuhart said. The cargo was in violation of A U.N. embargo on trade with Iraq aimed at forcing Saddam Hussein to relinquish Kuwait. A British defense ministry spokesman, quoted by the Press Association in London, said helicopter-borne U.S. sailors led the boarding party and British and Australian military men later followed by boat. He said the operation was carried out off Oman near Masirah Island. The ship was ``secured'' and escorted to a nearby anchorage, he said. Neuhart said the trouble started when the sailors approached the pilot house of the freighter ``and a number of the crew attempted to hold the boarding party members back and grab their weapons.'' He said members of a female peace delegation aboard the ship, which included Americans, also joined in the fracas, but that neither the crew nor the women used weapons against the boarding party. He said that in the fracas, ``one of our guys was knocked over by one of the women.'' The Iraqi shipmaster claimed that there were two heart attacks and two miscarriages because of the boardings, but a U.S. Navy medical officer found the claims unfounded, Neuhart said. ``After consultations with the master, he agreed the passengers did not require medical evacuation and there were no injuries,'' said Neuhart. The master agreed to divert his ship to an unidentified port to discharge the cargo, the Navy spokesman said. The ship was carrying about 240 passengers and a 40-member Iraqi crew. Baghdad Radio said today the women aboard were from 10 Arab countries, Italy, China, the United States and Japan. Pro-Iraqi Arab news reports have dubbed the Ibn Khaldoon ``the peace ship'' and said it was sailing to Basra in a demonstration of support for Saddam and his initiatives for solving the Persian Gulf crisis. The Ibn Khaldoon went through the Suez Canal in mid-December en route from Algeria. The shipmaster gave the vessel's origin of voyage as Aden, Yemen. The vessel refused to stop for a search after ``repeated requests'' when first intercepted by the Australian frigate HMS Sydney early today. The Sydney, five U.S. warships and the Britain's HMS Brazen were involved in the boarding.

DOC.HEAD: Three Jewish Settlers Who Killed Arabs Win Early Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with three soldiers stabbed, conditions. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `The three...' ^By KARIN LAUB
DOC.TEXT: Three Jewish West Bank settlers were freed from prison today after serving less than seven years of a life term for killing three Palestinian students and maiming two West Bank mayors in the early 1980s. Scores of chanting and dancing settlers carried the three on their shoulders out of Maasiyahu Prison in the central Israeli town of Ramle. Dozens of Israeli jurists and lawmakers outside the prison protested the release, saying it will encourage Jewish extremism. In the occupied Gaza Strip, meanwhile, troops shot and killed a Palestinian today after he stabbed three soldiers patrolling the Shati refugee camp, the army said. Palestinian reports identified the slain man as Ala Abdul-Latif Obeid, 30, from Shati. Doctors at Gaza's Shifa Hospital said he was shot at least 30 times. His death brought to 780 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the 3-year-old uprising against the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Another 322 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. Fifty-seven Israelis also died in the violence. Two of soldiers who were stabbed were in fair condition at Tel Hashomer Hospital in Tel Aviv and the third was treated for a minor wound at Soroka Hospital in Beersheva, the army spokesman's office said. The three settlers freed today were the last of a 28-member cell called the ``Jewish underground'' to be released from prison. The group carried out bombings and attacks aimed at Palestinian officials, mosques and the Islamic College in the occupied West Bank. Menahem Livni, the leader of the group who as released today, said he was not sorry for what he did, though officials who reduced the sentences had said the three settlers expressed remorse. ``The use of the word regret in this case is childish,'' Livni told Israel radio after he left prison with the two other convicted settlers, Shaul Nir and Uzi Sharbav. Livni and other settler leaders claimed the group was pushed to violence because the government didn't crack down hard enough on Palestinian militants. ``There is a grave shortcoming in the way the government is dealing with Arab terror. This shortcoming has persisted for 10 years,'' Livni said. In Israel, a life sentence usually means the inmate must serve at least 20 years. There is no death penalty, except for Nazi war crimes. President Chaim Herzog reduced the sentences of the three men to 10 years in 1989 after being ``convinced that the three had expressed unambiguous and honest regrets,'' the president's spokesman said at the time. Two weeks ago, a parole committee cut the terms by another third for good behavior. ``This is a message of contempt for human life, of making a difference between one type of life and another, and it violates the basic tenet of equality before the law,'' said Yitzhak Zamir, a former Israeli attorney general protesting outside the prison. The three settlers released today had been jailed since they were arrested in April 1984. All three were convicted in July 1985. Livni was convicted of masterminding three June 1980 car bombings that maimed two West Bank mayors, Bassam Shaka of Nablus and Karim Halaf of Ramallah, and blinded an Israeli police explosives expert. Shaka, wheelchair-bound after losing his legs in the explosion, said the early release was part of Israeli government policy to ``encourage extremists to act against Palestinians.'' Nir and Sharbav were found guilty of breaking into the Islamic College in the West Bank town of Hebron in July 1983, throwing a hand grenade and firing wildly. Three students were killed and 30 wounded in the attack. Livni, who planned the attack on the college, said the victims ``were not innocent. ``The Islamic college is a hornet's nest of terror, and there is nonstop incitement there,'' Livni said. The ``Jewish Underground'' was also blamed for unsuccessful attempts to plant bombs on five Arab buses in east Jerusalem and to blow up the Dome of the Rock, one of Islam's holiest monuments.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Dec. 23 The Oregonian, Portland, Ore., on the Soviet Union: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's surprising resignation is a tremendous shock to the West on two counts: It potentially takes a Western-looking and trusted negotiator from a key position. Shevardnadze's reason - a reactionary trend toward dictatorship - shows how uncertain the Soviet Union's future, including its relationship with the West, really is. Shevardnadze has been a key associate of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, and that team has been a good one from the Western perspective. The international result has been breathtaking - the effective release of Eastern Europe from the Soviet grip and the breakup of the Warsaw Pact as a military force. Within the Soviet Union, however, the situation is chaotic. A political revolution of rising expectations has unleashed yearnings for independence among various Soviet republics. The food supply and other economic indicators have gotten worse. Many are calling for forcible imposition of central control. It's no surprise that such disorder brings cries for order at any cost. But Shevardnadze's warning is as chilling for the West as for the Soviet Congress that he issued it to: ``Dictatorship is coming - I say this with all responsibility. Nobody knows what kind of dictatorship it will be, and who will come - what kind of dictator, and what kind of system.'' From the Western perspective, the hope is that reform doesn't break down in the Soviet Union. The reactionaries Shevardnadze warned against are likely to hold the old, brooding Russian view of the world, particularly the West, as a threat and never to be trusted. The best policy for the West is one of benign non-interference - to show we are ready to be friends with whatever manifestation the Soviet Union takes if it is equally ready. We can hope for reform, but must be ready to work with whatever results. --- Dec. 24 The Birmingham (Ala.) News on the Soviet Union: ... Shevardnadze's resignation on principle certainly is something we haven't seen much of here in the West from Soviet political leaders. In the past, those moves took place behind the Kremlin's dark walls. And Shevardnadze's warning that if a dictatorship is created, there's no guaranteeing who the next dictator will be must be considered. But it's clearly a warning more for Gorbachev and the Soviet people to consider than for us. We've seen Soviet dictators before; our way is clear. We must maintain a strong military force. We have to keep the NATO alliance viable. Arms reduction talks must continue, but our negotiators should be as diligent as ever in assuring that any agreement reached is verifiable and enforceable. And while we might prefer dealing with Gorbachev and our interests may best be served if he remains the Soviet leader, we can't bank solely on him. If Shevardnadze was trying to tell us anything by his abrupt resignation, that probably was it. --- Dec. 23 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on the Soviet Union: For a year now, everybody has been celebrating the end of the Cold War. Recent events in the Soviet Union, however, might make us more comfortable with the word ``truce.'' As disturbing as it is, Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation as Soviet foreign minister at least concentrates the attention of everyone, East and West, on the seriousness of the crisis in the Soviet Union. ... Does Mikhail Gorbachev really stand on the side of democracy and openness, and how far is he willing to go to fight for these principles? His enemies are at the gates, perhaps within them, and he can't dither too much longer before casting his lot. The lesson for the West: That we should not tie our plans too closely to individual leaders in a place as unpredictable as the Soviet Union. And we should not necessarily expect the more benign regime of the recent past to continue. It is worrying that powerful forces have expressed ever-increasing resentment about the Soviets' declining world influence, about the loss of control of Eastern Europe, and so on. The Soviets will still be in a position to threaten the West if new leaders should decide to act on these resentments. --- Dec. 24 San Francisco Chronicle on the Persian Gulf: Generals have been known to fire from the verbal hip, sometimes with a naive insouciance about just what it is they are saying - and their words' potential consequences. In the case of Lieutenant General Calvin Waller, however, this deputy commander of American forces in the gulf was simply being candid about what many have already intimated: American troops are not yet at peak strength and efficiency for what may be an extremely difficult desert operation. His words take some of the pressure off January 15, that looming date on which seemingly Saddam would retreat, or we would attack. Generals may be isolated, but they sense the hazards of war more acutely than diplomats. Let the attack come, if it must, when we are ready. --- Dec. 20 Beacon Journal, Akron, Ohio, on minority scholarships: The Bush administration's partial retreat from its assault against college scholarships for blacks and other minorities was wise. But it did not go far enough. In shifting gears rapidly and with clear nudges from an embarrassed White House, Michael L. Williams, assistant secretary for civil rights in the U.S. Department of Education, left standing at least part of his original and unfortunate ban on scholarships designated for minorities. ... In retreating, however, Williams said colleges could award such scholarships without penalty as long as the money came from private donations or federal funds designed to aid minority students. He then said colleges would not be allowed to use money from their general operating budgets for scholarships based on race. ... How such a far-reaching policy could have been set in motion without presidential knowledge defies understanding. Why it was not totally reversed is now even more of a mystery, especially since Bush made it clear ``I've long been committed'' to such scholarships. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: such scholarships.
DOC.TEXT: --- Dec. 20 The Repository, Canton, Ohio, on the war on drugs: Let's not get too excited about those government figures that show a drop in the use of cocaine over the last five years, let's just be cautiously optimistic. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said the latest figures show some progress in the effort to change attitudes and drug habits, and President Bush said the statistics demonstrate that ``our hard work is paying off.'' Maybe so, but we're a long way from being out of the woods. The statistics also reflect the fact that many adolescents are experimenting with drugs and the number of people who use cocaine daily has increased since 1988. This means the nation has a long way to go before anyone can declare that the drug menace is under control. We all must keep fighting. --- Dec. 20 The Press-Courier, Oxnard, Calif., on commercial banks: Contrary to the Chicken Little scenarios gaining currency on Capitol Hill, the banking industry is not about to go the way of the beleaguered savings-and-loan system. For starters, banks have been more tightly regulated than the thrifts. That stricter oversight is one reason banks made $26 billion last year, while the S&L industry lost $19 billion. Many thrifts disintegrated during a period when the government gave them a free hand to make risky investments under the cover of federally guaranteed deposit insurance. Banks always have been subject to much stricter government control. In addition, many failed S&Ls were undercapitalized and thus vulnerable to looting by larcenous managers. As publicly held corporations, major banks are required to open their books to public scrutiny, so such abuses are much easier to detect promptly. Despite several weak years, the banking industry is still capable of regaining its financial health with a timely assist from Congress .... --- Dec. 24 Chicago Tribune on the elections in Haiti: Last week's elections in Haiti were praiseworthy for what didn't happen as well as for what did. Unlike in 1987, when 37 people died in election day violence at the hands of thugs believed backed by the army, the military this time provided security at the polls rather than trying to subvert the democratic process. Voting was generally peaceful as 70 percent of registered Haitians turned out to elect Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a priest who advocates liberation theology, by a sizeable majority. ... Aristide appealed to the young and the poor by stressing self-reliance, social justice, economic reform and the elimination of corruption. In a country where annual per capita income is under $400, the poor are the constituency to champion. From now on, though, it will be the powerholders - the military, business leaders, landowners - who can be expected to watch the priest-president's every move, looking for missteps to exploit for their selfish ends. --- Dec. 19 The Commercial Appeal, Memphis, Tenn., on the messiness of democracy: Watching former dictatorships hold elections, you realize what inexperience with freedom means. What looks to a hardened Westerner like the normal rough-and-tumble of a campaign may shock and mortify a Pole. In any event, slander charges have been brought against Stanislaw Tyminski, defeated in Poland's recent presidential race. A curious upstart candidate who returned from 22 years in Canada and Peru to run from president, Tyminski got the world's attention by outpolling the prime minister in the first round. But then he lost by a big margin to Lech Walesa two weeks later after a bitter campaign. Tyminski enraged Poles with his Communist connections, shady past and fierce attacks on the prime minister and Walesa. ... One local prosecutor overreacted, however, when the candidate falsely accused the government of selling off state property too cheaply. If convicted of insulting the Polish state, Tyminski could go to prison for six months to eight years. One sympathizes with the wish that democratic politics could always be scrupulously fair, campaigns always clean. But veterans of democracy know better. They know, too, that the way to counter a candidate's lies is by exposing them publicly - not by trotting out the very law the old Communist government used to silence dissidents or anyone else it wanted to punish. ---

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged with Circular Saw Homicide
DOC.TEXT: Police today arrested a man for allegedly killing his mother with an electric circular saw as she slept on Christmas Eve. Detectives said Clifton Williams, 30, linked several extension cords together and savagely attacked his 50-year-old mother, Dessie Williams, in her bed leaving her in a pool of blood in a second-floor hallway of their home. The suspect, who relatives said has a history of mental problems, was arrested at his home this morning after being at large since Monday. An arrest warrant charges him with first-degree murder and possession of a deadly weapon. The body of Mrs. Williams, a hospital housekeeper, was discovered Monday by her daughter, Sheila Mayor, 33. ``I didn't have to get up the stairs all the way to see my mother. I screamed and ran out of the house,'' she said. Mayor and her other brother, Norman Williams, said Clifton Williams had been diagnosed as a paranoid-schizophrenic. Medication kept his condition under control, they said, but he was prone to irrational behavior when he would refuse to take his pills. He had gone a long time without his medication, they said. ``He was different from all of us,'' Mayor said. ``You do something one way and he'd do the opposite.'' ``But we always felt he didn't have the capability of hurting anybody,'' Norman Williams said. Clifton Williams kept the electric saw in his bedroom, using it at times to cut wood into pieces, said Mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Newspaper: Emergency Care Saved Performing Pandas
DOC.TEXT: Emergency medical care at a Chinese zoo saved two star performing pandas that had become critically ill because of intestinal problems, an official newspaper reported. The Liberation Daily said Tuesday that the pandas at the Fuzhou Zoo in southeastern Fujian province were near death when they were diagnosed as having acute intestinal inflammation and intestinal blockage. The diagnosis was made early this month after zoo officials held urgent consultations with medical and animal experts, the newspaper reported. After nine days of special treatment, Qingqing and Yuanyuan had recovered, it said. The report said Qingqing, 15, and Yuanyuan, 9, have performed for audiences around the world, including stops in the United States, Australia and Hong Kong. Their popular stunts include riding bicycles, doing somersaults and dunking a basketball. Fewer than 1,000 of the endangered giant pandas still live in the wild, most of them in southwestern China near Chengdu.

DOC.HEAD: Year's Company Entertainment Expenses Totaled Record $36.5 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Japanese corporate executives wined, dined and golfed their way to a record $36.53 billion in expense account spending between February 1989 and January 1990, a tax agency report said Wednesday. The annual report compiled by the National Tax Administration Agency said the figure was 9.4 percent higher than the previous year's, which had been the record. Company expense account spending is tax deductible in Japan. The agency said it calculated this year's figure by analyzing reports from 59,772 of 1,962,026 businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Rabies Scare Monitored In Oman
DOC.TEXT: Police marksmen went looking for foxes and wild dogs on Wednesday as authorities began trying to curb an outbreak of rabies that has left one 8-year-old boy dead. The outbreak also has killed camals and other tribal livestock, and it is believed to be centered in northern Oman near villages surrounding Ibri, 200 miles from the capital. The boy who died of the disease was the first documented case of human rabies infection in the sultunate. A task force from the World Health Organization will work with state health and agricultural officials to try to stop the spread of the disease. As part of the effort, police will shoot wild dogs and other animals that can carry the disease. Ministry of Health spokesman M.S. Elbualy said the situation ``has been a matter of concern but it is under control.'' ``We are looking into methods of introducing oral bait containing a vaccine which will enable these wild populations in effect to vaccinate themselves against rabies and to prevent further spread of the disease,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: to punish.
DOC.TEXT: --- Dec. 21 The Daily Telegraph, London, on the Soviet Union: The resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze ... provides dramatic confirmation of what the outside world has suspected fr months - that the Soviet Union is teetering on the brink of dictatorship. The enormous authority which Parliament has handed to Mr. Gorbachev, his own prevarication over radical changes and his frequent references to the importance of law and order suggest that he is prepared to halt, or even reverse, internal reform for the sake of holding the country together. --- Dec. 21 The Independent, London, on the Soviet Union: The lights are going out in the Soviet Union. The resignation of Mr. Eduard Shevardnadze is the despairing gesture of a sincere and exhausted man who does not want to be associated with the journey into darkness. Because he has supported reform so fully, he takes with him a large portion of Mr. Gorbachev's credibility. He will also be a loss to his country in other ways, for he played a central role in its opening to the world and its rapprochement with the West. --- Dec. 23 The Sunday Telegraph, London, on the Soviet Union: Much Western piety surrounds Western fears of Soviet ``dictatorship.'' Doubtless, it would be bad in comparison with Western democracy and a free market. But Gorbachev seems incapable of creating that happy combination. The democracy he has produced is, it seems, a drag on the free market. Instead of accepting the necessity for unemployment straight away, as Mrs. Thatcher did when she started reforming the British economy in the early Eighties, Mr. Gorbachev encouraged people, in the name of democracy, to express dissent if they thought he was doing things wrongly. Those with vested interest in the existing order slowed him down. The Soviet Union now has the blessings of political freedom but not the blessings of economic freedom. A ``dictatorship'' might well be secure enough to withdraw guaranteed employment, and thus force workers to emerge from their age-old sloth. It could break up the collective farms and parcel them out among private owners just as those earlier dictators, the first Bolsheviks, did the opposite. Farmers would then have the incentive to produce food for the city shops. Democracy and the free market are not dependent on each other. That they exist together in the West is because of something akin to an evolutionary miracle. Asian countries with free markets have become rich without much democracy. Britain herself was the richest country in the world long before most of her people had the vote. Naturally, we in the West fear a new Soviet dictatorship because we fear it might revive the Soviet military threat to us. That is the only good reason for fearing it. We should not continue sentimentally to suggest that Mr. Gorbachev's freedoms, and Mr. Gorbachev himself, are essential to the well-being of the Soviet people. --- Dec. 24 The Times, London, on the Persian Gulf crisis: The Gulf confrontation has revived the spirit in which the United Nations was conceived, a force for world order through which the civilized nations could join to counter aggression, notably aggression against small states. That many Arab and Third World nations have aligned themselves with this vision of a new world order is as significant as the unity between the superpowers. What has emerged in the past six months is the possibility of a total realignment in the vast military might built up during the cold war, a realignment in the cause not of regional self-defense but of world order. The world ill-serves itself by criticising the pain through which the United States is now passing as it debates its inevitably dominant role in this order. American power, for all its inadequacies, its hesitations, its ineptitudes, remains unquestionably the best hope that civilized standards will triumph. A high price may yet be extracted. The Gulf may erupt and swiftly give the lie to too much Christmas optimism. But war has never been a painless route to a greater peace. The year fast closing has shown a glimpse of that peace, and marked out the route. There have been few more hopeful years than 1990. --- Dec. 20 Straits Times, Singapore, on Cambodia: The irony might as yet turn against Hanoi and its Phnom Penh satellite. It is not they, but the battle hardened and logistically strong Khmer Rouge that can gain most from a breakdown of the peace process. Without a return of more Vietnamese troops to Cambodia - or the even more unlikely arrival of other sympathetic foreign forces - the Phnom Penh regime is no position to deal with the Khmer Rouge militarily. It would appear to be in the interests of all concerned, therefore, for Vietnam and its lackeys to try and make a success of the talks on Cambodia opening in Paris this week. Using sovereignty as a wedge against peace is not only unsustainable, but might prove to be counter-productive. If there is no peace, what Cambodia will have is not sovereignty, but war. The Khmer Rouge has never been known to find that preference distasteful. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
U.S. Denies Report That Baker to Meet Saddam in Baghdad Jan. 9
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th pvs, `Maariv said...' with 1 graf to CORRECT Ross' title to top Baker aide, sted assistant secretary of state. Pickup 14th, `The Foreign...'
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli newspaper reported today that Secretary of State James A. Baker III will likely meet Saddam Hussein in Baghdad for talks on Jan. 9, but a U.S. official said no date for any negotiations had been set. The independent daily Maariv attributed the report to accounts reaching Jerusalem from Israeli diplomats, based ontheir talks with U.S. colleagues. But in Washington, State Department spokeswoman Sondra McCarty said there was no such agreement on talks aimed at resolving the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Our embassy in Baghdad is in almost daily contact with the Iraqi Foreign Ministry. There has been no Iraqi movement on the question of dates,'' she said. She declined to elaborate. Israel's Foreign Ministry said it had no information on any meeting between Baker and the Iraqi president. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner, also said he had no knowledge of such a proposal. Ruth Yaron, spokeswoman for the Israeli Embassy in Washington, also said: ``We have no knowledge of anything of the sort.'' She called the newspaper report ``pure speculation.'' Maariv said the meeting was set amid apparent secret negotiations between the United States and Iraq. The Iraqi president has said for months that any resolution of the gulf crisis should be linked to a settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Saddam has recalled his ambassadors from the United States, the United Nations and several Western European nations in past days, giving rise to speculation that a new diplomatic initiative was in the works. The paper said senior officials in Washington told Israeli representatives that Baker would agree to visit Baghdad on Jan. 9, despite its proximity to the Jan. 15 United Nations ultimatum for an Iraqi troop pullout from Kuwait. Saddam has previously offered to receive Baker in Baghdad on Jan. 12, but the White House has rejected that date as being too late. It has said any date after Jan. 3 would not be acceptable. Saddam is also said to be demanding that the U.N. Security Council pass a resolution linking Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to a settlement of the Palestinian issue. The Israeli newspaper Hadashot quoted the Jordanian daily Al Shaab as saying Saddam would announce such a plan in the next few days. The United States and Israel both have opposed any linkage between the Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait and Israel's 23-year occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Maariv said a Jan. 9 Baker-Saddam meeting could be linked to plans by a top aide to Baker, Dennis Ross, to visit Israel on Jan. 7 to discuss new Middle East peace proposals. The Foreign Ministry spokesman said Ross was expected to come to Israel on Jan. 7 or 9. The State Department appears to be putting together a proposal for opening peace talks between Israel and Arab countries in tandem with holding municipal elections for 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied territories, Maariv said. Maariv also reported ``military movement'' along Israel's border with Jordan, and Israel's chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, warned Iraq may try to use Jordan as a springboard for action against Israel. Shomron said in a statement broadcast on Israeli radio stations that Jordan was ``liable to find itself - despite its will or that of its leaders - caught up in Iraqi moves.'' An army spokesman declined comment on the reported military moves along the Jordan frontier. The military routinely refuses comment on reports of military maneuvers. The spokesman, whose name cannot be used under army regulations, added there was no change in the army's level of alert since a heightened preparedness was declared at the outset of the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Post-Christmas Sales Lure the Bargain-Minded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with analyst's quotes today. Picks up 2nd graf pvs: `Prospects for ...
DOC.TEXT: Shopkeepers across the country looked for bargain-hunting buyers today, hoping to clear out slow-moving holiday merchandise that made this a lackluster season. Today is traditionally one of the busiest shopping days of the year, as hordes descend to return gifts and comb aisles for after-Christmas deals. ``Generally, I think retailers would be quite pleased if their sales matched what they were a year ago,'' said David A. Williamson, a retail analyst for the Advest Group Inc., an investment research company in Hartford, Conn. ``Profits will be at least 10 percent below a year ago,'' he said today. ``Consumers were very tight with their dollars,'' Williamson said. ``Retailers had to be very promotional just to get customers into the stores, let alone buy stuff.'' Prospects for a reversal of the lackluster holiday shopping season were slight, with much of the country mired in economic recession, but buyers who take advantage of steep markdowns on Christmas cards, decorations and wrapping paper might help ease storekeepers' pain somewhat. Pre-Christmas sales were hurt by the economic slowdown, especially in the Northeast, and fears of possible harder times if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, analysts said. ``We're slightly below expectations,'' said Matthew Howard, senior vice president for marketing at Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retail store chain. A surge in the three days before Christmas helped, he said Monday. Other high-profile retailers also reported an 11th-hour jump in sales, but the extra business wasn't considered enough to turn the season around. Retailers traditionally count on Christmas sales for up to half of yearly receipts.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Remember Mao, Not Always Respectfully
DOC.TEXT: The line was short Wednesday as a bitter wind whipped around the Mao Tse-tung Memorial Hall, where the late revolutionary's body lies under glass. Even on Mao's 97th birthday, few ordinary Chinese seem interested in remembering their former leader, who died 14 years ago. When they do remember, it's not always with respect. There's a joke that says senior leader Deng Xiaoping, seeking advice, telephoned the late Premier Chou En-lai in heaven and Mao in hell. When Deng got the bill, there was a huge charge for the long-distance call to heaven but no charge for calling Mao. ``Local calls are free,'' the operator explained. Other jokes make fun of Mao's infatuation in the 1930s with movie actress Jiang Qing, for whom he divorced his wife. He married Jiang, who became the screeching, violence-inciting policewoman of the arts during the 1966-76 leftist Cultural Revolution. The Cultural Revolution remains the main blight on Mao's image as leader of the Communist struggle against imperialism and founder of what is officially called New China. During the reformist 1980s, Mao's heirs in power were too busy dismantling his farming communes and rebuilding the legal structures he destroyed to spend much time commemorating him. But since the party was challenged by huge pro-democracy protests last year, Mao has made a bit of a comeback in official circles. Activities to mark the birthday were more numerous than in recent years, and included performances of Mao's poetry set to music and scholarly forums on ``Mao thought.'' The People's Daily said a new book was published compiling remarks by Mao that could apply to the recent collapse of socialism in other countries, reflecting the party's position that his ideas remain a living, relevant force. At the Mao Memorial in Tiananmen Square, however, there was nothing to mark the day as different from any other. ``Line up four across,'' a museum guard barked at Chinese visitors, most speaking in out-of-town accents, who waited to enter at mid-morning. They filed through in groups of about 50, one group every five minutes or so, many ignoring the sign at the door that said: ``Please take off your hat.'' Guards allowed visitors little time to pay respects to Mao, who lies under a national flag in a glass coffin. Only his face, preternaturally pink and shiny, is exposed. Visitors were ushered along the sides of the room, separated from the coffin by at least 10 feet and by large, clear plastic partitions. Memorial officials said attendance for the day was about 17,000, but the figure seemed exaggerated. Souvenir vendors outside, selling plastic thermometers bearing Mao's picture and Mao Tse-tung Memorial Hall chopstick sets, say daily attendance is generally under 5,000. The memorial was closed for most of 1989, ostensibly so the building could be repaired. However, a Westerner who first saw Mao's body several years ago said it appeared some touchup work also was done on the body. Officials said Mao's one surviving son, one of two daughters and three grandchildren visited the memorial and brought flower wreaths, as they do each year. Ordinary visitors were not allowed to see the family, who are rarely mentioned in the official media. It was not known if Mao's widow, Jiang, now 74 and believed still in prison, marked the day in any way. Filming recently began in Beijing of yet another movie about Mao, following several similar war-era epics last year. The new movie, about the death of a son in the Korean War, will try to show a new side of the stern leader, his human face and love for his family, the studio said. A scene shot in the ballroom of the historic Beijing Hotel showed Mao and several dozen aides, all in their 50s and 60s, fox-trotting with a host of pigtailed teen-age girls. Jiang was not shown.

DOC.HEAD: Deng Seen in Public For First Time Since July
With AM-China-Mao's Birthday, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Senior leader Deng Xiaoping made his first public appearance since July, voting in citywide elections in the capital on Wednesday. The 86-year-old leader, widely believed to be suffering from cancer, appeared frail. Deng was shown on state television moving steadily but a bit shakily up to the voter registration table, where he sat down to sign his name. His daughter held his arm as he walked to the ballot box and dropped his ballot in. However, the official Xinhua News Agency described Deng as walking vigorously to the polling station inside Zhongnanhai, the Communist Party's vast, red-walled compound in central Beijing. ``With a beaming smile on his face, Deng received a voting slip from a young election worker after showing his elector's card,'' Xinhua said. Deng had not made a confirmed appearance in public since July, when he visited the Asian Games Village. A Japanese newspaper recently reported that a tourist saw Deng and President Yang Shangkun eating dinner in a public restaurant, but there was no official confirmation. Since the last sighting of Deng, rumors had circulated that he was on his deathbed, as happens whenever he is long absent. Although Deng retired nearly a year ago from his last official post, there is fear that his death will leave a power vacuum, with no single leader strong enough to hold together competing ideological and regional factions. Some Western diplomats, however, say to a certain extent that has already happened. Deng lost prestige as a result of the democracy movement in 1989 and its bloody quashing by the army, and hard-liners reportedly have criticized him directly in behind-the-scenes debates over China's future course. The party leadership has been unable to agree even on a new economic blueprint for the next five years, suggesting that Deng is no longer playing policy-maker and power broker as he had since 1978. Chinese sources said the party finally opened a long-delayed Central Committee meeting on Tuesday to discuss the five-year plan, but that deep divisions remained. Several recent articles in the official media have summed up Deng's achievements completely in the past tense, as if he no longer were contributing to the party. The television news also showed Premier Li Peng, Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin and other top leaders casting their ballots in Zhongnanhai. The election was for delegates to district and county people's congresses, China's lowest-level representative bodies and the only offices directly elected by the public. The congresses have no legislative power and act mainly as conduits for citizens' ideas and complaints. But they are the basis for China's assertion that it has a democratic system. Beijing has 18 such congresses with a total of nearly 17,000 delegates. Given China's one-party system, the campaign was a placid affair, with no debates or candidate advertisements and little contact between candidates and voters. Nominations are made chiefly by closed-door committees and candidates must have good ideological credentials. The law permits at most two candidates per seat, but in practice the ratio is generally lower. In the Zhongnanhai district, for example, Xinhua said Deng and other voters were to choose two of three candidates. Ballots were to be counted by hand, with results taking several days to tabulate.

DOC.HEAD: Top Auction Houses Come to Berlin, Hoping For Eastern Finds
DOC.TEXT: The world's top auction houses have set up shop in Berlin, seeking to acquire and sell treasures kept hidden during Communist rule in eastern Euope. Sotheby's, the world's largest art auction house, has chosen a former Prussian palace in eastern Berlin as the site of its new office. The previous tenant was the German-Soviet Friendship Society. Rival Christie's has selected a posh ground-floor setting just off the Kurfuerstendamm, western Berlin's most fashionable shopping boulevard. The arrival of the two major auction houses could signal the start of a revival of Berlin's prewar role as Germany's major art center. Both aim to explore the art world of the formerly Communist east, largely closed off to capitalist dealers durin the Cold War. ``Sotheby's had long thought about going to Berlin. With the opening of the Wall, it became necessary to open,'' said H. Josef Koenig, director of the Berlin office. Koenig says he gets offers every day from eastern Germans seeking appraisals of silver, paintings, or antiques they had hidden for years. The objects include old Meissen porcelain, pieces of Biedermeier furniture, silver, jewelry and paintings. Sometimes works of real value appear and can make their owners rich. Shortly before unity on Oct. 3, an East German from Dresden showed up at the Frankfurt branch of Sotheby's with a painting he had inherited. The retired worker had hidden the painting after the 1945 Red Army invasion and kept it secret from East German authorities, who had forbidden private ownership of art. Experts identified the painting as a portrait by the 20th-century German expressionist Emil Nolde. The work, out of sight for half a century, had been given up for lost by art connoisseurs. It was valued at $900,000. ``Nobody knows what is over there,'' said Koenig. To find out, Christie's hired Peter Betthausen, former director of the National Gallery in what was East Berlin and a specialist in German art of the 19th and 20th centuries, to head its office. Christie's is also staffing its Berlin office with experts to assess the value of objects offered, focusing on silver and jewelry. Sotheby's eastern expansion does not stop in Berlin. It already has an office in Budapest and another is planned for Prague in 1991. Berlin was an art center in 1933 when Nazi leader Adolf Hitler took power. But the Nazis banned many artists, and in 1939 publicly burned more than 1,000 works they deemed offensive. Socialist realism became the predominant style when the Communists came to power in eastern Berlin after World War II. Artists who did not conform could not exhibit. The unstable postwar political situation also affected West Berlin. The city found it hard to attract valuable works for museums while the city was divided. Sotheby's sponsored a public exhibition that drew large crowds in October to see modern paintings by such artists as Kandinsky, Matisse and Modigliani. Christie's flew in former NATO Secretary-General Lord Carrington, now chairman of Christie's International, for the official Dec. 10 opening of its Berlin offices. However, it may take a while for Berlin to become the site of the kind of spectacular auctions held regularly in London. Auctions are most likely to fetch higher prices in London, where the public is more international than in Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Some Americans Ordered Home Because of Gulf Situation
DOC.TEXT: Americans connected to U.S. embassies in six Middle East and two African countries are being ordered home or permitted to return voluntarily as a result of ``unstable conditions'' related to the Persian Gulf, the State Department said today. A U.S. official said these conditions have intensified following the decision of the U.N. Security Council to set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi troops to withdraw from Kuwait. All non-essential personnel and dependents of U.S. government personnel are being asked to leave Jordan and Sudan ``well before the Jan. 15 deadline,'' the announcement said. The State Department also recommended that U.S. citizens defer travel to the two countries. Later, a State Department official said the actions announced today affect only Jordan and Sudan. The decisions concerning the other six countries had been announced earlier, the official said. There has been strong pro-Iraqi sentiment in Jordan, and King Hussein has been an outspoken advocate of a negotiated settlement to the gulf conflict. The Sudanese government, meanwhile, generally has been supportive of the Iraqi position. The statement indicates concern over the possibility that pro-Iraqi sentiment in the eight countries could be directed at U.S. diplomatic offices. Large anti-American demonstrations have taken place in the Sudan and Jordan. Following is the list of actions concerning the safety of U.S. citizens which had been taken previously: -Dependents and non-essential personnel are being sent home from U.S. embassies in Sudan and Yemen. -The voluntary departure of U.S. government dependents and non-essential employees was authorized from Jordan and Mauritania. -Voluntary departure also was authorized for U.S. government dependents in Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and the Eastern province of Saudi Arabia - all gulf states.

DOC.HEAD: After Record-Cold, New Arctic Front Heading Toward the West
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with cold also affecting air quality in parts of Oregon; minor editing to trim. Picks up 12th graf pvs: `There have ...' ADDS 2 grafs with details of freezing pipes, ski area in Idaho. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A relentless cold wave that killed people and crops as it plunged temperatures to record lows all over the country eased in the West somewhat today, but the relief isn't likely to last. Another arctic front is on the way. A week of bone-numbing temperatures, often accompanied by hail, sleet, snow or freezing rain, led up to the coldest Christmas on record for more than 125 U.S. cities on Tuesday, including San Francisco; Albuquerque, N.M.; Boise, Idaho; Eugene, Ore.; and Winslow, Ariz. Yellowstone, Mont., was the nation's coldest spot at 30 below. Temperatures fell to subfreezing levels all over the Lower 48, including parts of Southern California and Florida. Snow blanketed most of the Pacific Northwest, Rocky mountains, the Great Plains and the Appalachians. A mass of warm air snapped the bitter cold in some areas of the Southwest today, but forecasters said not to get used to it. ``We're starting to see temperatures moderate a little bit,'' said Ross Dickman, a National Weather Service meteorologist in California. ``But there's also the possibility, with the new frontal system moving in, by the end of the weekend we could be back in below-freezing temperatures.'' Outside the Southwest, miserable conditions prevailed another day. A freezing rain advisory was in effect for the mountain passes of Washington state today; more subzero temperatures were forecast for Idaho, Montana and parts of Nevada; freeze warnings remained in effect for parts of Arizona; warnings of heavy snow were issued for Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania and gale warnings were in effect across most of the Great Lakes. In Arkansas, forecasters feared warm air catching up with stalled cold air might blend to bring freezing rain. The cold left many highways as slick as glass, stranding countless holiday travelers nationwide. ``The entire core area is just like a skating rink,'' state police Sgt. Aaron Olson said of the highways in Portland, Ore. The cold weather also took a toll on air quality in Oregon. Air in the Eugene-Springfield area was rated unhealthful Tuesday. Wood smoke was a major source of the problem. There have been more than 80 weather-related deaths, including three Texas boys who plunged through the ice of frozen lakes and ponds on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. In Texas and Arizona, citrus growers say their crops dodged the cold-weather bullet so far, but heavy navel orange losses were reported in California, where flowers for next week's Rose Parade floats also withered. In central California's Tulare County, where most of the state's navel orange crop is grown, Agricultural Commissioner Lenord Craft estimated a $200 million loss to this year's harvest. Thousands of people in Northern California's San Lorenzo Valley area were without water service when many pipes froze and burst. Others in the drought-stricken area had to run their water constantly to keep the pipes from freezing. ``After all of our conservation because of the drought, it breaks your heart to see it pouring out of the pipes,'' said local resident Carol Rice. Many people throughout southern Idaho also continued to wait for plumbers to repair frozen water pipes and for mechanics to fix cars halted by the gelid conditions. The state's ski resorts reported excellent conditions, except for Idaho's most famous resort. Sun Valley's slopes haven't shared in the wealth of snow dumped on the state in the past week and reports only an 18-inch base.

DOC.HEAD: Sandwich Shop Near Prison Serves as Museum of Prison Contraband
DOC.TEXT: They're not exactly art treasures, but there is a certain creativity in the items on display at Carla's Sandwich Shop just outside the gates of Florida State Prison. The collection, confiscated from inmates by many of the shop's customers, ranges from a felt-tip pen concealing a razor blade to a Vienna sausage can with a hidden compartment for drugs. Carla Hawthorne, owner of the shop and a former correctional officer, hopes to eventually open a law enforcement museum that will show people the kinds of things officers deal with. ``Inmates run a con game on people - mothers, wives, grandparents. Then they come down here and really see what's going on,'' she said. ``They are naughty boys inside.'' She said visitors to the eatery, which is near three Jacksonville area prisons, are sometimes surprised by the contraband that inmates imaginatively fashion from everyday items. Among the items on display are a key to a door lock made from a disposable razor blade and a variety of knives fashioned from pieces of wood, metal and plastic glass. There also are several ``zip guns,'' in which small metal tubes are fashioned into crude weapons in which sulfur shavings from match sticks are used to fire nails or other projectiles. But not all inmate creations are deadly. Mrs. Hawthorne also has on display toaster ovens made from cigarette package foil and light bulbs. And in front of her counter is a still created from a metal box, plastic buckets and pieces of copper tubing welded together. Mrs. Hawthorne said inmates used it to ferment an alcoholic potion they call ``buck.''

DOC.HEAD: Pressure and Criticism Led to Heart Attack, Deputies Say
WIth AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
Laserphotos MOSB1-3,9
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, the target of relentless criticism over the economy, suffered a heart attack after a government reshuffle left his job in doubt. He was said Wednesday to be out of danger. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, visibly saddened, delivered the news to the Congress of People's Deputies in a slow, soft voice. ``A very difficult event last night. Nikolai Ivanovich (Ryzhkov) had a heart attack, a coronary. ... There is no threat to his life. But that's the situation. We wish him a return to health. We're very sorry.'' A spokesman for the Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, headed by Ryzhkov said by telephone that the prime minister was out of danger and resting in a hospital on Wednesday. Ryzhkov, 61, was under ``constant surveillance'' but no other information was available, said Yuri I. Tyunkov. The deputies reacted with silence to the news, then returned to their day's agenda on granting Gorbachev more presidential powers. The 2,250-member parliament had voted Tuesday to eliminate Ryzhkov's Council of Ministers and create a new Cabinet under Gorbachev's control. It was unclear whether Ryzhkov would retain the post of prime minister in the revamped body. Ryzhkov has been accused of delaying radical reforms that some consider necessary for halting the country's economic crisis. Last fall, Rhzykov's conservative economic reform plan was pitted against a more radical plan pushed by Russian republic leader Boris Yeltsin. That put Gorbachev in the middle of the fractious political battle that continues to paralyze the government. ``In his face you could see the imprint of the constant worry about what was going on in the country and all the things people were saying about him,'' said Nadezhda A. Kryuchenkova, a deputy from Tambov. She said she was among Ryzhkov's critics. The heart attack ``testifies to the fact that he really took to heart everything that the country was going through,'' said Air Force Marshall Alexander N. Yefimov. ``I'm very sorry that he will not be taking active part in government work for awhile.'' Yefimov said he believed Ryzhkov would have been the top candidate for prime minister in the reorganized government, but that now deputies did not expect Ryzhkov to return to work any time soon. His ouster long had been demanded by reformers, but Gorbachev stood by his friend. Ryzhkov was appointed by Gorbachev in 1985, shortly after Gorbachev's own ascent as Communist Party chief.
