Nadim Salem, a Catholic who was appointed minister of public works, also said he would not join the government unless Phalangists and the Lebanese Forces end their boycott. Geagea and Saadeh have said the dominant representation of pro-Syrian factions in the new Cabinet implies it has been dictated by Syria. Both called it a ``fait accompli government.'' Syria is Lebanon's main power broker. It has 40,000 troops stationed in northern, eastern and central Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the Arab League. But the Arab League last year sponsored a special session of the Lebanese Parliament in the Saudi town of Taif that approved a peace plan based on Moslem-Christian equal power-sharing. The plan also calls for the disbanding of Lebanon's militias by March 21 and for the Syrian army to gradually withdraw from Beirut and major towns over the next two years and redeploy in east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. Geagea and Saadeh contend they represent the major Christian fighting forces and that no national reconciliation is possible without their participation as the main Christian negotiators. President Elias Hrawi, a Maronite, and Karami, a Sunni Moslem, have tried both directly and through intermediaries to persuade Geagea and Saadeh to join the new government. Karami has to present his Cabinet to Parliament next week to seek a vote of confidence. Seven Christian and Moslem warlords have been appointed state ministers without portfolios in the new Cabinet to gain their approval of a plan to disarm and disband their militias. Geagea's 6,000-member Lebanese Forces control more than 70 percent of Lebanon's Christian heartland north and northeast of Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Believes Saddam May Attack Israel if War Seems Inevitable
DOC.TEXT: The United States believes Saddam Hussein may attack Israel and try to break the international coalition of forces arrayed against him if he fears war is inevitable, a U.S. military intelligence expert said Wednesday. The Iraqi president is showing no sign of withdrawing from Kuwait and it looks increasingly likely that hundreds of thousands of Iraq's troops will have to be forced from the emirate, said Air Force Lt. Col. Tom Coury, a member of the U.S. Central Command intelligence staff. He warned that Iraq, which has the most extensive chemical arsenal in the Third World, would likely use such weapons ``against attacking coalition forces.'' Coury was one of three speakers at the first regular weekly news briefing by the U.S. Central Command, held in a hotel ballroom in the Saudi Arabian capital and broadcast live by CNN-TV. The military deliberately chose 6 p.m. for the briefing to avoid any comparison with the daily 5 p.m. briefing during the Vietnam War, dubbed ``5 O'clock Follies'' by reporters. If hostilities break out in the Persian Gulf there will also be daily briefings. With the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait only three weeks away, Coury said, ``We see absolutely no indication that Saddam Hussein intends to withdraw from Kuwait.'' He said a key indicator that Saddam intends to stay in Kuwait for ``the long haul'' is the ``tremendous resources'' he is spending to fortify the small oil-rich nation at a time when Iraq is being subjected to U.N. economic sanctions. Lt. Col. Greg Pepin, an Army artillery officer selected as the regular military briefer, said Iraq is estimated to be losing $100 million in revenue a day, or $3 billion monthly. Coury said ``for the immediate future we think he (Saddam) will attempt to avoid conflict while working to erode both U.S. public support and allied cooperation. ``As a last resort, if he fears war is inevitable, he could initiate open conflict which may include a provocation with Israel and an attemt to decouple the coalition forces,'' he said. Asked whether he believed it was realistic for Iraq to attack Israel, Coury said: ``I think it is very realistic.'' Israel has kept an uncharacteristically low profile since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait to keep from upsetting the fragile coalition of Western and Islamic forces confronting Saddam. Coury said Saddam ``continues to pour both men and materials into the country and along his flank to the west.'' The Iraqi leader is constructing massive defenses in Kuwait including trenches, minefields, barriers and hundreds of miles of barbed-wire fences, he said. Iraq now has over a half-million troops, thousands of tanks, 2,500 armored personnel carriers and 2,700 artillery pieces in Kuwait and southern Iraq, Coury said. He said Iraqi troops in Kuwait ``are being adequately supplied'' though he would not elaborate. On the fighting quality of the Iraqis, he said, ``The ground fortifications are formidable but they more of World War I vintage, and we'll be looking at a technologically superior force going after that sort of defenses.'' The Republican Guards, who were in the vanguard of the invasing troops, are the ``most capable forces,'' he said. ``Exactly how the remainder of the army would react under combat, under invasion of their own country, it's difficult to say,'' he said. Iraq has thinned out its ground forces along the Iranian border to reinforce defenses in Kuwait, Coury said. Along the Turkish border, Iraq has mainly infantry with some heavy units. ``Overall, (Iraq) flight activity has generally increased with a definite increase in fighter training and operation,'' he said. But although Iraq has the largest air force in the Middle East, with over 700 combat aircraft, Coury said ``they are no match for the combined strength of coalition airpower.'' Maj. Gen. Dane Starling, Central Command's director of logistics, said Saddam still has time to withdraw everything from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline.

DOC.HEAD: Historian of Italian Unification Dies
DOC.TEXT: Carlo Francovich, a leader of anti-Fascist partisans in Florence during World War II and a prominent historian of Italian unification, died Wednesday. He was 80. Francovich was considered a top expert on Italy's unification in the 1860s, and taught the subject at universities in Siena and Florence. He wrote a two-volume history of the anti-Fascist resistance in Florence, where he took part in the 1944 uprising. The president of the Italian Senate, Giovanni Spadolini, said in a message of condolence to Francovich's family that the historian had ``studied in depth the themes of the formation of democratic, secular Italy'' and had been ``an authoritative and original voice.''

DOC.HEAD: Authorities: Explosives Knocked Out Power
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities on Wednesday were seeking a motive for two high-powered explosions that knocked out power at an electrical substation and at a hotel-casino just outside this gaming resort city. They also were trying to determine whether the two Saturday night blasts, caused by dynamite or some kind of high explosive, were related to the detonation of a smoke bomb at the same hotel-casino a short time later. ``There were two separate explosions and we believe they could have been related,'' said Sig Celaya, resident agent-in-charge of the Las Vegas office of the federal bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. No injuries were reported in the explosions, which caused an estimated $650,000 damage and left 3,000 Nevada Power Co. customers without electricity for several hours. Authorities said they had no suspects and no arrests had been made. The first blast destroyed a Nevada Power Co. substation at Jean, about 30 miles southwest of Las Vegas. Damage was estimated at $400,000. A second blast a short time later destroyed an emergency generator at the nearby Nevada Landing Hotel and Casino and blew out windows on one side of the complex, causing an estimated $250,000 in damages. Guests were transferred to other hotels. The explosions were similar in size and detonation, Celaya said Wednesday. A man in the casino set off a smoke grenade after the second explosion, said Celaya. ``We don't want to speculate on the situation,'' he said. ``We don't know if the smoke grenade was related to the two bombings,'' Celaya said. ``It could have been anything from using the grenade to provide light, to a robbery situation.'' No robbery demands were made and no robbery took place, he said. Las Vegas Metro Police and Clark County Fire Department investigators joined the ATF in searching for clues. Evidence from the blast sites was sent to the ATF's laboratory in San Francisco, Celaya said. Nevada Landing reopened this week. A company spokeswoman declined to comment on the explosion and smoke bomb, except to say that the hotel-casino had received no threats.

DOC.HEAD: Barn Fire Kills 250 Pigs
DOC.TEXT: More than 250 pigs were killed by a fire that swept through a barn when sparks from farm machinery ignited hay, authorities said. About 300 pigs escaped the blaze, which destroyed the barn on the Westmoreland County farm of Adam and Mary Lou Skokut. The fire broke out Monday afternoon and spread quickly. ``It just exploded,'' Skokut said. ``It went fast.'' Skokut said his son-in-law Gary Cunningham was working alone in the barn when the fire started and had to run a considerable distance to call for help. The barn was destroyed. Cunningham was operating a skid loader, a fork-lift used to clean hog pens, when sparks from the machine ignited hay in the barn. The flames spread so quickly that Cunningham did not have time to pull the vehicle out of the barm, Skokut said. Neighbors helped round up the surviving pigs, which are being kept temporarily in a silo.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Prosecutor Blocked from Moving Lawsuit to Washington
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit accusing special prosecutor Lawrence Walsh of trying to stifle an insider book about the Iran-Contra investigation will stay in New York, a federal judge ruled Wednesday. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan of Manhattan turned down a request by Walsh to have grand jury secrecy issues decided by the judge in Washington who supervised the Iran-Contra grand jury. Keenan said such a move would constitute ``a waste of judicial resources'' and would put an undue burden on the book's author, Jeffrey Toobin, who decided to sue in New York. Keenan said he was ``fully capable'' of deciding whether Toobin's manuscript violated laws governing the secrecy of grand jury proceedings. Toobin, who worked for Walsh's Office of Independent Counsel from 1987 to 1989, accuses Walsh of trying to stop publication of his book about how the government built its case against Oliver North. The suit said Walsh claims the final version of ``Opening Arguments: A Young Lawyer's First Case - United States v. Oliver North'' improperly discloses staff discussions and internal memos of the office and that it violates grand jury secrecy. The book is ready for distribution to reviewers and is scheduled for publication by Viking early next year, said Viking's parent corporation, Penguin Books USA, which brought the suit with Toobin.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Iraq Test Fired Another Surface-to-Surface Missile
DOC.TEXT: Iraq test-fired a surface-to-surface missile Wednesday, but the projectile was aimed away from the multinational forces massed in Saudi Arabia, the U.S. Central Command said. The command said in a statement it had ``received indications ... that Iraqi armed forces conducted activity that included the firing of another surface-to-surface missile within Iraq.'' Previous such firings put some of the 300,000 American forces deployed in Operation Desert Shield on a heightened state of alert, but the U.S. Command would not comment on the current alert status. ``The missile landed in Iraq. The flight path of the missile was away from U.S. and coalition forces. The firing appeared to be part of an additional training or testing mission,'' the statement said. No further details were available on the type or exact direction of the missile fired, or on the methods used to detect it. U.S. troops were already on heightened alert because of the possibility of a terrorist attack over the Christmas and New Year holidays. Last Friday, some U.S. forces went on a low-level alert for a possible chemical attack after a missile firing. It turned out to be an Israeli missile test fired into the Mediterranean. British and U.S. military officials reported that Iraq test fired Scud missiles from east to west on Dec. 2, prompting some units to don gas masks against a possible chemical attack. If the missiles were fired north to south they would hit Saudi Arabia. The Los Angeles Times reported last week that Iraqi test firing of three medium-range missiles apparently took U.S. military officials by surprise. The first launch of the series was completed before American satellites and sensors noticed it, the Times reported, and Israeli and U.S. officials readied their air forces. The Iraqis are estimated to have 500 to 1,000 surface-to-surface missiles of various types, either Soviet-built SS-1 Scud-Bs or Iraqi variants. Baghdad bought 1,500 to 2,000 Scud-Bs during the 1980-88 war with Iran and launched scores during that conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Loyal Party Servant Is Surprise Pick For Soviet Vice President
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB13
DOC.TEXT: Gennady I. Yanayev, a 53-year-old lawyer nominated Wednesday as a surprise choice to become the Soviet Union's first vice president, has risen steadily in the Communist bureaucracy by showing strong party loyalty. Neither reformers nor conservatives in the Congress of People's Deputies, the nation's parliament, reacted enthusiastically to his nomination by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Many said they would support him anyway. Most of the speculation had centered on other, more prominent people who have worked closely with Gorbachev. After Gorbachev told the Congress he wanted Yanayev, the cavernous Palace of Congress was silent for a moment, followed by a smattering of applause. Yanayev took the floor and told deputies he supports Gorbachev's reform program and would work to help stabilize the economy if confirmed. The Congress is to vote on the nomination Thursday. The vice presidency, a new job in the Soviet Union, has not been fully defined by Soviet officials. It could be powerful. A constitutional amendment says the vice president ``replaces the president of the U.S.S.R. in case of his absence and inability to carry out his duties.'' Yanayev told the Congress the nation needs ``consolidation of all socio-political forces around the platform of the president's anti-crisis program and the decisions of the Congress.'' ``In this 300-million person country, we don't have any right to carry out unpredictable, convulsive politics. If we adopt some kind of shock transition to the market, that would mean that in the first year we would have tens of millions of unemployed people,'' Yanayev said. His remarks and those of other people in the chamber were reported by Tass, the state new agency. Yanayev urged respect for law and law enforcement institutions, such as the army and KGB. In the past, he has expressed concern about Soviet involvement in the Persian Gulf. ``Any solution by force might provoke unpredictable consequences. We do not want those consequences to occur,'' Yanayev said in August when the Kremlin was looking for a diplomatic settlement in the gulf. After Yanayev's nomination, Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev, one of those mentioned earlier as a possible vice president, said curtly: ``Yes, I will support him. No, I will not comment on his merits.'' The Russian republic's information minister, Mikhail Poltoranin, told reporters a worse candidate would have been hard to find, but that ``Gennady Yanayev stands a chance to be elected by the current Congress.'' Yanayev, an ethnic Russian, was graduated from the Gorky Agricultural Institute in 1959. He obtained a law degree in 1967 from the All-Union Juridical Correspondence Institute. He later worked as a mechanical engineer in Gorky before becoming a volunteer in the Communist Party's youth organization, the Komsomol. In the early 1970s, he came to Moscow to become chairman of the U.S.S.R. Committee of Youth Organizations, a group that deals with foreign youth movements in conjunction with the party. In the 1980s, he served for six years as deputy chairman of the Soviet Friendship Society, a group that maintains non-governmental contacts with foreigners. He later returned to the Komsomol and ascended to the policy-making Central Committee, eventually becoming a secretary. He was elected to the party's ruling Politburo in July after a party shake-up that also significantly decreased the authority of the Politburo. This year, he also became an official of the government-run trade union organization, which has tried to distance itself from its pro-government positions to compete with an assertive independent workers' movement. Yanayev is a member of the parliament, where he is a leader of the 730-member Communist bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Apologizes for Bethesda Chain Saw Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Gov. William Donald Schaefer personally apologized Wednesday for a state work crew which mistakenly cut down seven trees bordering Arun Vohra's yard. ``We made a mistake and we're going to do everything we can to rectify it,'' said Schaefer in a visit to Vohra's home in this Washington suburb. The governor, accompanied by several aides including state Transportation Secretary James Lighthizer, made the 40-mile trip from Annapolis to see Vohra and the stumps that remained along the highway outside his house after the saga known familiarly as the Bethesda Chain Saw Massacre. One of the felled trees was a massive cedar 80 feet to 100 feet high. ``That was a great tree,'' admitted the governor. Schaefer called the tree-cutting incident a result of missed communications. ``We made a mistake ... (and) we learned,'' said the governor. The story of the seven destroyed trees - all on a state right-of-way - began last spring when Vohra notified the state highway administration about a diseased pine tree on state property in front of his house. A few days later he came home and found that tree still standing, but six other ``awesome'' trees - two pines, three blooming dogwoods and a giant lilac - had been cut. He complained, and soon another state official came to his house and was shown the suspect tree. Vohra said he marked the tree with a ribbon. But then, next time around, he returned from work and found the massive cedar a few feet from the pine tree had been cut. The pine tree, still, was untouched. ``I acted a little crazy,'' recalled Vohra. He called the governor's mansion in Annapolis, his state delegate, his congresswoman and the state department of natural resources. And the story began to get some press. Vohra was informed this week that the governor wanted to visit, so he made coffee and ordered some extra food for his guests. As the entourage arrived, Vohra expressed surprise at all the attention given his loss. ``I had no idea this would ever happen,'' he said. Schaefer said ``We want to do the right thing,'' and promised the state would replace whatever trees Vohra chooses. ``I'm tree conscious,'' said the governor, reminding reporters he has vowed to plant 1 million trees in Maryland. The two men posed atop the stump that once had been the massive cedar. Nearby was the pine that started all the trouble. State officials have since said it's not diseased at all, but only the target of woodpeckers.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Plans New Apartments in Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with United States saying Israel has given assurances; pickup graf 3 `About 100,000...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th pvs `Once the...' with details. Picks up graf 14th pvs, `Soviet immigration...'
DOC.TEXT: Left-wing legislators accused the Israeli government Wednesday of risking U.S. aid for absorption of Soviet immigrants by erecting hundreds of trailer homes and apartments in the occupied territories. But in Washington, the State Department said Israel has assured U.S. officials that no immigrants will be directed to settle in new housing projects planned for the occupied lands. About 100,000 Israelis live among 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East War. The United States objects to these settlements and considers them an obstacle to peace efforts. Haim Oron of the socialist Mapam party said Housing Minister Ariel Sharon told Parliament's Finance Committee on Monday that 1,000 trailers and another 1,200 apartments would be go up in the West Bank and Gaza in the coming year. Another 300 trailer homes have been moved into the disputed territories in the past year, Oron quoted Sharon as saying. Oron said Sharon insisted the government was not steering Soviet immigrants to the occupied territories, in keeping with American conditions for $400 million in loan guarantees voted by Congress this year. But Oron argued that a housing shortage in Israel could easily propel immigrants to the occupied territories. ``People go where there are apartments, whether they are immigrants or old- timers,'' Oron said. ``Sharon never said it was being built for immigrants, but I think he's putting the issue at risk, since the Americans are unequivocally against their money reaching the territories,'' Oron added. A communique from Sharon's office said a total of 33,000 trailers were to be purchased over the next year but did not say where they would be parked. Sharon's spokesman, Nimrod Granit, was not available at his office to comment. Sharon, a former defense minister, has led the Jewish settlement effort in the occupied lands since 1977, when he first joined an Israeli Cabinet as agriculture minister. Labor Party leader Shimon Peres has also accused the government of indirectly pushing immigrants to move to the occupied territories by moving trailers there. ``Once the trailers are built there, they will say: `We have no choice, the immigrants have no place to live,' and they will be forced to move there,'' Peres was quoted as telling a party forum on Dec. 13. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher on Wednesday said Israeli authorities have provided assurances that they ``are not going to direct immigrants from the Soviet Union beyond the green line'' - Israel's internationally recognized border until 1967. He also reaffirmed U.S. opposition to Israel's policy of establishing settlements in the territories, calling the activity an ``obstacle to peace.'' Soviet immigration has totaled more than 170,000 this year, and construction of housing in Israel has fallen far short of demand. Israeli reports say construction is under way on less than half of 45,000 apartments planned for this year. They said Sharon promised the committee that all would be in the building process by the end of the fiscal year in April. Meantime, immigrant families are doubling up in apartments in some Israeli towns. Many arriving in the past month have been put up temporarily in hotels and army bases.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Advised Not To Travel
DOC.TEXT: Americans were advised Wednesday by the State Department not to travel to Suriname and those in the South American country were told to stay indoors. Army leaders have seized control of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Capsized Ferry Pulled Out of Haifa Bay
LaserPhoto TLV104
DOC.TEXT: A floating crane on Wednesday pulled from Haifa Bay the chartered ferry that capsized last weekend, drowning 21 sailors from the USS Saratoga aircraft carrier. As the red and white ferry was pulled ashore, sailors watched from the Saratoga's deck with binoculars and cameras. Water poured from the broken ferry windows and orange life jackets tumbled into choppy waves. A U.S. helicopter hovered overhead. Israeli and American authorities are investigating the sinking. On initial inspection Wednesday, the ship seemed to be in good condition with no obvious problems, Israel army radio said. Israel television said investigation teams would inspect the ferry's hull Thursday for any defect that could have led to the disaster. The 57-foot Israeli ferry, hired to transport the U.S. sailors, was about 200 yards from the Saratoga early Saturday when it was swamped by two swells, survivors said. Israeli officials believe the ship may have been destabilized when too many men gathered in its aft. The Saratoga and its escort ships had come from the Red Sea, where they were participating in the anti-Iraqi force. The servicemen were on shore leave in Haifa, about 75 miles northwest of Jerusalem. The accident was the deadliest involving U.S. servicemen during the Persian Gulf buildup.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Stays at Top of Chess World
LaserPhotos PAR5,6
With AM-Chess Championship
DOC.TEXT: What do Greg LeMond, Joe Montana and Garry Kasparov have in common? All three are world champions in their sports the last five years - not once or twice, but three times. Kasparov, the reigning world chess champion, finished off Anatoly Karpov for the third straight time in the championship finals with a draw on Wednesday and proved once again that he is at the top of his sport, like cycling champion Lemond and San Francisco 49ers quarterback Montana. LeMond has won the world's most prestigious race, the Tour de France, the last three times he has competed in it. Montana is considered the finest quarterback in pro football, and has four Super Bowl rings to disprove naysayers. Now Kasparov, world chess champion since 1985, has reaffirmed himself as the world's premier chess strategist. Kasparov was aprodigy, starting to play chess at 4. He was born April 13, 1963, in Baku, Azerbaijan, and was originally named Gary Kimovich Weinstein. At six, after the death of his father, he was taken in by his mother's family and adopted her name, Klara Kasparova. Kasparov soon showed his chess potential, winning the Soviet junior championship at 13 and the world junior title at 17. He challenged Karpov for the world title in 1984, which resulted in a notable confrontation. Karpov went ahead, 5-0, in a match when draws didn't count. Kasparov came back to narrow the score to 5-3. Suddenly, after five months and 48 games, the International Chess Federation decided to call off the contest, saying it was for the good of the players. Kasparov took the championship outright in 1985 by a score of 13-11 to become the youngest champion in the history of chess at 22. He retained the crown in 1986 in a series split between London and Leningrad, 12.5-11.5. In their last meeting in Seville in 1987, Karpov led, 12-11, going into the final game. Kasparov, unshaven and needing a victory to even the series and retain his title, played aggressively, rallied to win the game and save his title. It was an electric atmposphere the final day and a 10-minute standing ovation to the cheers of ``Torero, Torero!!'' that traditionally hail bullfighters accompanied the triumph. Kasparov went for the kill this time, scoring a convincing win over Karpov. After playing to 10 draws of 12 games in New York, Kasparov won three of the last seven games with three draws to beat Karpov. The two men, who are known to dislike each other, differ in temperment, looks, politics and even playing style. Kasparov is talkative and flamboyant, playing chess with creativity and decisiveness. Karpov, 39, is often protrayed as a colorless introvert who plays with surgical precision. ``I have two loves,'' Karpov has said. ``Communism and chess.'' ``Normally chess is a battle between two individuals,'' Kasparov once said in an interview. ``But in my case, with Karpov, it's a fight between two different mentalities in Russia. I identify him with the system I've been fighting.'' ``Karpov represents the power authorities,'' Kasparov said in a previous interview. ``He was (Soviet leader Leonid) Brezhnev's boy when Brezhnev was in power and is (President Mikhail) Gorbachev's boy when Gorbachev is in power.'' The pair's personality clash has endured more 150 encounters in official competition over 700 hours. But in Lyon, after a draw or a decision, they often discussed their play, almost amicably. ``I know him. He knows me,'' Kasparov said in an interview. ``You have to realize he is the only serious opponent for me. I am talking chess with the No. two in the world.'' Kasparov is the highest-rated player in the history of the sport, with 2,800 points in rating chess grandmasters. The previous best was 2,785 by American chess genius Bobby Fischer, who held the world title from 1972 until he refused to defend it in 1975. That allowed Karpov to take it until Kasparaov came along. Married last year, Kasparov dabbles in other fields. He likes jogging, tennis and has attended a number of games of the soccer club Moscow Spartak. He founded one of the first computer clubs in the Soviet Union and was an advocate for getting paid his prize money in tournaments. That led to Soviet tennis players Natalia Zvereva and Andrei Chesnokov also demanding their winnings rather than splitting them with the state.

DOC.HEAD: Tom Cruise Marries `Days of Thunder' Co-Star Nicole Kidman
DOC.TEXT: Actor Tom Cruise married his ``Days of Thunder'' co-star, Nicole Kidman, during a private Christmas Eve ceremony at a Colorado ski resort, his publicist said Wednesday. The 30-minute civil ceremony was witnessed by a handful of family members, said Cruise publicist Andrea Jaffe. Details about the wedding weren't disclosed. It was the first marriage for the Australian actress and the second for Cruise, whose nearly three-year marriage to actress Mimi Rogers ended January in divorce. The couple surfaced in Telluride, Colo., on Christmas Eve with other family members. Their honeymoon plans weren't disclosed. Cruise, 28, met Miss Kidman, 23, while filming ``Days of Thunder.'' Among Cruise's other movies are ``Risky Business,'' ``Top Gun,'' ``The Color of Money,'' ``Rain Man'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Miss Kidman is currently filming ``Billy Bathgate,'' co-starring Dustin Hoffman. Cruise and his bride are in pre-production for their next film together, ``The Irish Story,'' directed by Ron Howard.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Predicts Victory; Washington Withdraws Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with U.S. expert saying peace prospects poor, Iraq test-firing missile, CORRECTS Dennis Ross' State Department title penultimate graf, edits to conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHR1,2
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein said the American army would lose a war with Iraq because it doesn't have ``right on its side.'' Washington took steps Wednesday to pull American civilians from the increasingly tense Persian Gulf region. In the Arabian Sea, meanwhile, U.S. and other sailors enforcing the U.N. trade embargo aimed at forcing Iraq from Kuwait fired warning shots in a fracas with crew members and female activists aboard an Iraqi ship. But there were also reports of renewed diplomacy in the 4-month-old gulf crisis. An Israeli newspaper said Wednesday that Washington and Baghdad had broken a deadlock and set a date for talks. The independent daily Maariv, quoting Israeli diplomats in contact with American officials, said Secretary of State James A. Baker III will likely meet with President Saddam in Baghdad on Jan. 9. The State Department denied any date was set. Jan. 15 is the U.N. deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face possible attack. Saddam has recalled his ambassadors from western Europe, the United States and other nations, but there is speculation Iraq is planning a new diplomatic initiative. In an interview broadcast Wednesday by Mexican television, though, Saddam spoke only of war. ``It is certain that the American army will be defeated,'' Saddam told Mexico's Televisa network. ``But you know why? Because it does not have right on its side ... because the American army has left its land ... has come to kill a people who live in security and in stability.'' In Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, a U.S. intelligence officer gave a bleak assessment Wednesday of peace prospects. Air Force Lt. Col. Tom Coury of the U.S. Central Command intelligence staff said U.S. officials think Saddam may attack Israel to break up the international force opposing him if he believes war is inevitable. ``We see absolutely no indication that Saddam Hussein intends to withdraw from Kuwait,'' Coury said. He also said it is likely Iraq will use chemical weapons if it is attacked. In another development, the U.S. Central Command said Iraq test-fired a surface-to-surface missile Wednesday. The projectile was aimed away from the multinational forces massed in Saudi Arabia, officials said. No other details were available. In his broadcast comments, Saddam reiterated he would not allow the United States to set a date for his meeting with Baker. Washington has suggested a meeting on or before Jan. 3, but Saddam has insisted talks be held Jan. 12. ``The Iraqi people reject that its president receives orders from outside,'' Saddam said. Washington also appeared to have little optimism about the crisis. The State Department asked all non-essential personnel and dependents of U.S. government workers to leave Jordan and Sudan before the Jan. 15 deadline. The State Department recommended that U.S. citizens defer travel to the two nations, both of whose populations generally support Iraq. It said earlier that pro-Iraqi sentiment could be directed at Americans in Yemen, Mauritania, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and eastern Saudi Arabia. It had recommended non-essential U.S. personnel leave those countries as well. Meanwhile, U.S. sailors enforcing the U.N. trade embargo boarded an Iraqi ship near Masirah Island. They were involved in a 30-minute melee with the crew and female peace activists from 10 Arab countries, Italy, China, the United States and Japan. A U.S. Navy spokesman, Cmdr. Mark Neuhart, said the trouble started when U.S. sailors approached the pilot house of the freighter ``and a number of the crew attempted to hold the boarding party members back and grab their weapons.'' The sailors fired warning shots, a smoke grenade and a noisemaker grenade ``for crowd control,'' he said. There were no injuries, he said. The 11,333-ton Ibn Khaldoon carried 800 tons of sugar in violation of the U.N. sanctions. Pro-Iraqi Arab news reports have dubbed the vessel ``the peace ship'' and said it was sailing to the Iraqi port of Basra in a demonstration of support for Saddam and his initiatives for solving the gulf crisis. The Israeli newspaper said the Jan. 9 date for talks aimed at resolving the gulf crisis was set amid secret negotiations between the United States and Iraq. But a State Department spokeswoman denied any date had been set. Diplomats in the region say Saddam might be willing to make concessions if he can win linkage between resolution of the gulf crisis and efforts toward establishing Palestinian self-rule in the Israeli-occupied territories. The United States and its allies have rejected linking an Iraqi pullout from occupied Kuwait to the Palestinian issue. But Maariv said a Jan. 9 Baker-Saddam meeting could be tied to plans by Dennis Ross, director of the State Department's policy planning staff, to visit Israel on Jan. 7 to discuss new Middle East peace proposals. The State Department appears to be putting together a proposal for opening peace talks between Israel and Arab countries in tandem with holding municipal elections in the occupied territories, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Moroccan Courts Sentence 47 for Rioting
DOC.TEXT: Moroccan courts sentenced 47 people to prison terms of up to seven years for rioting during a general strike this month, officials said Wednesday. The sentences were the most severe so far in dozens of trials following Dec. 14-15 unrest in Morocco which killed at least five people. Forty people in Fez drew sentences late Tuesday and Wednesday ranging from one to seven years in jail on charges of rebellion, destruction of property, carrying arms and attacking the liberty to work, Twelve were acquitted. Seven people, aged 18 to 29, were sentenced in Meknes, north-central Morocco, to terms of six months to one year in prison on similar charges. Courts in Tangier and Sidi-Kacem last Friday sentenced 37 people in all to prison terms ranging up to one year. Fez suffered the worst violence. Rioters there attacked hotels, post offices and a police station. The government says five people were killed there and 127 injured. It said security forces withheld fire. The two unions that called the strike claim about 30 people were killed. Thirty-three other defendants are awaiting trial in Fez. Also on trial is Mohamed Titna Alaoui, leader of the Fez branch of the General Moroccan Workers' Union, which along with the Democratic Work Confederation called the strike. The government claimed unidentified foreign powers helped foment the unrest. It is negotiating with unions and employers on ``priority measures'' promised after the riots, the official MAP news agency reported, including increases in minimum wages and in social allocations.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Examiner Says Body Not That of Helen Brach
DOC.TEXT: The Cook County medical examiner is convinced a recently exhumed body is not that of missing candy heiress Helen Brach, but federal investigators said Wednesday they haven't ruled out the possibility. Medical examiner Robert Stein said he and a team of scientists, including a forensic dentist, an anthropologist and a radiologist, studied the body. ``It's definitely not Helen Brach,'' Stein said Monday. ``As far as we're concerned the case is closed.'' Federal authorities plan more examinations on the body, including a DNA test, said Jerry Singer, spokesman for the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Stein called it ``silly'' for federal investigators to continue believing the body may be Mrs. Brach's. He refused to elaborate on how the team of scientists ruled out the possibility. The still-unidentified body was exhumed Dec. 11 from a pauper's grave. The hands and part of the face were missing, the Chicago Tribune has reported. Mrs. Brach, heiress to the Brach Candy Co. fortune, was 65 and had an estimated net worth of $17 million when she disappeared in 1977 after checking out of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. She was declared legally dead in 1984. Most of her estate, now valued at more than $50 million, went to the Helen Brach Foundation, a charitable trust. Her husband, Frank V. Brach, who was president of E.J. Brach and Sons Candy Co., died in 1970. The discovery of the body in a suburban forest in 1978 raised speculation it was that of Mrs. Brach. Stein ruled then the body was not that of the missing heiress and it was buried. The results of a yearlong racketeering fraud investigation prompted federal authorities to exhume the body, Singer said. He and other state and federal authorities have refused to divulge further details. ``We refrain from commenting on the particulars of an open investigation,'' Singer said. ``All we can say is that the process is still continuing and there's no timetable as to when the examinations will be completed.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Consults on Palestinian Situation
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar may seek help from member nations' consulates in Israel to monitor the safety of Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories, U.N. officials said Wednesday. They said he was consulting through the Interntional Committee of the Red Cross about using the consular staff in Israel of the 164 nations that signed the 1949 Fourth Geneva Convention on protecting civilians in occupied lands. The Security Council told the secretary-general last Thursday to discern the views of the signatory nations about a possible meeting to discuss implementing the Geneva convention and helping Palestinians. Signatories include the United States, Britain, France, Canada and others. Perez de Cuellar also is considering expanding the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, which cares for Palestinian refugees, to observe and report on the Palestinians' situation in the Gaza Strip and West Bank. Israel seized the territories in the 1967 Mideast War. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said any change in the agency's mandate was unlikely in view of Israeli and U.S. opposition to expanding UNRWA's role. They said no decisions have been made. The U.N. chief is on vacation until Jan. 4. The Security Council resolution, adopted unanimously, asks the secretary-general ``to monitor and observe the situation in the occupied Palestinian territories, on an urgent basis, using the United Nations personnel stationed there and appointing the necessary staff to accomplish this task.'' Arab nations called it an important first step in council involvement to protect Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories. They say the council must act evenhandedly in opposing both Iraq's occupation of Kuwait and Israel's occupation of the territories by subjecting Israel to economic and other sanctions, like Iraq. Perez de Cuellar says he will send his personal emissary, Jean-Claude Aime, to study the situation, but has yet to announce a trip. He also accepted an Israeli invitation to visit, but no date was announced. UNRWA, created in 1949, has 2,300 staff in the region. The agency helps more than 2.1 million refugees, including hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in Israel and elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian President Overturns Bank Nationalization Law
DOC.TEXT: President Alberto Fujimori has repealed the controversial bank nationalization law passed three years ago by his predecessor, Alan Garcia. Fujimori's decree was published Dec. 25 in the official newspaper. The decree came after both houses of Congress voted to repeal the law, under which 33 private banks and insurance companies would have been nationalized. The law was announced Aug. 9, 1987, by Garcia, who at the time said the measure aimed at ``democratizing credit.'' It was later approved by Congress, then dominated by Garcia's party, APRA. The unpopular law was immediately challenged in court. It has never taken effect because the court has yet to issue a ruling. However, it raised fears of further nationalizations and exacerbated capital flight, estimated at $5 billion to $10 billion during Garcia's tenure, according to private economists. After the law was announced, police occupied Peru's two largest private banks. Bankers and politicians then began to organize large rallies against the measre. Novelist Mario Vargas Llosa eventually emerged as leader of the groups opposed to the law. These groups later formed a political party, which named Vargas Llosa as its presidential candidate for 1990 elections. He lost to Fujimori, who became president in July and heads the Change 90 party. Fujimori has 120 days to present a new law to regulate bank activities.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Spiritual Leader Says Rushdie Death Sentence in Force
DOC.TEXT: Iran's spiritual leader on Wednesday rejected the latest concessions of author Salman Rushdie, saying his death sentence for offending Moslems remains in effect. Rushdie issued a statement in London on Monday embracing Islam. It stated that the author would not seek the printing of a paperback edition of his novel, ``The Satanic Verses,'' and would not allow its translation into any more languages. The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's leader, called for Rushdie's death in February 1989 for allegedly defaming Islam in his book. In a statement carried by Tehran radio, Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said Wednesday the death sentence still stands. ``God willing, from now on no one will dare insult the great messenger of God, and Islamic sanctities,'' Khamenei said in the statement monitored in Nicosia. He said Rushdie's contention that he had not meant to cause offense would do him no good. Quoting Khomeini, he said that ``even if he (Rushdie) repents and becomes the most pious Muslim on earth, there will be no change in this divine decree.'' ``The Satanic Verses'' has sold 1 million copies. It has been translated into 15 languages. The radical daily newspaper Jomhuri Islami stressed that the death sentence is irrevocable, and it called on Rushdie to prepare to die. ``If Rushdie's repentance and his return to Islam are seen as a sign of his bravery, naturally it is necessary that he shows greater bravery and prepares himself for death,'' the Farsi-language newspaper said Wednesday. ``He will die anyway, but he will be better off to choose his way to eternal salvation courageously before a son of Islam fires the coup de grace,'' it added. The editorial was reported by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency and monitored in Cyprus. Rushdie has been in hiding since Khomeini called for his death, and Tehran put a $1 million bounty on his head. Iran cut diplomatic ties with Britain over the Rushdie affair. The ties were restored Sept. 27 after British officials publicly conceded the book had offended Moslems and said the government had no wish to do so. Khamenei said Wednesday that Rushdie's statement demonstrated that ``Western arrogance has been forced to retreat step by step.'' He added that ``the edict, and the commitment of Moslems around the world to implement it, is showing its first results.'' Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, who has attempted gradually to rebuild Iran's ties with the West, has not rescinded the death edict. But his supporters have indicated they are willing to let the decree lapse.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Draws with Karpov to Retain Chess Championship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with ADD quotes, background on the players and series. No pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Garry Kasparov of the Soviet Union retained his title as world chess champion Wednesday with a draw in the 22nd game, defeating his longtime rival, countryman Anatoly Karpov. The pair ended the 22nd of the 24-match chess championship series with a draw after 43 moves. The half-point each player received put the 27-year-old Kasparov ahead 12-10, allowing him to remain champion. ``I was really nervous because I didn't know what to do, whether to play for the win or draw,'' Kasparov said afterward. ``Then my life became much easier when I had the worse positions, and I had to fight for the draw - and I obliged.'' Though Kasparov has clinched the title, the two must play two more games to determine how the $3 million purse is split. If there is a 12-12 draw after 24 games, the purse will be split evenly; if Kasparov gets another draw or win, he gains $1.7 million. Kasparov won the title from Karpov in 1985. At 22, he was the youngest champion in chess history. He defended the crown by beating Karpov in 1986 and 1987. Karpov had taken the championship in 1975 when American Bobby Fischer refused to defend the title he won in 1972. Kasparov, playing white, arrived promptly at the 5 p.m. (11 a.m. EDT) Wednesday, the starting time at the Palais des Congres. He fidgeted with his pieces awaiting the arrival of Karpov, then made his first move, advancing his king's pawn, before his rival entered. The 39-year-old challenger, 10 minutes late, made an identical first move. They went into an opening known as the Ruy Lopez with the Zaitsev variation, seen before in the second, fourth and 20th games. Kasparov won the second and the 20th using white. But Karpov, playing aggressively, pulled slightly ahead by the 25th move and had two pawns well advanced before Kasparov captured them. By the 30th move, Kasparov had a pawn clear on the queen's side of the board as well as three more pawns, but black had a knight. Both players still had two bishops and their queens, along with their kings. The pair traded bishops and then, on the 38th move, Karpov offered a queen exchange. Kasparov thought about it for 10 minutes and then moved his queen to put Karpov in check. Karpov moved out of check but Kasparov put Karpov in check, forcing a perpetual check situation. Karpov, realizing the forced draw was the likely outcome, looked at Kasparov and shook hands, implicitly offering the draw and giving Kasparov the world title again. Kasparov showed little emotion, talked over the game briefly with Karpov and then smiled when being interviewed. The two men, who are known to dislike each other, differ in temperment, looks, politics and playing style. Kasparov is talkative and flamboyant, playing chess with creativity and decisiveness. He is reform-minded in his politics. Karpov is often protrayed as a colorless introvert who plays with surgical precision. ``I have two loves,'' Karpov has said. ``Communism and chess.'' ``Normally chess is a battle between two individuals,'' Kasparov once said. ``But in my case, with Karpov, it's a fight between two different mentalities in Russia. I identify him with the system I've been fighting.'' The 22nd game had been delayed a week. Karpov had called a timeout Saturday, then the organizers called a technical timeout on Christmas Eve, twice postponing the game. Kasparov rallied to beat Karpov after committing what he called ``the worst blunder of my career'' during the first round of play in New York. It occurred in the seventh game, when Kasparov misplayed a bishop and gave Karpov an advantage that allowed the challenger to win and tie the series at 3.5 points each. However, Kasparov won the previous three times he had white in the nine games in Lyon. Karpov had only won twice in the 21 previous games of the series. The two Soviet grandmasters had six draws in the French portion of the championship. They drew 10 times in the 12 games played in New York between Oct. 8 and Nov. 7.

DOC.HEAD: Four Kashmiri Militants Killed in Grenade Blast
DOC.TEXT: Authorities chasing suspects in an ambush on police lobbed a grenade at a house Wednesday and set it on fire, killing at least four Kashmiri militants, witnesses said. Police said the extremists were only wounded. The witnesses said the militants hiding in the house were the ones who ambushed an Indian police patrol in Kupwara, which borders Pakistani-held Kashmir. They said police demanded the militants surrender but the militants continued to fire bullets from inside. The witnesses in Kupwara, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said at least four militants were killed. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said he did not have details. But he said information indicated the four militants were injured and not dead. He said no policemen were killed. The Moslem militants fighting for Kashmir's independence frequently ambush police patrols. Police have often retaliated by setting fire to houses in villages where the militants take refuge. The government of predominantly Hindu India accuses Pakistan of training and arming the militants. Pakistan denies the allegation but says it is sympathetic to the cause of the militants. Both India and Pakistan claim Jammu-Kashmir state, the only Moslem-majority state in mainly Hindu India. Since gaining independence from Britain in 1947, the two countries have fought two wars over the disputed state. They came close to another war last spring when Kashmiri militants stepped up their violent campaign for secession from India.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Deputy Premier in Baghdad, Will Press Soviets to Return
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Deputy Premier Igor Belousov arrived in Baghdad on Wednesday for talks, the official Iraqi News Agency said. Soviet diplomats in Baghdad said Belousov's principal mission was to try to persuade Soviet workers still in Iraq to leave the country before the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. INA, monitored in Nicosia, said the Soviet minister thanked Iraq for allowing Soviet experts to leave the country although the terms of their contracts had not expired. Iraq decided Dec. 4 that all the Soviet workers and experts in the country could leave. However, about 1,000 Soviet workers have elected to stay in Iraq, where they earn hard currency, rather than returning to the Soviet Union to face a winter of hardships.

DOC.HEAD: Precede PARAMARIBO
Venezuela Asks World Act in Suriname Coup; Nation Reported Calm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Venezuela asks action against new military government in Suriname, U.S. puts Suriname off limits. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Army coup leaders were reported living up to their promise to refrain from repressive measures in Suriname, but Venezuela on Wednesday called the toppling of the democratically elected government intolerable and asked for world action. The U.S. and Dutch governments earlier condemned the coup in the former Dutch colony. The State Department advised Americans on Wednesday not to travel to Suriname and told U.S. citizens in that small, South American nation of 400,000 people to stay indoors. The Foreign Ministry in Caracas, Venezuela, said it would refuse to recognize Suriname's new military government, and asked for a ``firm response'' to the bloodless coup on Christmas Eve that ousted President Ramsewak Shankar. A report from Paramaribo, capital of Suriname, quoted Shankar as saying he and his ministers were not under house arrest and that he had complete freedom of movement. He was reached by telephone at his home late Tuesday. A newspaper editor in Suriname, Leo Morpurgo of the morning daily De Ware Tyd, said on Wednesday that the military has not restricted the press or civil rights since the overthrow. Venezuela emphasized, however, that the November 1987 elections that brought Shankar to power in January 1988 ``expressed the free will and sovereignty of the Surinamese people'' and said the coup must be condemned as as an ``intolerable violation of democracy.'' ``This is a regression in the process of Latin American democracy,'' said a communique from the office of Foreign Minister Reinaldo Figueredo. It demanded immediate restitution of the Shankar government and said the international community should taken ``necessary measures'' to restore the president. A first step might be foreign governments' refusing to recognize the new Suriname government, a government source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Shankar was ousted in an uprising led by acting army chief Cmdr. Ivan Graanoogst, who then pledged to hold elections within 100 days and relinquish power. The army has not spelled out what motivated the coup, but is expected to blame Shankar for not restoring economic health. The coup mastermind was thought to be Lt. Col. Desi Bouterse, who resigned as army chief hours before Shankar was toppled. He and Shankar have long feuded. Bouterse ruled Suriname for eight years after seizing power in a 1980 military coup and wielded considerable power even after Shankar's government was overwhelmingly elected three years ago. Surinamese citizens stayed home from work Wednesday, a regularly scheduled national holiday. Their only information about the coup came from radio and television. Newspapers there do not publish on Christmas Day or the day after. The army leaders who seized power in Suriname, a Georgia-sized nation on South America's northeastern coast, pledged allegiance to democratic principles. They promised to govern in consultation with the elected National Assembly until elections can be held. ``The army is not bent on having and keeping power,'' Graanoogst said in a Christmas Day radio address. He said a ``non-political'' government Cabinet would be appointed within a week. Graanoogst is chief of military police and No. 2 in the military chain of command. Bouterse has not been seen or made any public statements since the coup. It was not immediately clear how the coup might affect an insurgency that has crippled the mining of bauxite - a major export used in producing aluminum. The army opposed a peace agreement between guerrillas and the ousted government. In the 1987 election, Shankar's three-party coalition, the Front for Democracy and Development, easily defeated the military-backed National Democracy Party.

DOC.HEAD: Executed Dictator's Jailed Son Says He Opposed Parents' Policies
DOC.TEXT: Nicu Ceausescu, jailed son of executed Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, said in an interview published Wednesday that his parents had dubbed him an enemy of the people for opposing their policies. ``I told my parents that people were suffering as far back as 1970. From a political point of view, it was a generation struggle,'' The Times of London quoted him as saying. The Times said the interview with its reporter, Tim Judah, took place Monday in the hospital wing of Jilava jail near Bucharest, the Romanian capital. It said the interview was conducted in the presence of Nicu Ceausescu's lawyer, his doctor, and the chief guard of the prison medical wing. The reporter quoted the doctor as saying Ceausescu was terminally ill, suffering from cirrhosis of the liver, a varicosed esophagus and depression. Communist President Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown in the Romanian revolution. He and his wife Elena were executed by firing squad on Dec. 25, 1989. Nicu Ceausescu, 40, is serving a 20-year jail term for incitement to murder following the deaths of 89 people in Sibiu, Transylvania, during the revolution. The former chief of Romania's Communist Youth League, he was Communist Party first secretary at Sibiu at the time. The Times' reporter quoted him as saying: ``The authorities are afraid of me ... but I'm left here, an innocent man in prison, wondering why.'' Ceausescu was quoted as saying that before he fled Sibiu, he ordered the army and the Securitate state security force not to fire on revolutionary demonstrators but his orders were countermanded. Ceausescu did not say by whom. He was quoted as saying he was banished to Sibiu because he opposed his parents' actions. Judah said Ceausescu denied that before the revolution, he had been preparing to succeed them. In the interview, the prisoner said his parents called him an enemy of the people because he opposed the destruction of much of old Bucharest to make way for the huge House of the People building and the 2{-mile-long Boulevard of the Victory of Socialism. The reporter quoted him as saying his father knew only part of what was happening in the country. ``He was surrounded by sycophants. In order to maintain their privileges and power, they told me father that everything he did was good and they agreed with everything he said. No one told him the truth, so from this point of view it was a dictatorship,'' he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Says Government Improperly Seized Building
DOC.TEXT: The government wrongfully seized a rental building where tenants dealt drugs because the landlords were not allowed to defend themselves against the action, an appeals court ruled Wednesday. The seizure was carried out under a federal civil forfeiture law that allows prosecutors to take property used for narcotics activity. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said a judge improperly approved the seizure based only on a finding that the owners, Harvey and Helen Lehrer, were aware tenants dealt drugs in the Brooklyn building. The forfeiture law, adopted by Congress in 1988, includes a clause designed to protect landlords. It states that the government cannot seize buildings if the owners can prove they had no knowledge of drug activity or that they made ``reasonable efforts'' to prevent illegal use of their property. The court said the couple didn't get the chance to show they took steps to curtail drug activity. The appeals court reversed an order approving the seizure and sent the case back to U.S. District Judge Thomas Platt to allow the Lehrers to further defend themselves against the forfeiture. In December 1988, Drug Enforcement Administration agents raided the building and found heroin, cocaine, cash and drug paraphernalia. After the raid, the U.S. attorney's office took steps to seize the building. Bernholtz said the building has been sealed and vacant since the raid.

DOC.HEAD: FTC Staff Again Urges End to Fin-Syn Rules
DOC.TEXT: The economics staff of the Federal Trade Commission said Wednesday it again had urged the Federal Communications Commission to abolish rules that keep broadcast television networks from owning program rerun rights. The FTC's Economics Bureau first urged abolition of the rules in September. It expanded its comments to include several proposed modifications of the financial interest and syndication rules, which commonly are called fin-syn. One proposal would regulate negotiations between program producers and networks, negotiations about which the economists said ``we do not find compelling reasons to adopt any of the proposed restrictions.'' A proposal that would modify but not abolish the rules ``may lead to a result that is less desirable than either complete elimination or complete retention of the rules,'' the bureau said. ``Our analysis of these options leads us to continue to believe that the best course for the FCC is to repeal completely the existing fin-syn rules,'' the bureau said. The Justice Department also has said the rules should be eliminated. The FCC plans to decide next year whether to keep, junk or change the rules, adopted 20 years ago when the broadcast networks had a much larger shae of the prime-time viewing audience than they have today. The rules permit the networks to own only the overseas rerun rights to the prime-time shows they produce themselves and bar the networks from any financial interest in other prime-time programs, including any interest in off-network or ``syndicated'' showings. The FTC's Economics Bureau comments frequently on proposed regulations of other federal agencies and state agencies, generally urging views that would result in increased competition.

DOC.HEAD: Suspicious Fires Disrupt Post-Christmas Shopping, Destroy Stores
DOC.TEXT: Suspicious fires destroyed stores on the same block Wednesday, disrupting post-Christmas shopping and creating a colossal traffic jam. The noon-time blazes erupted simultaneously at Pier 1 Imports and Strouds linen warehouse on opposite ends of the block in the Studio City shopping district, fire officials said. Witnesses reported seeing a man dressed in black behind the stores before the fires broke out, authorities said. Gasoline containers were found. ``It is suspicious, very suspicious. Our arson investigators are on the scene,'' said city fire spokesman Rinaldo Rojo. The only injury was to a firefighter, who suffered a minor burn, said Greg Acevedo, another fire spokesman. Damage was expected to run into the millions of dollars. It was unknown how many people were in the stores when the fires began. Shoppers and employees had fled both buildings by the time firefighters arrived. ``I ran around and the whole comforter aisle was in flames,'' said Lisa Evans, who was inside Strouds when the fire erupted. It took more than 140 firefighters about 1{ hours to extinguish the fires, Acevedo said. At the height of the fires, a pillar of smoke could be seen 10 miles away. Several other Ventura Boulevard businesses were damaged by the fires, including a Realty office, a drug store and a guitar repair shop.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea's Roh Reshuffles Cabinet, Names New Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with other appointment, background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo on Thursday named a new prime minister and foreign minister and reshuffled eight other Cabinet posts in a bid to spruce up his party's image before next year's elections. Ro Jai-bong, 54, a chief aide and former university professor, was named to succeed Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon, who reportedly asked to retire from public life. Ro holds a doctorate in political science from New York University. He would be expected to lead South Korea's delegation in a fourth round of high-level talks on easing tensions with longtime rival North Korea, scheduled for February. The new foreign minister was career diplomat Lee Sang-ok, the ambassador to Switzerland and a former vice foreign minister. Cabinet changes were also made in trade and industry, labor, unification, information, sports, transportation, communications and education. Presidential spokesman Lee Soo-jung announced the shakeup at a news briefing Thursday. Park Seh-jik, chief of the Seoul Olympic Committee that staged the successful 1988 Summer Olympic Games, was named mayor of Seoul. The changes were seen as an attempt by the governing Democratic Liberal Party to spur public support before local elections to be held in 1991. Roh's five-year term ends in 1992. He has made dramatic progress in foreign relations by expanding Seoul's ties with socialist and former communist nations, but support for his domestic policies is at an all-time low. Roh has changed the Cabinet several times since taking office in February 1988. On Wednesday, the Agency for National Security Planning, a government intelligence agency, announced the arrest of 31 students on charges of forming a North Korean-directed organization that sought to overthrow the government. It said in a statement that more than 70 other members of the Chamintong group were being sought and that the organization has about 800 members. The agency said the goal of Chamintong - an acronym meaning ``independence, democracy and unification'' - was to form a unified Korea by 1995 under the leadership of North Korea's Communist chief, Kim Il Sung. It said the organization would resort to armed fighting if necessary. The agency said investigations found that Chamintong has manipulated the Chondaehyop, a dissident student alliance, to stage anti-government and anti-American activities in the guise of seeking democratization. The two Koreas have been separated since 1945 and fought in the 1950-53 Korean War.

DOC.HEAD: Census Figures Good News for the West, the South and the GOP
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf: ``A state's,'' to CORRECT number of electoral votes needed to win from 268 to 270
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Census Count Bjt, a0626
DOC.TEXT: The government's 1990 census figures awarded political clout to California and the South on Wednesday and carried good news to Republican presidential candidates for at least the rest of this century. At the same time, the numbers diminished the political strength of states in the Northeast and Midwest, and set the stage for power struggles in every state except the six which now have only one congressional district each. As a result of the census count, congressional district lines will be redrawn in every state except those six, and 19 congressional seats will be shifted. Eight states will gain representation - and power - in Congress. Thirteen will lose seats and clout. California will be the chief gainer, adding seven more congressional seats, bringing its total to 52. Florida will gain four, going to 23; Texas will gain three, going to 30. And one additional seat in the House will go to five states - Arizona, going to six; Georgia, to 11; North Carolina, to 12; Virginia, to 11 and Washington, to nine. New York, going down to 31, will lose three seats. Two seats will be lost by four states - Illinois, going to 20, Michigan, to 16; Ohio, to 19; and Pennsylvania, to 21. Eight states will lose one each - Iowa, going to five; Kansas, to four; Kentucky, to six; Louisiana, to seven; Massachusetts, to 10; Montana, to one; New Jersey, to 13; and West Virginia, to three. In presidential elections, the figures make winning easier for Republicans because states which the GOP usually carries will gain votes in the electoral college while states which the Democrats depend upon will have less importance. A state's number of votes in the electoral college equals the total of its congressmen and its two senators. So in the presidential elections of 1992 and 1996, California, which no Democrat has carried in a presidential election since 1964, will have 54 of the 270 electoral votes a candidate needs to win the presidency, or one out of five. The other states with new electoral college importance are also in the West and Sunbelt - regions tending in recent years to go Republican. ``The political consequences advantage the Republicans,'' said Stephen Hess, political analyst at the Brookings Institution, a research organization. ``The Republican vote has tended to come more from the new West and the burgeoning Sunbelt.'' Curtis Gans, director of the non-partisan Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, disputed what he said was the widespread view of the census figures as a ``windfall for the Republicans.'' He said Republicans will gain in congressional elections, but only in the short run. Most states that gained seats did so because of growing Hispanic populations, Gans said, and ``Hispanics of the class that is expanding the population in California, Florida, New Mexico and Arizona tend to vote 2-1 Democratic. Eventually that's going to tell - probably within the next decade.'' Only in Florida, where Cuban-Americans favor conservative candidates, can the Republicans anticipate long-term gains, he said. Redistricting battles will start soon in the 43 states which will have more than one representative in Congress - and they promise to be particularly painful in states which must eliminate seats held by incumbents. In New York, for example, redistricting may mean that Democratic Reps. Charles Schumer and Stephen Solarz, both representing Brooklyn, will have to compete for a single seat in the game of musical chairs that a new census sets off every decade. It is no coincidence, Hess said, that both have built up campaign war chests in the million-dollar range, anticipating a costly battle to stay in Congress - or perhaps a costly race for a post elsewhere, perhaps the Senate seat occupied by Republican Alfonse M. D'Amato. The six states which have only one congressman, and thus avoid redistricting, are Alaska, Delaware, North Dakota, South Dakota, Vermont and Wyoming. Montana, in losing a congressman in 1992, will join that list.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Reporter Testifies in Court Fight Over FBI Documents
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter who received copies of confidential FBI documents during the trial of nine organized crime figures said Wednesday he knew who sent him the material and promised the source anonymity. The U.S. attorney's office in Pittsburgh wants to recover the documents from two newspapers and three television stations so investigators can trace the leak. Initially, six news outlets that received the documents were subpoenaed to give them to a federal grand jury. The Tribune-Review of Greensburg relinquished the documents. Attorneys for The Pittsburgh Press, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and television stations KDKA and WPXI filed motions to quash the subpoenas. Television station WTAE also received the documents, but did not join in the motions. During a hearing, Post-Gazette reporter Mike Bucsko said he received the documents in the mail several weeks before other news organizations did. Bucsko said he knew the source and had promised anonymity. Assistant U.S. Attorney Linda L. Kelly didn't ask Bucsko to identify the source in court. U.S. District Judge Donald J. Lee took the matter under advisement and will rule later. Attorneys for the news organizations argued that relinquishing the documents could ultimately identify the source, whether reporters know the source or not. The government claims the documents, known as FBI 302 reports, have value as evidence. Prosecutors have said whoever mailed the documents could be prosecuted for obstruction of justice or contempt of court. The reports were capsules of debriefings of federal witness Marvin Droznek. The reports were among many shared by the government with defense attorneys in the trial of nine organized crime figures. A jury Oct. 29 convicted reputed organized crime underbosses Charles ``Chucky'' Porter, Louis F. Raucci and seven others of racketeering and related charges. The convictions ended an eight-week trial that prosecutors called the largest ever involving organized crime figures in western Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles County Sheriff Calls 1990 Year of Homicides
DOC.TEXT: The year was one of rampant homicides and violence in Los Angeles County, but public tolerance of the bloodshed is even more troubling, the sheriff said Wednesday. In the past, Sheriff Sherman Block said, a homicide report would bring news media running to the scene. ``Now, they call and ask, `Is it a routine murder?''' Block said. ``We have routine murders. ... Homicides become box scores like the baseball games. ... There doesn't seem to be the level of outrage I think there should be at these events.'' Block called 1990 a year of ``pluses and minuses'' for his department, the largest minus being the conviction of six deputy sheriffs on charges of skimming drug money. But he said he was proud of the majority of honest people who make up his 12,000-member department. Block said the year's most troubling development was the explosion of gang-related homicides responsible for pushing murder figures up 32 percent in areas of the county policed by the sheriff's department. There were 158 gang-related homicides within the sheriff's jurisdiction during the first 11 months of this year, way up from 104 during the same period last year and shattering the record of 116 set for all of 1989. The sheriff said a report that 22 people died violently over the Christmas weekend was ``not unusual.'' ``What troubles me is the apparent tolerance of violence that we have developed in this community,'' Block said.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Tunisian Diplomat Sentenced to Death for Spying
DOC.TEXT: A senior Tunisian diplomat has been sentenced to death for spying, government sources said Wednesday. Lamari Mohamed Dali, deputy director of the African Affairs Department of the Tunisian Foreign Ministry, was arrested in October for ``espionage for profit,'' said the sources, who would not allow themselves to be further identified. Dali was passing ``secret documents'' to a foreign power when he was arrested, said the sources, who declined to identify the other country. Dali's death sentence was handed down Tuesday, the sources said. His appeal is set to be heard Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Industrialist Irl Daffin Dead at 88
DOC.TEXT: Industrialist Irl A. Daffin, who developed labor-saving machines for the farming and construction industries, has died at age 88. Daffin died Tuesday at his home in Lititz. In the early 1940s, Daffin and associates turned farmer-inventor Edwin Nolt's idea for a hay baler into a moneymaking product. They bought control of New Holland Machine Co. and turned the baler into the cornerstone of what is now Ford New Holland Inc., a major manufacturer of agricultural implements. Daffin also developed a mobile feed mill and in his 70s founded a charter airplane company bearing his name. ``I don't think I've ever been in anything yet that wasn't more or less new,'' Daffin once said. ``You don't always get big, but you have to think big.'' Daffin, a native of Caroline County, Md., grew up on Maryland's Eastern Shore and studied at the former Goldey Business College in Wilmington, Del.

DOC.HEAD: Another 60 Albanians Cross Into Greece Over Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs with two Albanian fishermen seeking refuge in Italy
DOC.TEXT: Police on Wednesday said that 60 Albanians seeking political asylum crossed into Greece over two days. A police spokesman in the capital said border posts reported the Albanians, including 37 ethnic Greeks, walked across the frontier near the villages of Delvinakion and Filiates. He said most arrived on Tuesday. ``It's a madhouse here, the police station is full of refugees,'' a police officer in Delvinakion said. The Albanians all filed for political asylum and were to be taken to a United Nations refugee center on the outskirts of Athens. Ethnic Greeks are automatically granted asylum. The spokesman in Delvinakion said on condition of anonymity that he did not know if any Albanians had been stopped on the other side of the border. He said local welfare agencies were giving refugees food, clothing and pocket money. Albanians have been trickling into Greece since last summer, when protests of Albania's Communist government broke out in the tiny Balkan nation of 3.3 million. The Greek government has accused Albanian authorities of murdering many ethnic Greeks who try to cross the border. Government spokesman Vyron Polydoras on Monday charged that Albanian soldiers shot and killed three men, including an ethnic Greek. He did not say when the killings occurred but described them as ``extermination in the most revolting fashion.'' The Christmas exodus was the second-largest in three days, police said. On Monday, 107 Albanians, including 70 ethnic Greeks, fled into Greece. Greece claims there are more than 350,000 ethnic Greeks living in southern Albania. The Albanian government says the minority only numbers 60,000. In Brindisi, Italy, authorities said Wednesday that two Albanian fishermen locked up four co-workers and sailed their boat to Italy. Police said the pair had requested political asylum, and the four others who had been locked in the ship's cabin planned to go home on their boat.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Gives Seabrook Plant's Management Above Average Assessment
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday that the management of the Seabrook nuclear plant did an above average job in preparing to go on line. The commission rated plant management's preparation ``a little above average,'' and called the overall evaluation ``positive,'' said Karl Abraham of NRC regional headquarters in Pennsylvania. Seabrook began operation in August, following two decades of court challenges and thousands of arrests in mass demonstrations. Critics still charge that the plant's plan for evacuation in the event of a nuclear accident is inadequate. Federal stock regulators last week approved acquisition of the bankrupt facility that controls the Seabrook plant. Northeast Utilities wants to buy Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, which holds the largest stake, 35.6 percent, in the plant. The NRC report said preparation for full-power licensing and subsequent testing and commercial startup was ``careful, conservative planning and safe, proficient accomplishment.'' The review, covering July 1, 1989, to Oct. 31, 1990, also gave high marks to emergency preparedness, security and safeguards, as well as plant operations and maintenance. Seabrook management received good ratings in a previous NRC review covering Sept. 1, 1987, through June 30, 1989. The NRC said the latest review showed improvements in some areas, including operations and safety. The $6.6 billion plant was completed in 1986, 10 years after construction began. It received full power licensing in March, reached full power in July and began commercial operation in August. It has operated efficiently, except for two weeks in November when mechanical problems shut down the reactor. ``This report will be very helpful for us as we continually strive to improve our performance,'' said Ted Feigenbaum, president of New Hampshire Yankee, the plant's operator.

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Cruzan was a Lover of Animals, Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `A state ...' to CLARIFY Nancy Cruzan's brain likely deprived of oxygen for 12 to 14 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Right To Die, AM-Cruzan-Legacy
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan was driving home from work when her 1963 Rambler ran off the road. She was found face down in a ditch and stopped breathing for about 15 minutes.
