The accident left the vibrant young lover of children and animals in a vegetative state for nearly eight years, and it produced a landmark right-to-die ruling that allowed for Ms. Cruzan's death Wednesday after her feeding tube was removed. Ms. Cruzan worked at a cheese plant at the time of the accident in 1983. For six months in 1978, she worked as a teacher's aide at a school for deaf and blind children in Joplin. Each day, Ms. Cruzan fed Melissa, a severely handicapped 3-year-old who suffered from an involuntary reflex that caused her to thrust out her tongue when food touched her mouth. Ms. Cruzan repeatedly had to stick a tube filled with food down the girl's throat. ``We agreed if we were ever in a car accident or impaired to the point of Melissa, we would not want to live like that,'' a fellow teacher's aide, Marianne Smith, recalled in court last month. Judge Charles Teel Jr. considered Mrs. Smith's testimony and that of two other former co-workers when he granted the request of Ms. Cruzan's parents Dec. 14 and allowed her feeding tube to be withdrawn. Ms. Cruzan, 33, died with her parents at her side in the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, 12 days after the tube was removed. The accident that disabled Ms. Cruzan occurred about 1 a.m. Jan. 11, 1983. She was driving home from her job in Carthage when she apparently took a curve too fast and her car overturned. A state trooper found Ms. Cruzan lying face down in a ditch. She wasn't breathing. Paramedics got her breathing again, but not before her brain had been deprived of oxygen for an estimated six to 20 minutes, most probably for 12 to 14 minutes, court records showed. Joe Cruzan, a construction worker, remembered his daughter as ``mischievous.'' ``She was always the clown, but not a smart aleck. And yet for all her orneriness, she was just as cute as she could be,'' he said. Ms. Cruzan's mother, Joyce, who is a school secretary, said Nancy loved all animals, especially cats. She preferred to work at night because she hated to get out of bed in the morning, her mother said. She also had a green thumb, nursing back to life sick plants brought to her by her sisters, Christy and Donna. ``Nancy didn't have a long life, but it's all the life she's going to have,'' Mrs. Cruzan said. ``She lived life to the fullest pretty much all her life. That's more than a lot of people do.'' ``It's so terrible to have all the good memories shaded over by what she's like now,'' said Ms. Cruzan's sister, Christy White. Joe Cruzan said last week he looked forward to his daughter's death so she finally would be at peace. ``Somewhere out there Nancy's still tied to this body by a thread,'' he said. ``We are going to snip that thread and then she will be completely free.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition, Foreign Observers Allege Vote-Rigging in Serbia
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties and electoral observers on Wednesday accused the ruling communists of widespread vote-tampering in Serbia's first free elections in 50 years. The Socialists, a renamed Communist Party, crushed opposition parties in the Dec. 9 first-round vote and in runoffs Sunday, taking a total of 194 seats in the republic's 250-seat parliament. Socialist President Slobodan Milosevic was reelected with more than 60 percent support. Serbia, the country's largest republic, and Montenegro, the smallest, are the only two of Yugoslavia's six states to elect Communist governments. In the other four states, center-right or nationalist parties triumphed in multiparty elections this year. ``Because of all the irregularities that accompanied them, the Serbian elections would not be considered legal in the West,'' said Zoran Hodzera, a political consultant from Washington, D.C. He was a member of a delegation of Americans and Canadians of Serbian origin that monitored the vote. He said the elections ``were not really democratic.'' To buttress his claims, Hodzera cited a sudden, 10-percent increase in the number of registered voters on Dec. 9 and evidence of voting without identification documents. He also said officials had tried to intimidate voters and showed strong bias against opposition parties in state-run media during the campaign. Miodrag Skulic, a spokesman for the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest opposition party, told reporters specific complaints of irregularities had been lodged with the state electoral commission. The movement won 19 seats. However, the commission has discounted as ``undocumented'' numerous opposition objections to how the vote was handled. Serbian authorities have denied any wrongdoing. Serbia is at odds with the Western-minded republics of Slovenia and Croatia, which intend to secede if Yugoslavia is not transformed into a looser confederation. Serbia favors strong central control.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Israel to Receive First Blow in Case of War
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has told a television interviewer that Israel is the prime mover behind the Persian Gulf crisis and, as such, would receive the first Iraqi blow if war breaks out. The remark was contained in an interview broadcast after midnight Wednesday by the Spanish private network Tele 5, which earlier paraphrased Saddam's threat in a news release. Saddam spoke to the network Saturday in Baghdad. Saddam blamed the crisis on what he said were U.S. attempts to preserve its international influence and on Israel's ``expansionist'' policies. He also expressed surprise at the Soviet Union's position in the conflict, deeming it irresponsible and unjust. ``We consider that the responsibility for the problems, for the Arab conflicts, falls on Israel and the Zionists. It is they who have pushed Bush into the dead-end street in which he now finds himself,'' he said, referring toi President Bush. ``Because of that and in the case we suffer an aggression, we consider Israel a participant ... In other words, if we must suffer the first blow, whether at the front or here in Baghdad, and whether or not Israel participates directly in the aggression, they will suffer the second in Tel Aviv.'' Saddam reiterated his position that no peaceful solution to the conflict can emerge unless steps are taken to provide Palestinians with a homeland. ``For us, the Arabs, the Palestinian cause is the main issue, the central axis of our struggle,'' he said. He said the Iraqi people ``do not give the slightest importance'' to the United Nations Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait, although he said Iraq was suffering under the U.N.-sponsored embargo. The U.N. Security Council authorized the use of force by U.S. and allied troops if Iraq fails to withdraw from Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2 and later annexed. He said Iraq was ready to fight, but left open the door to dialogue. ``We advocate peace and dialogue, but if others want war and aggression ... we are decided to crush that aggression,'' Saddam said. ``We are not worried by threats. The most fundamental thing for us is to preserve our spiritual integrity ... our dignity and our sovereignty.'' He said Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation last week showed that many Soviets opposed the government's decision to back the U.N.-sponsored embargo against Iraq. ``Shevardnadze danced to (U.S. Secretary of State James) Baker's tune. And he didn't have a clearly defined point of view. In any case, whether it was Shevardnadze or someone else who was responsible for Soviet foreign policy, the Soviet posture is neither just nor responsible,'' the Iraqi leader said. Saddam said the United States sent troops to the gulf to preserve power after the end of the Cold War. ``The decline of the Soviet Union has made the United States the only superpower in the world. The United States needs to control Middle East petroleum to keep excercising influence over Europe, Japan, and probably, in a later phase, over the Soviet Union,'' he said. Saddam said Arab leaders lined up against Iraq in the conflict were not heeding their people's will. ``We want to see the heads roll of aggressors and traitors, and we also want the decline of leaders who preach injustice and practice aggression,'' he said.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Music Hall of Fame, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0545,0306
DOC.HEAD: Five Recordings Inducted Into Recording Academy Hall of Fame
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Moonlight Serenade ... to ADD details on first Miller induction. Pick up 7th graf, ``Show Boat ...
DOC.TEXT: The original Broadway cast recording of ``West Side Story'' and Erroll Garner playing ``Misty'' are among five inductees at the Hall of Fame of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. The academy, which bestows the annual Grammy Awards, has inducted pre-1958 musical pieces into its Hall of Fame since 1974. The Grammys were first awarded in 1958. This year's Hall of Fame recordings are: ``Call It Stormy Monday,'' ``Misty,'' ``Moonlight Serenade,'' ``Show Boat,'' and ``West Side Story,'' the academy announced Wednesday. ``Call It Stormy Monday,'' is a blues piece recorded in 1947 by Aaron T-Bone Walker. Walker, who died in 1975, helped develop the modern blues sound with his electric guitar style. ``Misty,'' was recorded by pianist Garner in 1954 and is his most famous composition. Garner, a self-taught musician, died in 1977. ``Moonlight Serenade,'' was Glen Miller's theme song, and is the second of his works to be inducted into the Hall of Fame. His recording of ``In the Mood'' was inducted in 1983. Miller recorded ``Moonlight Serenade,'' which helped the Miller band to a top spot among American dance bands, in 1939. ``Show Boat,'' recorded by Jerome Kern in 1932, was the first album of show music recorded in the United States. The voices of Paul Robeson and Helen Morgan are among those on the album. The original cast album of Leonard Bernstein's ``West Side Story'' was produced and released in 1957. It featured Carol Lawrence and Larry Kert. The recordings were chosen by the academy's 100-member Elections Committee, which considers recommendations from the academy's 8,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Nation Continues to Shiver From Record Cold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The low ...' to CORRECT spelling to Embarrass, sted Embarass. Pick up 6th graf, `International Falls ...' ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Bitter cold permeated much of the nation Wednesday and the Pacific Northwest braced for a new blast of arctic air this weekend. Sacramento, Calif., shivered through a seventh day of record-breaking temperatures, with a low of 23 degrees. Other low temperature records shattered included 29 degrees below zero in Aberdeen, S.D.; 23 below in Alamosa, Colo.; 5 in both Albuquerque, N.M., and Amarillo, Texas; zero in Colorado Springs, Colo.; 22 below in Dickinson, N.D.; and 25 below in Duluth, Minn. International Falls, Minn., had a record-breaking low of 38 below. The low temperature for the nation Wednesday was 45 degrees below at both Embarrass, Minn., and Park Rapids, Minn. At 1 p.m. EST, temperatures remained below zero over parts of Wisconsin, Iowa, Minnesota, South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana. It was a different story in Kodiak, Alaska, where warm west winds pushed the temperature up to a record high of 46 degrees. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 14 degrees below zero at Thief River Falls, Minn., to 80 degrees in Key West, Fla. Snow was scattered Wednesday over New Hampshire, New York state, Ohio, Michigan, Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, Kansas, Idaho, Montana, Washington and Oregon. Rain fell along the Washington and Oregon coasts. Showers and isolated thunderstorms dampened the eastern half of Texas and western Louisiana as warm air from the Gulf of Mexico rolled over a ridge of cooler air hovering over the area. A second round of snow, cold temperatures and gusty winds was expected to reach the northern Pacific Coast this weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Disqualifies Eight Parliament Members
DOC.TEXT: The Election Commission has disqualified eight members of parliament for joining a rebel organization and forming a rival government, state radio said Wednesday. The announcement said the eight were being punished for collaborating with insurgent organizations to form a parallel government. The rival administration was formed at the headquarters of the Karen National Union rebels bordering Thailand on Dec. 18. Six of the deputies were from the National League for Democracy, one was from the Party for National Democracy, and one was an independent. The National League for Democracy won 392 of 485 seats in May 27 general elections, but the military government refused to relinquish power. The government earlier declared the eight fugitives from arrest. It canceled the registration of the Party for National Democracy on Dec. 20 after its chairman, Sein Win, was declared leader of the rival government.

DOC.HEAD: Frost Nips Rose Parade Flowers, Cold Brings Shiver to South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `The lowest ...' to CORRECT spelling of Embarrass, sted Embarass. Pick up 9th graf, `Snow covered ...'
DOC.TEXT: Workers in Los Angeles scurried Wednesday to find replacements for frost-damaged flowers on Rose Parade floats and residents in states used to milder winters continued to shiver from unusual cold. Low records on Christmas Day were shattered in more than 125 U.S. cities and at least 80 deaths have been blamed on frigid cold and floods. Ann Jones of Tupelo, Miss., was among thousands of people who endured a lack of heat when a natural gas pipeline crossing the Tombigbee River ruptured in a rush of high water over the weekend. Heat was restored Tuesday. ``We have been camped out in front of the fireplace making memories,'' she said. ``The best Christmas present was the heat and hot water.'' In Sacramento, Calif., Wednesday brought a record low for the seventh consecutive day - 23 degrees. It broke the 1962 record of 26 degrees. Kodiak, Alaska, basked in Christmas Day's record high of 47 degrees. The previous mark was 46 degrees, set in 1984. Other record lows set around the nation Wednesday were: Aberdeen, S.D., 29 degrees below zero; Albuquerque, N.M., 5 degrees; and Amarillo, Texas, 5 degrees, which was a shade colder than the 6 degree record set in 1894. The lowest recorded temperature was 45 degrees below zero in Embarrass, Minn. Snow covered much of New England and upper New York, the Midwest, the Rocky Mountain states and down in east Texas and Western Louisiana. Wind machines, orchard heaters and sprinklers deployed to fight the freeze couldn't save much of California's orange, lemon, avocado and strawberry crops. Leaves on avocado trees were limp, their edges dried to a frosty crisp. The usually waxy green leaves on lemon trees turned gold and curled. Worst off are the orchards of navel oranges, said Bob Krauter of the California Farm Bureau Federation. He had no dollar estimate on the damage. The state reported that California's 1989-90 navel orange crop was valued at $248 million. California Citrus Mutual, a growers' organization, estimated 80 percent of the current crop was still on the trees when frost hit. Since that was wiped out, the loss could reach $200 million. The cold hindered builders in a hurry to complete Rose Parade floats. Volunteers busily attached corn husks, dried straw flowers and onion seeds while float builders searched for replacements for frost-damaged marigolds, lavenders and irises. ``The weather has us scurrying, but that's what this business is all about,'' said Rick Chapman, owner of Azusa's Festival Artists-Floatmasters Inc. ``It hasn't been this cold since 1981.'' The bad news on Northern California's cold front is drawing attention from a much bigger problem - drought. ``Our reservoirs, statewide, are at about 50 percent of the historical average and 30 percent of capacity,'' said Geno Young of the state Department of Water Resources. The National Weather Service predicted another burst of winter this weekend for the Northern Pacific coast. Frost was expected as far south as San Diego early next week.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Attack 20 Minutes after IRA Christmas Cease-Fire Ends
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen fired at police guarding a road checkpoint early Thursday, 20 minutes after the end of a three-day Christmas cease-fire ordered by the IRA. Police headquarters at Belfast said in a statement that police at Annathmartin checkpoint, 70 miles west of Belfast, returned the fire but nobody was reported injured on either side. No group immediately claimed responsibility but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite the Protestant-dominated province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule. Police said the shooting happened 20 minutes into Thursday. The IRA cease-fire began at midnight Sunday and ended at midnight Wednesday. Police said no attacks were recorded in Northern Ireland throughout the IRA cease-fire.

DOC.HEAD: Parishioners in Last Days of Fight to Save Historic Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Barry said ...' to UPDATE with Wednesday night gathering and CLARIFY that `vigil' to be held one hour a day for five days. Pick up 5th graf, `The Society ...'
DOC.TEXT: The faithful who gathered at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church hoped it wouldn't be the last Christmas celebrated in the deteriorating church, one of the few buildings to survive the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. Parishioners need to raise $125,000 more by New Year's Eve to save the 130-year-old Victorian Gothic church, said Dick Barry, a spokesman for the Holy Family Preservation Society. ``We're going to make our goal,'' the Rev. George Lane said Monday. ``Our motto is `Say prayers and send money.''' About 20 parishioners braved 10-degree temperatures to gather on the church steps Wednesday night for the first candlelight rosary service to be held one hour a day for five days. The Society of Jesus, which owns the church, has threatened to tear it down and sell the property unless the parish can raise $1 million of a $3 million repair bill by the deadline. Construction on the church began in 1857. By 1860, it was the third-largest church in the United States. Its 226-foot bell tower was the tallest structure in Chicago and its stained glass windows were the first installed in the city. When fire broke out in October 1871 and devastated the city, Holy Family, only five blocks from where the fire began, was unharmed. It was one of only five public buildings spared by the fire. ``The Rev. Arnold Damen, Jesuit founder of the parish, vowed that if the church was spared, seven lights would burn perpetually at the church's shrine to Our Lady of Perpetual Help,'' Lane said. ``The seven lights, now electrified, still burn in the church today, even though the main section of the building has been closed for six years.'' The congregation has been using the side chapel since falling plaster made the main room unusable. But the main nave is still structurally sound and seats more than 1,200, so church officials would like to reopen it after repairs. Barry said the church needs repairs to its slate roof and its copper sheeting, as well as work on its downspouts and interior plaster. ``The first $1 million would go for that, and we'd use the rest for less urgent things, like renovating the interior and adding modern improvements,'' he said. Barry said generous former parishioners and alumni of the adjoining St. Ignatius College Prep, one of the city's oldest and most prestigious Roman Catholic high schools, helped them near their goal. ``One auto dealer from the suburbs, a graduate of St. Ignatius, gave us $50,000 last week,'' he said. ``Another graduate, who has a large Italian restaurant, threw banquets for us and gave us all the proceeds.'' If the parish makes the deadline for raising the first $1 million, it then will have some breathing room to come up with the rest of the money. Barry said the Jesuits have pledged a $750,000 maintenance fund, and a union has offered to do $50,000 worth of electrical work for free.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Believe Handgun Used to Kill Women Stolen From Nearby Cabin
DOC.TEXT: The handgun used to kill two women who were slain when they surprised two intruders at a remote mountain cabin apparently was stolen from a nearby cabin, authorities said Wednesday. Several cabins were burglarized before Beth Harmon Tidwell Potts, 76, and her daughter, Kaye Tidwell Tiede, 49, were killed Saturday, Summit County Sheriff Fred Eley said. Mrs. Tiede's husband, Rolf Tiede, 51, was shot in the face during the confrontation and has been released from a hospital. The couple's two daughters, age 16 and 20, were held hostage but were not harmed. The family, from Humble, Texas, planned to spend the holidays at the cabin. Most items stolen from the unspecified number of cabins in the Beaver Springs subdivision 45 miles east of Salt Lake City have been recovered, said Eley. On the day of the slayings, authorities arrested Von Lester Taylor, 25, and Edward Steven Deli, 21, who walked away from a halfway house for prison parolees Dec. 14. The men were charged with two counts each of first-degree murder, two count of attempted first-degree murder, two counts of aggravated kidnapping and other felonies. They were held without bond pending a Jan. 8 preliminary hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Former West Virginia University President Dies
DOC.TEXT: Irvin Stewart, a former president of West Virgina University and top government research executive in World War II, is dead at age 91. Stewart died Monday at his Washington home. He had suffered a series of strokes. A lawyer, Stewart first worked in Washington in 1926 as an assistant solicitor at the State Department. His various Washington positions over the years included service, on loan from the State Department, on the staff of Rep. Sam Rayburn, D-Texas, where he helped draft the 1934 Communications Act. That legislation established the Federal Communications Commission and still guides federal telecommunications policy. In World War II, Stewart was executive secretary of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, the agency that guided development of the atomic bomb. He was president of West Virginia University from 1946 to 1958, and taught law there until retirement in 1967. Stewart is survived by his wife, Florence, and a son.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT California increase from 26.3 percent to 26.1 percent; SUBS grafs 13-15 bgng: ``The sharpest,'' to CORRECT Arizona from 36 percent to 35.3 percent; South Atlantic from 18.4 percent to 18.8 percent and ``West South Central'' to ``East South Central''
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Census Count-States
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. population stood at 249,632,692 as of the 1990 census, the government said Wednesday in a numerical portrait of a nation growing far more rapidly in the Sun Belt than in the industrial north and agricultural heartland. California, the nation's largest state, added more than 6 million people in the decade, a 26.1 percent increase to 29,839,250 people. Wyoming remained the smallest state, with 455,975 people, down 2.9 percent from 1980. Nevada was the biggest population gainer in percentage terms, and Florida and Arizona each grew by more than one-third as millions of Americans flocked to the sunshine. West Virginia was the largest loser in percentage terms. In all, the population increased by 10.2 percent from the 226,504,825 people counted in the 1980 census, below the 11.4 percent population growth recorded from 1970 to 1980, and the 13.4 percent rate from 1960 to 1970. The information was contained in the Census Bureau's first release of ``final figures'' - really tentative final figures - from the 1990 count. The information will be used for everything from readjusting the size of each state's congressional delegation to parcelling out federal aid. In political terms, the population shifts will give California seven new House seats, and add lawmakers to seven other states. Thirteen states will lose representation. Because of the importance of the population estimates, some states and cities are likely to challenge the tallies, and a final count isn't expected until next summer. The cost of the 1990 census, from planning begun in 1984 to a final release of data in 1993, is estimated at $2.6 billion by the bureau. Still locked in Census Bureau computers - to be doled out over the next several years - is a wealth of information about age, race, living conditions and other details of America near the turn of the century. Besides Wyoming, four other states lost population. The biggest percentage loser was West Virginia, whose population dropped by 7.6 percent to 1,801,625. Other states losing population were Iowa, down 4.3 percent, and and North Dakota, down 1.7 percent. The District of Columbia also lost population, 4.5 percent. The sharpest gainer in percentage terms was Nevada. That state's population grew by 50.7 percent to 1,206,152. Besides California, other states with gains of more than 25 percent were Florida, up 33.4 percent; Arizona, up 35.3 percent; and Alaska, up 37.4 percent. The Pacific states were the fastest growing region, 23.4 percent, followed by the Mountain states, 20.6 percent, and the South Atlantic states, 18.8 percent. By contrast, the East North Central states grew a bare 1.1 percent, and the West North Central states, 3.1 percent. Some regions went against the broader trend. New England, which had a boom in high-tech industry during the 1980s, grew by 7.2 percent. The East South Central states grew only 3.9 percent. Because of the high financial and political stakes, the census numbers and the way they were obtained are certain to draw continued sharp scrutiny. More than 6,000 local governments challenged the accuracy of a preliminary count based mainly on the April 1 census taken by mail. The Census Bureau responded with a series of recounts and an ad campaign urging people who thought they had been missed to come forward. The final national population total was nearly 4 million people more than the preliminary number released by the bureau earlier this year. Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher has until July 1991, to decide whether to adjust the census numbers to account for a statistically determined undercount of minorities. An adjustment would increase political representation of areas with a high percentage of minorities, and lower that of other areas. California will gain seven seats, giving it 52 in the 435-member House. Florida will gain four; Texas, three; and Arizona, Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia and Washington, one seat each. New York will lose three seats; Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania, two seats each; and Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Montana, New Jersey and West Virginia, one seat each. The 1990 census for the first time counted some Americans living abroad. The total included 922,819 members of the armed forces, civilian employees of the federal government and their dependents. The comparable numbers from 10 years earlier counted only people living within the United States. The Census Bureau on Wednesday released two sets of 1980 numbers. The 226,504,825 figure used by the bureau for comparison with the 1990 national total was released in December 1980 but was later adjusted slightly to get rid of minor problems. The adjusted figure was 226,545,805. The 1990 population count was nearly 64 times the 3,929,214 counted in 1790, the first census in the nation's history. By 1900, the population had reached 76,212,168. In 1950, the first census after World War II, the population was 151,325,798. In January, the Census Bureau will begin sending information on small areas, in some cases the size of a city block, to state legislatures so they can begin drawing new congressional and legislative boundaries. That process will be completed by April 1. The bureau will put off releasing detailed demographic data until after the decision on adjusting the figures.

A late Christmas card from your procrastinating Uncle Harold won't be the only thing missing from your mailbox today. Your annual greetings from the Internal Revenue Service won't be in the mail either. The IRS, after years of sending its tax packages out on the day following Christmas, has decided to give taxpayers a brief reprieve. This year, the forms will go out on Friday, three days following Christmas. ``We want to move it away from the Christmas holiday to allow folks to enjoy that period of the year as long as they possibly can before we throw a wet blanket on them,'' said Arthur Altman, director of the IRS tax forms division. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - School suicide-prevention programs for teen-agers can do some youngsters more harm than good, researchers said today. Columbia University researchers said they found little evidence that such programs reduced suicides or suicide attempts, according to a study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association, ``There was some evidence of unwanted effects'' on teen-agers who have attempted suicide, researchers from Columbia's medical school. Discussing the topic openly often stirred up suicidal feelings, subjects of the study said. Of those who had tried to kill themselves before taking part in school counseling, 26.7 percent thought the programs increase the chances that youths will attempt suicide. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Dismissing demands that he stand aside, Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. says he will keep ``plugging away'' as chairman of the Senate Banking Committee while defending his conduct against new ethical questions in the Keating Five savings and loan scandal. Riegle intends to convene hearings early next year on providing money for the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency selling off assets of defunct thrifts, and he has prepared legislation to rescue the government fund that guarantees bank customers' deposits. He likely will call Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan to testify in February - just the type of setting that attracts heavy media coverage and gives lawmakers a forum for expressing concern about the victims of a slowing economy. But while the Michigan Democrat busies himself for work overseeing an industry in financial distress, he also must defend his own integrity against fresh questions in the heavily publicized Keating Five hearings - and fend off Republican calls to relinquish his committee chairmanship. ---= SPRING CITY, Tenn. (AP) - For Mayor John Landreth, the fourth flood in 18 months really took the cake. His 50th anniversary cake. ``When we opened (the banquet hall) up on Sunday, there was a foot of water and the cake was floating on the floor,'' said his wife, Mildred. In addition to ruining the party at the Legion Hall, the flood on Piney Creek caused $500,000 in damage and forced more than 160 people from their homes. Now Landreth is ready to take on the Army Corps of Engineers. ``We don't need another study,'' the mayor said Tuesday. ``We need the damn creek fixed. Take what money would be spent on the studies and get in there and do some corrective work.'' ---= CHICAGO (AP) - The faithful who gathered at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church hoped it wouldn't be the last Christmas celebrated in the deteriorating church, one of the few buildings to survive the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. Parishioners need to raise $125,000 more by New Year's Eve to save the 130-year-old Victorian Gothic church, said Dick Barry, a spokesman for the Holy Family Preservation Society. ``We're going to make our goal,'' the Rev. George Lane said Monday. ``Our motto is `Say prayers and send money.''' The Society of Jesus, which owns the church, has threatened to tear it down and sell the property unless the parish can raise $1 million of a $3 million repair bill by the deadline.

DOC.HEAD: Editors Vote Gulf Crisis Top Story of 1990 By Overwhelming Margin
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the heart-stopping standoff that ensued in the Persian Gulf was by far the top news story of 1990, according to a poll of Associated Press news editors and broadcast news directors. The Gulf crisis received 2,506 points to finish well ahead of the news story that placed second, the reunification of Germany. That story got 1,460 points in voting by 327 editors and news directors. The No. 3 story also unfolded abroad - the economic and political reforms that have racked the Soviet Union. The first domestic story to make the list was the continuing savings and loan debacle, which finished fourth. Finishing fifth was the warming of relations between the two superpowers, followed by Congress' difficulties with the 1991 budget; America's economic downturn; developments in Eastern Europe; Panama President Manuel Noriega's surrender and preparations to prosecute him; and the end of the Margaret Thatcher era in Britain. The top 10 stories: 1. When Saddam Hussein's Iraqi troops overran the tiny emirate of Kuwait in the pre-dawn hours of Aug. 2, they set in motion a dizzying sequence of dangerous events: a United Nations-ordered embargo against Iraq; a buildup of American and other forces in the region; the taking of foreign hostages as human shields for Iraqi military sites, and their later release. By September's end, the price of oil reached $40 a barrel, nearly double what it had been before the invasion. On Nov. 29 the U.N. Security Council voted to give Iraq until Jan. 15 to pull out of Kuwait or face a possible military strike. The world is waiting. 2. East and West Germany became one nation again on Oct. 3, ending a division that began at the end of World War II. Reunification had been an impossible dream just a year before - but that was before East German protests for democratic freedoms at the end of 1989 brought down Berlin Wall, since 1961 the Cold War's most palpable symbol. Free elections were held in East Germany in the spring of 1990 and the communists were sent packing. The Soviet Union accepted NATO membership for the united Germany, removing the last serious obstacle. 3. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's ambitious program of economic and political reforms foundered in 1990. Although Gorbachev won a new five-year term as president and tightened his control over the Communist Party, his nation was torn apart by ethnic unrest, rebellious republics, disgruntled hardliners and shortages of bread, sugar, meat, cigarettes and other goods. 4. The S&L mess got messier in 1990, and the tab to U.S. taxpayers was revised upwards to $500 billion over 30 years. The $2 billion failure of Charles Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan, the biggest bailout yet, came to symbolize the troubles of hundreds of thrifts. Keating, who faces federal fraud charges accusing him of misleading investors on the safety of junk bonds, made $1.3 million in political contributions to five senators who intervened on his behalf with thrift regulators. The Senate Ethics Committee held hearings on the five: Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. A federal judge found the president's son Neil guilty of conflict of interest for failing to disclose business ties with developers in his role as director of the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. 5. Gorbachev may have faced mounting headaches at home, but relations with the United States were never warmer. Bush and Gorbachev, who won the Nobel Peace Prize for easing international tensions, met three times during the year. The first meeting was in Washington to sign chemical weapons agreements; the second was a one-day summit in Helsinki, Finland, to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. The third meeting was in Paris in November for the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Its highlight was the signing of a far-reaching conventional arms control agreement by leaders of North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and Warsaw Pact nations. 6. After five months of sometimes acrimonious negotiations, Congress and Bush cobbled together a 1991 budget package in October. In addition to spending cuts, the $250 billion deficit reduction package provided for tax increases, belying the president's most popular pledge: ``Read my lips - no new taxes.'' Republicans campaigning for re-election felt betrayed. 7. Bush said the nation's economy was in a ``serious slowdown,'' Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan used the phrase ``meaningful downturn,'' but virtually everybody else was calling what was happening in the last half of 1990 a recession. The statistics were mostly bad: November's unemployment rate jumped to a three-year high of 5.9 percent. Single-family housing starts fell to levels unmatched since the 1981-82 recession. The October trade deficit took an unexpected leap to $11.6 billion in October, the worst monthly trade gap in 2{ years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which had flirted with 3,000 in July, was some 400 points lower in December. In a bid to stimulate the economy, the Fed cut its discount rate - the interest it charges on loans to member banks - for the first time since 1986. 8. Soviet troops began pulling out of Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and East Germany after non-communist governments came to power in those nations for the first time since World War II. But economic difficulties and ethnic tensions, kept under wraps during communist rule, flared under looser regimes and threatened the fledgling democracies. In Poland, Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa was elected president in a landslide victory in December. Romanians clashed with Hungarians in disputed areas of Romania, and separatist demands threatened to dissolve Yugoslavia. In Albania, the last bastion of Stalinist rule, the government formally recognized the first opposition party in decades and scheduled elections for early 1991. The same week, more than 150 people were tried for anti-government acts after protesters burned and ransacked buildings in four provinces. 9. On Jan. 3, Panamanian President Manuel Noriega stepped out of the Vatican mission where he had taken refuge and surrendered to U.S. authorities. He was brought to Florida and charged with accepting $4.6 million in bribes to turn Panama into a way station for Colombian drug traffickers. Noriega had been scheduled to go to trial this January, but his attorneys recently told a federal judge they will not be ready for trial until June. 10. Margaret Thatcher, the Iron Lady who ruled Britain longer than anyone else this century, bowed out. In 11{ years as prime minister she dismantled Britain's version of socialism, crushed obstructive labor unions and led a military victory against Argentina in the Falkland Islands. However, her increasingly isolationist role in European Community policies and her deeply unpopular poll tax cost her the support of her Conservative Party. In November she was succeeded by her handpicked successor, John Major.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Comes to Television
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: On his deathbed at Georgetown Hospital, behind the closed door of room C6316, Central Intelligence Agency director William J. Casey whispered two words. Washington Post investigative legend Bob Woodward, according to his own account, was bent over the dying chief, asking if and why Casey had participated in the Iran-Contra scandal. ``I believed,'' Casey replied. So, too, apparently, did the executive producers of a new ABC series about the CIA called ``Under Cover,'' debuting Jan. 7. Belief in what, however - like Casey's cryptic answer - is not really clear. That CIA agents are not all evil spies plotting to overthrow banana republics in far-flung corners of the world? That, like John Q. Public, said agents are fathers, mothers, Little League supporters and also concerned about the office dental plan? That's part of it. Left to the imagination in the two-hour pilot of ``Under Cover'' is why its characters do what they do and if they truly believe in the agency they work for. Co-executive producer William Broyles Jr., former editor in chief of Newsweek, founding editor of Texas Monthly, Vietnam veteran and co-creator of ABC's ``China Beach,'' said the lead characters of ``Under Cover'' are ``trying to do the right thing in a sometimes difficult and unethical situation. ``These agents, like soldiers, are often the foot soldiers of agents and policies that they disagree with,'' Broyles said in a recent interview at his Warner Bros. office. The makers of ``Under Cover'' find themselves in a somewhat similar and awkward position. It is Broyles and John Sacret Young who created the new series, as well as ``China Beach.'' And it is ``China Beach'' that ``Under Cover'' is replacing. ``There's an irony in it that's certainly not lost on me,'' said Broyles. The acclaimed Vietnam War series ``China Beach'' is going on hiatus, the victim of three different time period changes in as many seasons and a drop in viewership. Whether ``China Beach'' will be renewed is doubtful. Young is equally doubtful about the success of ``Under Cover.'' ``I can't imagine that it will succeed,'' he said. The reason being its time period of 9 p.m. Saturdays, an hour not known for attracting huge numbers of network viewers. Many of those who do tune in are watching NBC's successful ``Golden Girls'' comedy series. Young calls ``Under Cover'' a program about ``how a man thinks he's doing a job and it's really affecting his life. What's happening is getting under the skin.'' International espionage will do that to a person. Especially when bullets, needles and torture are involved. ``You don't want to whitewash the CIA,'' Young said. ``You tread a fine line, which creates a horrible and horrid situation.'' Imagine the series' story meetings. What to do about the CIA's historic involvement in foreign affairs? Chile, for example. Fidel Castro. Mining Nicaraguan harbors. The troublesome problem of overthrowing foreign leaders deemed to be unfriendly. The story line of ``Under Cover'' concerns husband-and-wife spy team Dylan and Kate Del'Amico (Anthony John Denison and Linda Purl) who are anxious to put down roots, live in the suburbs, go to Little League games and otherwise live the American dream. Wife Kate soured on ``the company'' a while back and no longer spies. Husband Dylan, while professing his desire for an agency desk job, ends up in the Soviet Union on a mission to save glasnost and becomes part of a convoluted double-agent scenario that leaves certain members of the agency unsure of whether Dylan works for them or the KGB. Meanwhile, back at the agency, the yuppies are threatening to take over with their flyover satellite pictures and technology-driven spying. Dylan and Kate's boss, Stewart Merriman, runs around imparting words of wisdom such as ``We're the only thing between order and chaos'' and ``In our business, things are not always what they seem.'' He should try dropping in on ``Twin Peaks,'' the bizarre nighttime soap opera that follows ``Under Cover.'' Over there, they've got this gaunt-looking giant who appears in visions and says ``The owls are not what they seem.'' --- Elsewhere in television... TV AND JUST SAY NO: The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences has arranged for 15 public service announcements denouncing substance abuse to be broadcast nationwide in 1991. The spots represent prize winners in the academy's annual Campaign Against Substance Abuse Film-Video College Competition.

DOC.HEAD: Proving That People Will Put Up With a Lot for a Bargain
DOC.TEXT: In increasing numbers, American consumers are shunning the glittery malls and choosing to shop in huge, drab buildings where service is almost a missing element. But prices are lower in warehouse purchasing clubs. The stocks are huge. And the economy is in the doldrums. The combination is proving irresistible; people will put up with a lot for a bargain. So many people are willing to pay the $25 membership fee that entitles them to go to the warehouse clubs and purchase everything from luggage to lettuce in a single trip. ``The service isn't great,'' says Marlene Green of Randallstown, Md., interviewed during a shopping trip in a warehouse club outside of Washington, ``but I've shopped at the warehouse for so long. I'm a veteran. I generally know where everything is and once you can figure that out. it's easy. ``The prices are so low, that I'm willing to trade service to save money.'' Charles Steinbreuck, president and chief executive officer of the Pace Membership Warehouse chain based in Englewood, Colo., says one reason for the success of the format is that consumers are tired of paying ``hidden costs'' of dealing with major retailers. ``Lower overhead costs and not having to pay for mass media advertising campaigns allows (us) competitive advantages over traditional retailers,'' he says. ``By doing direct mailings to our individual members and the small businesses we serve, there's no need to pass along to consumers the costs of trying to appeal to the masses.'' Gerry Warren of Piscataway, Md., who joined Pace in 1985, says he sees the difference in the nearly wholesale prices offered by the warehouses as compared to shopping at grocery store chains. ``This really surprised me ... the quality of the merchandise offered by the warehouse. I thought it was going to be one of those deals where cheap stuff is just marked down to get rid of it,'' he says. ``But I can tell you, the quality is as good or better than I can get (elsewhere) and it's saved me a lot of money in the past five years.'' Sandra Shaber, an economist with The Futures Group in Washington, says when the nation's economy goes into a decline, no matter how brief, consumers go where they can get the most for their money. ``When the economy gets soft, usually consumers are willing to trade down in price, as long as there's not much of a drop in quality,'' Ms. Shaber says. ``You can't just be cheap, you have to have something of value to offer. You have to have popular products available, the warehouse has to have a neat, professional appearance and it has to be convenient,'' she said. Sonyia Soper, a shopper at the Pace warehouse in Laurel, Md., says she first shopped at the outlet last year and now makes the majority of her purchases there. ``The prices are the main inducement. ... I can buy more for less money than going around the corner to Laurel Centre Mall. They have to pay for all of the glitz associated with being in a mall, and who gets stuck with the bill, you (shoppers) do,'' she says. Pace opened its first warehouse store in Denver in 1983 and currently has 62 outlets nationwide. It has 3 million members, who are charged $25 annually, and serves about 800,000 small businesses. The company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Kmart Corp., will do a projected $2.5 bilion in sales this year. Pace and the San Diego, Calif.-based Price Club, whose membership dues are also $25 a year, are the front-runners in the effort to capture dollars that are usually spent at supermarkets, department stores and specialty shops. The popularity of the warehouse stores, which started in the West, is rapidly spreading to the heavily industrialized Northeast. Ms. Shaber says since that is where the nationwide economic slowdown is being most severely felt, warehouse stores are targeting the region for growth. ``Whenever and wherever money gets tight, consumers look for an alternative to mainstream markets for goods and services,'' she says. ``We're seeing the backlash from the early 1980s when brand names were so strong that they squeezed out generic brands from the marketplace. That cycle has run its course and people now want more purchasing power for their money.'' Sales at the warehouse clubs have increased substantially in the past six years. Prices are usually 20 percent to 40 percent below what is charged by traditional retailers. Costs are lower because of the size of the stores, usually about 100,000 square feet, because they do not permit credit card purchases and they offer minimal customer assistance. Steinbreuck says the economic downturn is a factor in the recent popularity of the warehouse stores. Another is their convenience. ``We sell food - fresh and frozen and meats. We sell electronic equipment and appliances. we sell automotive supplies. We offer something that most retailers lack - the ability to offer several different categories of merchandise in one location, which means that our customers can shop at their leisure and save gasoline.''

DOC.HEAD: Turning Supply and Demand On Its Head
DOC.TEXT: Some people who claim to know how free markets work are doing things that make you wonder, such as raising their rates in an attempt to offset declines in business. Basic economics texts say that to do so is the road to ruin, but don't try telling that to bankers and many other financial institutions executives who already have decided to put the theory through another test. They wouldn't be the first to try. For years, automobile companies tried to cover higher costs by higher prices, only to be forced by lagging sales into rebating some of the increases. The steel industry tried it before them. The Wall Street Journal recently suggested that higher costs were behind its 50 percent price increase, drawing from Fortune Magazine a commentary on the importance of reading the Journal's own free-market editorials. But the Journal isn't the only publication by a long shot that is taking the higher price course. It's happening throughout the country. With business falling, you might think that financial institutions might consider lowering some fees for services, but throughout the industry there are plans to raise them instead. Citibank raised several fees 25 percent or more. Savings institutions are working their way through an absolute financial debacle, one that has swallowed up hundreds of outlets and scared away customers of many who survive. But they too are doing it. ``Instituting or increasing fees for services can better define relationships with customers,'' according to ``Savings Institutions,'' published for members of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions. According to an article, to boost fee income ``adds up in dollars - and sense.'' Traditional fees involve services such as safe-deposit boxes, checks returned for insufficient funds, stop-payment requests, money transfers ... Fees for many of these are sure to go up, but it is likely that some not-so-common fees also will head in that direction. In addition, you may find that local branch managers will less apt to waive fees. That latter practice, says Michael Wilson, a researcher for the league, is often a key factor in the poor performance of some branches. In the new thinking, imposition of the fees may rid the branch of unprofitable customers. The ``Savings Institutions'' article describes what it indicates is a highly profitable money-raiser used by one bank: it circulates a magazine to big-balance customers and sells advertising in it. That's not all. More important, it says, is ``the real gravy,'' which comes in the form of commissions paid by a travel agency on every cruise advertised in the magazine and booked by a bank customer. Will such practices work? Theoretically, they aren't likely to succeed over a long period of time if customers feel the services offered aren't worth the price or are available at a better price from a competing institution. However, in a crisis - and that is how many in the business view their condition - they may help an institution to survive. Securities brokers did it, you may recall, and they survived for a while. But with institutional business declining, many are rethinking policies and seeking to attract individuals. One of the key questions, of course, is whether the institutions will offer improved services, or simply try to squeeze more money out of the existing level of service, or perhaps even allow it to decline. Customers reaction will have something to say about it too. Will customers better appreciate the services offered when they have to pay for them? Or, as could very well happen, will they tend to feel exploited? If you continue to believe that the laws of the market place, of supply and demand, haven't been rescinded, then you must still believe the practices may be a short-term phenomenon, and that price competition will return.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Tercel: Upgraded From Basic Econobox
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The 1991 Toyota Tercel 2-door Deluxe is not your basic econobox. It has a remarkaby smooth-shifting five-speed manual transmission. It has contemporary, rounded exterior styling and clean, modern interior. And it doesn't have a hatchback sibling. For 1991, Toyota eliminated the hatchback design that's standard fare at the low end of the car market and decided to offer the Tercel in upscale, 2-and 4-door sedan models that have trunks. ``We want to keep Toyota buyers for the long haul, so we don't punish them in their first experience with us,'' said Bob McCurry, Toyota executive vice president. The Tercel's starting price of $6,488 also is noteworthy. It's unchanged from the previous model year and makes the new Tercel the lowest price car with a trunk in America. It compares with the $6,995 Honda Civic 3-door, the $7,999 Nissan Sentra and the $6,597 Daihatsu Charade 3-door. The AP's test Tercel, a 2-door with a base price of $7,798, performed well. It wasn't a barn burner, what with its 1.5-liter, in-line, 12-valve, four-cylinder engine capable of producing 82 horsepower at 5,200 rpm. I also had to really push the clutch to the floor so the key would activate the ignition. But the car does accelerate faster than the previous Tercel model, and the fuel economy of 29 miles per gallon in the city and 35 mpg on the highway was appreciated. It was a pleasure, too, to note the fine mating of the transmission with the engine. I rarely felt a jerk as I shifted gears. There was some road noise but not as much as might be expected. Toyota added extra sound-deadening material that's also used on the Camry and worked to minimize vibration. The car's suspension - MacPherson strut in front and a torsion beam in back - was decent and took bumps and turns quite well. Fit and finish were superb. Toyota has reduced the size of body panel gaps on the exterior. The interior was Spartan, though not necessarily cheap-looking. Ventilation ducts were modern and round and could be turned easily and directed for maximum effect. Gauges were large and easy to read. As expected, the car's equipment was basic. The vehicle did not have power windows, power locks, a clock, tilt steering or a remote trunk lid release, and the rear windows do not open. The trunk floor had a vinyl cover, but there was nothing to cover the bare metal on the interior trunk sides. The floor mats were a $55 option, and power steering - a real help in tight turns in parking lots - cost $250. The car had seat belts for five, but the middle person in back sits up quite high on an awkward, though cushioned, resting spot. I was glad to see that legroom in back was OK if the front seats are up a ways, but my knees were pushed into the seatbacks when the seats were all the way back on their tracks. Toyota said the new Tercel has 9 percent more interior space than its predecessor, with an average of 1 inch added to each interior dimension. The automaker looks to sell 130,000 of the 1991 Tercels, which were introduced in November. That would be up from approximately 100,000 for the 1990 model Tercel. The Tercel has been in the United States since 1980 and has averaged about 100,000 sales a year, spokesman Jim Fewel said. Tercel buyers traditionally have been young, single and female. Seventy percent of Tercel buyers are women, with a median age of 31, Fewel said. Thirty-five percent are married, and 54 percent are college graduates. Median income is in the upper $20,000s, he said. With the exception of the 1987 model, Tercels have ranked better than average or much better than average since the 1984 model year, according to Consumer Reports magazine's trouble reports from owners. The 1987 Tercel ranked average.

DOC.HEAD: Robertson, Calling Believers Into Politics, Sees Threat to Israel
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Christian broadcaster Pat Robertson, now off the campaign trail but still plugging for believers' engagement with political issues, worries the Persian Gulf crisis could be turned against Israel. He says Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein ``has set the machinery in motion'' by which a world military alliance and Arab nations eventually might ``isolate Israel and spark cataclysmic events.'' If tha happens, it would bring ``some heavenly intervention to protect Israel,'' Robertson said in an interview. ``Certainly events are marching in that direction and very rapidly.'' He doesn't offer any timetable or specific scenario for such convulsions, as do some end-of-time sifters of biblical clues. But as a firm backer of Israel's nationhood, he does see hints of it in the present turmoil. Robertson, in a wide-ranging conversation, also foresaw a sharpening ``struggle for the pinacles of power'' in this country - in government, the courts, schools and news media - and predicted religious values would regain ascendancy. ``It's a multifaceted struggle, but the people of faith are going to prevail,'' he said. ``A profound spiritual awakening is coming in this country in this decade.'' He elaborates his views in a new book, ``The New Millennium,'' published by Word Publishing of Irving, Texas, and it foresees a conflict between secularism and Judeo-Christian standards. Similar themes threaded his unsuccessful 1988 campaign for the Republican presidential nomination and he said that campaign accomplished a goal even though he didn't win. ``My main purpose was not to see me elected, but to get Christians involved in the public arena and in politics. And they're in there,'' he said. ``I found there is an enormous reservoir of pro-family, pro-Christian values in this country. These people are in it for the long haul. ... Within the next 10 years they may be the most powerful political force in America. Robertson, 60, is back as president of his financially rebounded Christian Broadcasting Network and chancellor of its affiliated graduate school, Regent University at Virginia Beach, Va. He brushes aside the idea of another presidential bid. Chuckling, he said, ``I'm so glad that Bush got handed the deficit, the savings-and-loan crisis and the Middle East, I don't know what to do.'' He said he has ``no plans whatever'' to run again. But earlier this year, he set up a national voter-education organization, the Christian Coalition, to alert grass-roots supporters to issues. It has about 50,000 participants so far, he said. ``They're going to make a big contribution. They're capable, intelligent, and make tremendous political operatives when they care to do so. It'll be for the good of the country.'' In his book, he predicts that in this decade, a ``fierce, intense and sometimes ugly battle is going to be waged to seize the control points of society away from the forces of anti-Christian secularism.'' ``After a period of intense struggle, the believers will stand firmly astride the fallen and crumbling ruins of the secular colossus,'' he says. He also predicts that ``we are entering the age of the supernatural,'' a colliding amalgam of all sorts of cults, esoteric ``lords and masters,'' ``New Age counterfeits,'' followers of the occult and even Satanism. But, he says, these will be countered by a ``groundswell of Christian renewal all over the world'' that will reverse smothering, irreligious secularism. He sharply criticizes the courts, saying they have ``legislated Judeo-Christian values out of American life,'' and the educational system, saying it has caused the ``dumbing of America.'' ``Generations have been so well trained to be so open minded, their minds are essentially empty,'' he writes. Anti-religious attitudes dominate the movies, television and print media, he says. But like communism, he says, ``secular humanism has failed . ... It is a bankrupt system, without moral guidelines or reliable safeguards to protect the people from its own corruptions.'' Robertson stressed similar points in the interview. He said the religious non-establishment clause in the constitution ``has been used for the establishment of everything else,'' chiefly ``a secularistic religion'' that excludes Judeo-Christianity. He blames the abandonment of America's religious roots for the most serious problems of the country - drug abuse, crime, child abuse, wife battering, the deficit and financial scandals. ``It's like taking the foundation from under a skyscraper. The whole thing comes tumbling down,'' he said. Robertson, relaxed, warm, with his ready smile, keeps in shape jogging, playing tennis and horseback riding. A one-time Golden Gloves boxer, he took time out this fall at the invitation of boxer Evander Holyfield to see him win the world's heavyweight boxing championship in Las Vegas. He's kept busy administering operations with revenues of $90 million a year, $70 million of it in donations (up from a low of $58 million in 1988) and more than 1,100 employees. He also is host of CBN's centerpiece, 90-minute talk show, ``The 700 Club,'' which is carried on 223 TV stations and cable systems reaching 52 million households. ``People are saying let's get back to our roots,'' he said. ``We've got to get back to our Judeo-Christian principles and restore the values that we've given up. Then we've got to roll up our sleeves and go to work to start rebuilding this country and the world.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri AMs, Dec. 28

DOC.HEAD: Betty Carter, Still on the Road After Four Decades
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Betty Carter has been bopping around as a jazz singer for 42 years, but she isn't tired of it. ``Performing live brings something out of you that the recording studio doesn't,'' she says. In fact, her new album, ``Droppin' Things,'' on Verve Records, was recorded live at the Bottom Line here on two nights in May. Her last album, ``Look What I Got!'', won a Grammy Award for best female jazz vocal performance in 1988. Carter, 60, feels it's important for a singer to work with new material and not get locked into an unchanging repertoire. ```Why Him' is an Alan Jay Lerner song I heard when they were giving him a tribute on TV. I decided to find the lyrics and do the song,'' she said of her new album. ```Thirty Years' is a brand-new song. `Droppin' Things' is very new. `Open the Door' I recorded before but never like this.'' She wrote those three. One of the tracks on the album is ``Star Dust,'' combined with ``Memories of You.'' But, Carter said, ``I never sang `Star Dust' before. I only sang `Memories' once or twice.'' Carter is known for daring improvisations and unusual approaches to songs. ``The more you do a song the more you learn about the tune and your concept of the tune. Then I'm free; then I just go any way I want to go and can go with it musically,'' she said. But she decided not to play around too much on the new album. ``At least you can recognize it,'' she said. ``Most people want to recognize `Star Dust.''' Carter is backed up by Marc Cary on piano, Duane Burno on bass and Gregory Hutchinson on drums. ``They're 20, 20 and 23,'' she said. ``My musicians are getting younger and younger. Maybe 15 years ago I had a hard time finding musicians. Now there are a lot of them out there who want to play acoustic instruments and work with me.'' They went to Japan in October, returned for some American gigs in November and probably will spend much of next year in Europe. ``I love performing. I know how spontaneous it is for me to do my work. Working keeps me alive,'' Carter said. A snatch of conversation overheard on the radio led her to rework the lyrics for ``Jumps,'' a song she wrote 12 years ago. Her trio liked ``Jumps,'' so when they went to Europe in March, she worked on more lyrics. ``The music was very abstract,'' she said. ``Once these young kids showed me their enthusiasm for the tune, I said OK, I'm going to develop it. I'd tried it with other musicians; they shrugged their shoulders. I find these kids, younger than my two sons, will try anything. ``I start doodling at the piano in front of my trio. If they say, `What's that?', I know it's time to develop the tune. I ask them for their input also. It makes them part of the material, which keeps it young and different.'' Carter credits Wynton Marsalis with ``inspiring a lot of young players to come out and take a chance. '' She said young performers are increasingly turning to material ``I thought I never would hear again, old Thelonious Monk, Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie tunes.'' But Carter doesn't want to keep listening to those re-creations. ``I keep telling them, learn all the songs we played in those days, know all the changes, lock it up in the brain and go for something else. Sit and learn all the standards. They're interesting. It's very educational to learn the blues in all kinds of keys. Learn how to transpose. ``Don't listen too long to some one artist. Get in the habit of being creative early, for the rest of your life. You could come up with something different than anyone has ever done. It could happen. There are 88 keys and all kinds of changes to experiment with. A voice can do a lot of wonderful things. ``Only time is going to make young musicians understand what I'm talking about. I wouldn't pay anybody any attention either in my young age. At least they get some information in the very beginning. Some that don't take advantage of it instantly will catch it later.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs AMs, Jan. 3

DOC.HEAD: Bush Has 119 Federal Judgeships to Fill
DOC.TEXT: In his first opinion as a federal appeals judge, A. Raymond Randolph ruled against the administration that had just chosen him. A conservative Washington attorney nominated to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals by President Bush earlier this year, Randolph rejected an administration argument that a board set up to regulate government nuclear weapons plants could meet secretly despite the Freedom of Information Act. His stinging opinion issued in October was joined by two conservative appointees of President Reagan - James L. Buckley and Douglas H. Ginsburg. Between them, Bush and Reagan have appointed more than 500 federal judges over the past decade. There are 34 vacancies now, and Bush recently signed a law creating 85 new judgeships around the country, bringing the total number of federal trial and appeals judges to 828. Those appointments have established the dominance of conservatives on the federal bench. But as the Randolph ruling illustrates, judges, named for life, are independent of the administrations that send them to the bench. And legal scholars say the impact of ideology is overstated by lobbying groups involved in Senate confirmation proceedings on federal district and circuit court judges. ``The fact of the matter is there isn't much leeway on the part of courts below the Supreme Court,'' said Philip B. Kurland, a constitutional law professor at the University of Chicago. ``The troops follow the direction of the commanding officers. They go where they are told to and there are few mutineers in their ranks.'' ``There has been a great deal of oversimplification and hype around this selection process and its impact,'' said Sheldon Goldman, a University of Massachusetts political scientist who studies federal courts. ``The impact is there but it is much more subtle than folks think or would like us to believe.'' Civil rights organizations and liberal advocacy groups have accused both Reagan and Bush of pursuing a long-range strategy to ``pack'' the federal courts with conservative ideologues. During the Reagan administration, liberal opposition was a factor in the withdrawal of eight nominees to the federal bench and the rejection by the Senate Judiciary Committee of three others. The confirmation battles culminated in the Democrat-controlled Senate's rejection 1987 of Robert Bork, an outspoken conservative, for a seat on the Supreme Court. So far, Bush's judicial nominees have enjoyed smoother sailing in the Senate. The Bush administration has tried to ``lower the thermostat in terms of the selection process,'' Goldman said. Reagan appointed a number of conservative theorists, such as law professors Richard Posner, Frank Easterbrook and Stephen Williams. Bush has generally appointed practicing lawyers with establishment Republican credentials. Under Bush ``there certainly isn't that effort to find professors whose judicial philosophies are carefully carved out, there isn't that zealousness ... in trying to fit all their candidates through this very narrow prism,'' said Melanne Verveer, executive vice president of liberal group People for the American Way. Bush's nominees ``bear an unmistakable conservative stamp but they are not necessarily of an ideological flavor,'' said A.E. ``Dick'' Howard, a University of Virginia law professor. They are ``people who are by and large of conservative temperament but whose background is not markedly political.'' So far, no Bush nominee has been rejected by the Judiciary Committee, but controversy looms next year. The committee took no action for seven months on Bush's nomination of Kenneth Ryskamp, a Miami federal judge accused of being hostile to civil rights, to a seat on the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals. The nomination died when Congress adjourned. But Ryskamp is expected to be renominated next year when lawmakers reconvene. His membership in a private country club reputed to have once excluded blacks and Jews, and his pronouncements from the district bench, could trigger the first Senate confirmation fight over a Bush judicial nominee. People for the American Way has noted in mailings to its members that Ryskamp ruled against the plaintiffs in all but four of 41 cases involving civil and constitutional rights that came before him. Nine of Ryskamp's civil rights rulings were reversed by the appellate court to which he was nominated. Critics also point to a case in which the judge told some black teen-agers who had been attacked by police dgs that ``it might not be inappropriate to carry around a few scars to remind you or your wrongdoing in the past.'' A renewed Ryskamp nomination could end two years of relative peace between the Democratic Senate and the Republican White House on judicial nominees. End Adv AMs Fri Dec. 28

DOC.NOTE: $Adv05
$Adv06
For release Weekend Editions, Jan. 5-6, and thereafter ^Another Televised War Possible In Persian Gulf Crisis ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: The blue plastic bubbles atop Saudi Arabia's Dhahran International Hotel symbolize all that has changed in TV's coverage of war. The bubbles house satellite uplink facilities, and they now transmit reports on U.S. and other troops training for a possible war with Iraq. Should that war begin, the uplinks would transmit TV's taped combat coverage - faster and in greater quantities than ever before in a large-scale conflict. And that coverage, for the first time, would be watched on both sides of the battlefront. Cable News Network's coverage of U.S. and allied troops can be seen on a same-day basis both in Baghdad and in Washington. How much will be seen is anyone's guess, even though Pentagon officials say there'll be no censorship at the transmission site in Dhahran. Because for all the new and flashy technology, at least one thing is expected to remain the same in a Persian Gulf war - the friction between the military and the media. If fighting erupts, ABC anchorman Peter Jennings thinks U.S. military officials ``will prevent us from seeing it as best they can,'' although he admits that he doesn't know what really will happen if the shooting starts: ``I don't know what the bottom line is ... but it's an extremely simple environment in which to control the press.'' Although details still are being worked out, there initially would be print and broadcast pool coverage of any hostilities, with a ``security review'' of outgoing material to see if it violates ground rules of coverage. Even though the Pentagon says there'll be no censorship, it's unclear what will happen if the security review causes a dispute over a given report and what, if anything, will happen to the reporter if the story is sent. ``If you agree to the ground rules, you would not expect, if you violate them, to have access to the U.S. military resources,'' says Robert Hall, a senior Pentagon spokesman. He refuses to specifically say if a violator would be barred from accompanying U.S. troops, but ``we are confident that there is not a problem with reporters understanding what the purpose of the ground rules is.'' ``We are not going to let people compromise the safety of the troops,'' he says. ``That's the bottom line. I can't speculate on what would happen if people did. But we are not going to allow that.'' Print and TV reporters in Vietnam, while also subject to ground rules regarding tactical information, such as planned operations, had a great deal of access toU.S. operations. American viewers saw an uncensored war. But fast TV coverage wasn't common. Satellite transmission was in its infancy and and rarely used because of cost. Field reports - on film then, not videotape - usually aired several days after the fact. But satellites got a heavy workout 23 years ago this month as U.S. networks showed the bloody scenes of the communist Tet offensive in Vietnam. NBC showed the first footage, shots of fighting at the U.S. Embassy in Saigon, airing it raw and unedited on ``The Huntley-Brinkley Report.'' Even with satellites, NBC's footage was almost a day old. It had to be flown from Saigon to Tokyo, processed there, and then sent via satellite to the United States. It arrived 10 minutes before the show began at 6:30 p.m. EST. Despite today's swift TV coverage, network officials say that if war starts after - or before - the Jan. 15 deadline the United Nations has given Irag to get out of Kuwait, it's unlikely there'd be live battlefield coverage. The uplink gear isn't mobile enough. It also can make a nice target. ``You never say never in this business,'' says Ed Turner, CNN's executive vice president for newsgathering. ``But it (live coverage) is highly unlikely at this point because the gear, while portable, ain't that portable. ``You still need to set up an uplink and it takes a couple of hours to assemble. And if you're out where shells are falling. .. .'' Print and broadcast reporters must sign up in Dhahran, in the same hotel where the TV satellite farm is located, at the Joint Information Bureau - nicknamed ``The Jib.'' The bureau's director is U.S. Army Col. William Mulvey. The number of print and broadcast journalists registered there fluctuates daily, but it has almost grown to Vietnam size: 450, when when President Bush visited U.S. troops at Thankgiving; nearly 360 later in December. Of that total, 110 were from ABC, CBS, CNN and NBC. Although there's no censorship, reporters must abide by military ground rules concerning tactical operations, unit locations and strength. And Mulvey says he has warned potential pool reporters that he won't let anyone go out with the troops ``who's not in good physical condition. ... I don't want the safety of any of our troops jeopardized by a journalist who can't keep up.'' What concerns network officials far more is how much access their crews will have to the troops in the field when and if fighting begins, and how quickly the military will get the reports back for satellite transmission. Military escorts - some of them renowned as spin doctors in uniform - now accompany reporters on organized trips to various U.S. units. The reporters have to sign up for the trips and are taken on a first-come, first-served basis, though more than one public affairs officer has privately admitted that TV gets precedence. It is clear that swarms of reporters will not be out there wandering unescorted on the battlefield. As CNN's Turner notes, in the initial stages, ``we'll go and only be able to show what the military will permit the pool to show - not unlike World War II.'' ``What the military does is that they pre-censor - they don't take you to areas where they don't want you,'' says Ed Fouhy. Reporters used to accompany Fouhy when he was a Marine captain in charge of a rifle company patrolling the Damascus-Beirut highway during an earlier Middle East crisis - the Lebanon crisis of 1958. He later became a network news producer and executive, and at one point was CBS' bureau chief in Saigon. Now a free-lance TV producer in Washington Fouhy thinks restrictions will be tight in the early stages of a Persian Gulf ar. ``And it'll it'll be difficult for the press corps to get a real grip on what's happening, because it'll be so fast. A lot of it will be air war, and a lot will be at night,'' he says. He also predicts that U.S. military escorts for the press ``will not be particularly cooperative in the early going ... they'll be uptight. But I think things will loosen up, assuming that the U.S. is successful.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Jay Sharbutt covered the Vietnam War for The Associated Press in 1969-70.
