DOC.HEAD: Commission Report Asks Hard Look at Rural America
DOC.TEXT: A presidential panel on rural development says in its final report that future planners should keep in mind that there are many perceptions of rural America and its people, including some that are not very accurate. The 15-member National Commission on Agriculture and Rural Development Policy said that ``definitions of rural America abound'' and that what appears to be rural in one part of the nation may seem pretty citified in another. But the commission, which was authorized in the expiring 1985 farm law, shied away from offering a single definition of rural. The chairman of the commission is Charles ``Pete'' Knigge, a dairy and grain farmer from Omro, Wis. Other members, representing diverse interests and regions, include other farmers and officials of agricultural organizations, representatives of agricultural industries and financial institutions, public office holders and educators. The massive 1990 farm law includes a rural development package, along with a provision that creates a new Rural Development Administration within the Agriculture Department. Many of the existing development programs in the Farmers Home Administration, for example, would be transferred to the new agency. The commission's report, which was sent to President Bush earlier this month, put the formation of a national rural development policy at the top of the agenda. No giant federal spending programs were recommended. Federal advice, expertise and other such help should be available, but rural people will have to settle their own problems. The term rural America has come to include ``farms and forested areas, mining and manufacturing areas, isolated small towns, and places under the growing influence of nearby urban centers,'' the report said. However, it added, if policy is to effectively address rural needs, there must be a clear understanding of the character of rural America. ``Popular beliefs about rural America are based on many perceptions,'' the report said. ``Some, if once true, no longer are. These misperceptions mayobscure true conditions in rural areas and divert policies in directions that are inappropriate to modern rural needs.'' The commission listed five major points to help ``confront and refute'' misperceptions relating to rural development policy. The facts, based on the report, include: -Most rural Americans no longer depend mainly on farming for their jobs and income. Agriculture is one of the nation's biggest industries and is the source of food and fiber for domestic and export consumption. In many states and rural areas, agriculture is the leading source of basic income in the economy. But less than 10 percent of the rural work force is directly employed in farming. In most rural areas, other industries, especially manufacturing and services, have eclipsed farming as a primary source of livelihood. -Rural America is more than small-town, farm-centered Midwestern communities. The national perception of ``rural'' is heavily influenced by images of small-town America, popularized in films and television, where the simple life persists. The largest numbers of rural Americans live in the South, where they are more likely to work at manufacturing jobs than in farming, and in the Midwest, where much of the nation's food production occurs. Still others call Western and New England communities home. Far from being monopolized by farm trade centers, rural America is made up of a diverse array of fishing villages in coastal areas, mining towns in Appalachia and the West, mill towns in the Southeast, and tourist centers near national parks and natural attractions. Each of these communities faces different challenges. -Not all of rural America is losing population. During the mid-1980s, more rural counties lost population than grew. Over the entire decade, more people moved out of rural America than moved into it. But these totals obscure the rapid growth that sometimes occurs in many parts of rural America. In areas that have ``high-quality natural amenities'' such as coastline, mountains or a warm climate, large numbers of retirees and vacationers have made them among the fastest growing areas in the nation. -Both growing and declining rural areas face difficult problems. Population losses cause strains for communities trying to provide basic services. Sometimes this threatens their survival as social and economic units. Growing communities, whose expanding populations bring new tax dollars and vitality, do not suffer from declining services and property values. But growth, especially if it's rapid, creates other problems, including new residents with values and expectations that differ from those of existing residents. Rapid growth can also put pressure on community services and institutions to keep pace with rising demands; rising property assessments that challenge low-income residents to meet growing tax obligations; and the prospect that new job opportunities may go to new residents, leaving few benefits for longtime citizens. -Many rural residents live in poverty. One in seven rural Americans, mostly in the South, have incomes below the official government poverty level of $12,675 a year for a family of four. The rural poor are likely to be ``working poor'' people with jobs. Many families have two or more full-time workers whose wages are too low even to yield a poverty-level income. The report added: ``Concentrated in minority groups, the poor live in areas that have been bypassed by economic growth, leaving them few alternatives to the meager jobs they hold. ``Their inability to afford proper health care results in disabilities that limit their ability to perform the manual labor jobs on which they often depend. Their poor schools provide them with educations inadequate to qualify them for better paying jobs.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Again, Stocks Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The dollar today rose against the Japanese yen for the fifth consecutive trading day, and Tokyo share prices rebounded after a three-day fall. Holiday season trading was sluggish on both markets. The dollar closed at 136.25 yen, up 0.30 yen from Tuesday's close of 135.95 yen. It opened at 136.05 yen and ranged between 136.05 yen and 136.35 yen. The dollar now has gained 3.22 yen in the last five trading days. Spot trading today totaled $2.9 billion, up from Tuesday's $2.3 billion. Currency dealers forecast little change for the rest of the year, barring major developments in the Middle East or the Soviet Union. North American and European financial markets were closed Tuesday for Christmas, and markets were closed in London today. ``The dollar is moving at around the 136-yen mark and is likely to stay there for a while,'' said a dealer with Daiichi Kangyo Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A sense of political instability after Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation last week has been pushing the dollar up. Continuing tensions in the Middle East also have enhanced the dollar's appeal to investors seeking a safe haven during international uncertainty. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,887.56 points, up 119.68 points, or 0.50 percent, from Tuesday's finish. The average had fallen a total of 1,108.90 points in the previous three trading days. Dealers said today's trading was extremely thin, with volume on the first section estimated at 220 million shares, up slightly from Tuesday's 210 million. Buying picked up slightly in the afternoon on local newspaper reports on the Gulf Cooperation Council summit in Doha, Qatar, that encouraged hopes of a peaceful resolution in the Middle East. Investors are waiting to see which way currencies move when overseas markets open after the Christmas holidays, Toshiyuki Nishiguchi of Daiwa Securities said. A stronger yen generally helps boost the Nikkei average. They also are waiting for a number of events early next year, including a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations and the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, said Yoshiro Inoue, a researcher at Nomura Securities. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.96 points from Tuesday's close of 87.36. Their yield fell to 7.080 percent from 7.210 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda to Cut Executives' Salaries 5 to 10 Percent in Recall Case
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Corp. of Japan said Wednesday it would cut the salaries of its chairman and 17 other top executives by up to 10 percent for three months in connection with a recall of nearly 3,500 cars. The pay cuts for chairman Kenichi Yamamoto and the other executives were decided one day after the Transport Ministry warned Mazda to pay stricter attention to the safety of its cars, said a Mazda official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The cuts, which range from 5 percent to 10 percent, will last for the first quarter of 1991, the official said. The ministry has investigated charges that Mazda has been replacing defective parts during routine maintenance without recalling the cars or notifying the government. After the warning, Madza notified the ministry Tuesday that it would recall 3,498 Luce model passenger cars produced between Aug. 8, 1986, and Jan. 31, 1987, because of switch defects in their stop lights and cruise control mechanisms. Because of the defective switches, stop lights may not work even if the driver hits the brakes and the cruise control may not turn off quickly. Of the cars to be recalled, 134 were exported to Middle Eastern countries, Mazda said. The others were sold in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Lead Most Grain Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher early in today's session on the Chicago Board of Trade, led by a modest rally in soybeans. Wheat and oat futures were slightly higher in early trading; corn was narrowly mixed. With little news on the supply-and-demand front this morning, the strength mainly reflected follow-through buying after Monday's late rally, said Anne Frick, oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Near-term soybeans rebounded to close nearly unchanged Monday after hitting life-of-contract lows early in the session. Wheat futures also rose in late trading Monday. The markets were closed Tuesday. In early trading today, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with March at $2.65\ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to } cent higher with March at $2.33} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $1.13{ a bushel; soybeans were 2} cents to 3} cents higher with January at $5.65\ a bushel. Cattle futures were higher while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. DOC.HEAD: Year's Company Entertainment Expenses Totaled $36.5 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Japanese corporate executives wined, dined and golfed their way to a record 4.98 trillion yen or about $36.5 billion in expense account spending between February 1989 and January 1990, a tax agency report said Wednesday. The annual report compiled by the National Tax Administration Agency said the figure was 9.4 percent bigger than the previous year's, which had been the record. Company expense account spending is tax-deductible in Japan. The agency said it arrived at the figure by analyzing reports from 59,772 of a total of 1,962,026 enterprises. Meanwhile, retained earnings during the period totaled 18.14 trillion yen or about $133.17 billion, up 2.72 trillion yen or 17.6 percent from the previous period, it said. They accounted for 36.6 percent of total profits, it added. Retained earnings are calculated by deducting taxes, dividends and bonuses from total profits.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Still Waiting Bridge Loan Offer From TWA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Pan Am chairman's name to Plaskett in 9th graf
DOC.TEXT: Merger talks between Pan Am Corp. and Trans World Airlines Inc. were on hold today after TWA Chairman Carl Icahn accused Pan Am of showing a ``lack of good faith.'' Pan Am and TWA negotiated through the weekend and into Monday over whether TWA would lend Pan Am enough money to keep it operating until the struggling carriers can merge. TWA spokesman Don Morrison said Pan Am's representatives canceled a Monday meeting to discuss the offer and no talks were held Tuesday. Pan Am spokesman Jeff Kreindler denied Tuesday that talks had broken off. He said ``the next step is for Mr. Icahn to submit a definitive offer'' to the company. ``We also indicated there would have to be bridge financing until the deal could close,'' he said. Pan Am on Friday accepted Icahn's buyout offer of $1.50 in cash and about $1 in preferred stock or notes for each of Pan Am's 150 million outstanding shares, as long as TWA made the loan. The deal would value the airline at about $375 million. Icahn launched his offer for Pan Am as he announced plans to sell all of TWA's London routes and some other assets to a healthier rival, American Airlines, in a package worth $625 million. Icahn has sought assurances that Pan Am could repay the loan, estimated at as much as $100 million. Icahn has proposed forwarding Pan Am ``debtor-in-possession'' financing that would put TWA first in line for repaymen t during a Pan Am bankruptcy reorganization. In a Monday letter to Pan Am Corp. Chairman Thomas Plaskett, Icahn wrote: ``The conflicting attitudes and signals that we have received from you and your other representatives cause us to wonder whether you are serious when you say that you believe that a combination of Pan Am and TWA `would be advantageous to our shareholders, employees and other constituencies.''' Icahn also wrote that he was amazed Pan Am sold its London routes to United Airlines on Oct. 23. ``For Pan Am to sell assets to third parties without discussing the same with TWA demonstrates your lack of a good faith interest in negotiating the merger of some of our airlines,'' Icahn wrote. Pan Am got some financial help Monday as UAL Corp. advanced $20 million toward leaseholds on gates and other property at San Francisco International Airport. Pan Am said the city Airports Commission has approved the deal and final city authorization is expected early next month. Weak airlines such as Pan Am and TWA have been hurt by rising fuel costs following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August and fewer passengers due to the recession. Pan Am has posted huge losses over the past decade and has survived by selling assets piecemeal. Pan Am has completed the sale of two Boeing 747 jumbo jets to UAL, and a $10 million spare parts sale is expected to be completed soon, said Kriendler. The sale of the leaseholds, Boeing jets and spare parts were all included in a $400 million deal to sell United some of Pan Am's routes to London's Heathrow Airport. The route sale has been snagged as U.S. and British authorities negotiate over whether United can take over Pan Am's authority to use Heathrow, or be switched to the less desirable but less congested Gatwick Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Zubaz Add Pizazz To Fashion Industry
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Zubaz pants are zooming off warehouse racks in greater quantities as the zany pajama-like clothes add pizazz, and dollars, to the fashion industry. But it wasn't instant success for former prison guard Bob Truax and his weight-lifting buddy, Dan Stock, who created the wildly patterned drawstring pants on a shoestring budget in 1988. ``We were laughed right out of sales meetings. We got laughed at over the telephone,'' says Truax, who is now laughing all the way to the bank. Truax and Stock began selling Zubaz (pronounced ZOO-baz) pants in the pro shop of their Roseville weight-lifting gym. Zubaz, which means ``in your face'' in gym lingo, was designed by a weightlifter and sewn by inmates at women's state prison in Shakopee with fabric bought from local stores. Today, they're sold in more than 75 patterns of assorted animal hides and jungle vegetation through Warrior Distributing Co. Similarly patterned Zubaz hats, ties, shorts, T-shirts and diaper covers also have evolved. Sales of the pants and accessories are expected to at least double in 1991 from last year, to more than $40 million, according to the company. Zubaz moved from gym shops into the mainstream with the help John Ford, a J.C. Penney Co. store manager who was wowed by the pants after seeing two University of Minnesota football players wearing them while shopping. He quickly placed a $270,000 order for Penney. ``They've been blowing out of stores ever since,'' Stock said. Warrior Distributing has 5,000 retail accounts nationwide. Besides large orders from stores like Penney, the company gets a bevy of smaller orders from sporting goods stores, college book stores, and small department stores. ``We're getting faxes (of orders) every day that are three to four inches deep,'' Truax said. ``We've got areas of the country where it's going nuts.'' Singer Crystal Taliefero counts herself among the enthusiastic Zubaz wearers. She custom ordered several pairs of pants recently. ``As soon as I get that I'll wear them every show. It's hot stuff,'' she said. Licensed to carry the logos of National Football League and college teams, Zubaz clothes were frequently spotted on NFL sidelines. Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Jim McMahon, for instance, gets no promotional fee for wearing an Eagles cap done in green zebra. ``He's perfect for it,'' Stock said. Zubaz garb also has found a place on the rock scene. During a November tour stop in the Minneapolis area, for example, Billy Joel's band and crew members invaded the Zubaz warehouse at the company's invitation, buying a van full of merchandise. The pants sell for $32 to $36; those featuring NFL logos go for as much as $60 at stadiums. Stock, 31, and Truax, 32, are as laid-back as their beloved togs - which they wear no matter where they go on business. The men share a fondness for sports. The walls surrounding their adjoining offices are blanketed with sports memorabilia and autographed pictures of sports heroes and other celebrities. A Miami Dolphins jersey worn by Dan Marino hangs in Truax's office and a row of NFL helmets line a shelf in Stock's. Warrior Distributing's eight investors, including pro wrestlers ``Hawk'' and ``Animal,'' hold equal shares in the company but Truax and Stock handle daily operations. Truax and Stock have been careful to build the company around the Zubaz label. When the existing fashions go the way of nehru jackets, they said, the label could give rise to other fashions. ``We don't want to be known strictly as the guys who do the zebra pants,'' Stock said.

DOC.HEAD: Need Some Cash? Hock Your Home - But Carefully
DOC.TEXT: Home equity loans have been developing a fast following in these troubled economic times as more homeowners find themselves debt-ridden and cash-strapped. Loans based on home values can give consumers tens of thousands of dollars at relatively low interest rates. And unlike other loans, the interest in many cases is tax deductible. But experts warn that homeowners should exercise a great deal of caution before using their single most valuable possession as collateral. ``The house is the last major remaining asset folks have and banks are all too willing to loan against the house because the loans are fully collaterized,'' said Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor, a weekly newsletter based in North Palm Beach, Fla. ``Consumers have to remember if they can't pay the loans back they lose the farm.'' Experts say the appeal of home-equity loans - with interest rates hovering about between one and three percentage points above banks' prime rate - should grow as rates in general continue to decline. The prime rate for most major banks stands at 10 percent, however, a few institutions recently lowered their rates to 9.75 percent. Rates remain much higher on unsecured bank loans. The average interest rate charged on a bank credit card was 18.83 percent in December, up from 18.60 percent at the start of the year, according to Bank Rate Monitor. The average rate for a bank personal loan was 17.34 percent, up from 17.19 percent in January, the publication said. For home equity loans banks typically lend up to 80 percent of a home's appraised market value minus the amount owners owe on their mortgage. More than $50 billion was lent out through home-equity lines of credit in 1989, and that figure is expected to grow between 15- and 20 percent in 1990, according to the American Bankers Association. Despite its growing popularity, experts warn these loans can contain many hidden costs that could run into hundreds of dollars, such as closing costs, application fees and appraisal fees. Also, if the prime rate rises, consumers with variable rates tied to the prime can suddenly be hit with a big jump in their monthly payments. Particularly risky is a so-called ``balloon note'' - a loan that calls for payments only on the interest for the first several years. After that, the borrower must cough up payments on a big principal. ``The consumer who doesn't read the details of the contract goes for it,'' says Heady. For those homeowners who don't necessarily have the need for cash right away but want the flexibility of long-term loan access, the option of choice is taking out an extended line of credit against their home's value. However, a few banks penalize consumers who don't borrow money from the credit line, charging them an annual ``non-usage'' fee that can be around $50, according to Heady. This is presumably to compensate banks for the cost of servicing the loan when they don't have the interest income. Other banks charge consumers who pre-pay their loans typically 2 percent of the amount in their credit line, Heady said. However, a prepayment penalty ``would definitely be the exception,'' said Phillip Wilson, a senior vice president at San Diego Trust and Savings Bank who is vice chairman of American Bankers Association's consumer credit executive committee.

DOC.HEAD: Yields Drop on Short-Term Notes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level in almost three years. The average yield was 7.32 percent, down from 7.49 percent at the last auction on Nov. 27. It was the lowest yield since two-year notes averaged 7.16 percent on Feb. 24, 1988. DOC.HEAD: Report: Beer Sales in a Froth, Hit Historic Mark
DOC.TEXT: Sales of beer, by far the most popular alcoholic beverage in the nation, are projected to rise 2.3 percent for a record 190 million barrels this year, a trade journal reported Wednesday. ``Five of the top 10 brands are expected to post advances in 1990, collectively recording a projected gain of 1.2 percent to 130.8 million barrels,'' said the wine, spirits and beer industries tracker Impact. As usual, Anheuser-Busch Inc., the world's largest brewer, leads the domestic market. With projected shipments of 84 million 31-gallon barrels this year, Budweiser and its A-B siblings will post 43.7 percent of market share, said the publication. Miller Brewing is second-best in market share with an anticipated 22.1 percent; Coors Brewing Co., 9.9 percent; Stroh Brewery Co., 8.0 percent, and G. Heileman Brewing Co., 6.1 percent. Heineken continues the top-selling imported beer. None of the figures includes sales of non-alcoholi brews. The final figures for the year could go even higher than expected, said Impact, owing to the wholesaler race to stock up before the rise in federal excise taxes on beverage alcohol goes into effect. On Jan. 1, the excise tax on beer will double to $18 a barrel. A January windfall is expected for wholesalers, who are buying beer at pretax rise rates and planning to sell it at post-tax rise markups, noted Impact, adding: ``Abnormally heavy shipments in December could result in dismal industry sales in the first quarter of 1991, as distributors and retailers work down pre-FET inventory.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Bars Stock Exchange From Seeking $50 Million Fine
DOC.TEXT: A bankruptcy judge has barred the New York Stock Exchange from seeking a record $50 million fine from Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., saying the firm's securities law violations had been punished adequately. The ruling by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Francis Conrad means the stock exchange can't proceed with disciplinary action against Drexel related to the investment firm's 1989 guilty plea to six felony counts related to illegal trading. The NYSE had planned to seek $25 million each from the parent company and the securities subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. It was negotiating with Drexel when the parent filed for Chapter 11 bankrupcty protection in February. Under federal law, the exchange needed court approval to proceed with the disciplinary action. The NYSE said in a statement that it is ``reviewing the decision to determine whether an appeal is appropriate.'' In the ruling, dated Dec. 14, Conrad deflated the exchange's argument that a fine was needed to send a message to Wall Street that wrongdoing would be dealt with harshly. He said the NYSE's ``public policy reasons'' for seeking the penalty ``don't appear to accomplish much more'' than Drexel's settlement with the U.S. Attorney's Office and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Drexel in September 1989 settled civil and criminal charges by agreeing to plead guilty to the felony counts and pay $650 million in fines and restitution. Conrad agreed with Drexel in ruling that the NYSE's attempts to extract $50 million from the firm would reult in ``the misallocation of scarce resources'' that could be used to pay creditors. Conrad also said the procedure would distract Drexel from drawing up a reorganization plan, and that ``Drexel's professional attention must remain focused on this critical stage.''

DOC.HEAD: Cola Companies Vie for School Vending Machines, Young New Buyers
LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: Buy a soft drink, help a school. Budget's tight, call a cola company. That is the thinking behind the unusual partnership between the nation's leading beverage companies and many parents and principals. In Moodus, Conn., the entire town is collecting Pepsi caps to save the dilapidated Nathan Hale-Ray High School. In the first three weeks, children saved 20,000 caps. At a nickel apiece the caps won't cover $9 million in expenses, but the fund-raising drive has raised hopes. The students have even suggested renaming the school ``Pepsi-Cola High School.'' It's also good business for Pepsico Inc., Pepsi-Cola's parent company. Local stores have increased their orders; one pharmacy ordered 6,000 bottles, said teacher Adam Friedman. ``We've noticed most (of the bottles turned in to recycling centers) are Pepsi products,'' he said. ``People are committing to Pepsi because of School Caps.'' At Weymouth High School in Massachusetts, Pepsi and Coca Cola are fighting over the chance to erect a new $5,000 scoreboard. Pepsi has warned it won't donate the board if the Coke vending machine remains in the school gym. Coke has made a counter offer to provide a similar board. School officials, once hesitant to mingle educational purposes with commercial ventures, say tight fiscal times have made these partnerships more appealing. ``I generally oppose endorsing products,'' said school committee member Francis Corbett. ``But if we're gonna make a pact with the devil, let's get the best deal we can.'' The National Association of Secondary School Principals supports school-corporate partnerships if children aren't corrupted in the process. ``They should not cross the line where they are using students for their own profit motives,'' said spokesman Lew Armistead. He said the association had objected to Channel One, a project of Knoxville, Tenn.-based Whittle Communications, which provides schools with special television news programming mixed in with advertising. The beverage makers, already renowned for innovative ways to reach consumers, have become more creative about reaching young buyers. Pepsi's ``Be Excellent'' video, a montage of pop stars and athletes preaching anti-drug and -alcohol themes, has been shown to 3 million students in 2,700 high schools this year, said Spokesman Andrew Giangola. Students at Pinkston High in Dallas and Southwestern High School in Detroit are eligible for $2,000 in scholarships if they meet attendance, grade and drug-free goals. Coca Cola donated $50,000 to the Massachusetts Interscholastic Athletic Association to keep the state's high school basketball tournament afloat. The cola companies, maintaining they have always been dedicated to community service, say interest in the programs has jumped dramatically in the last year. In economically depressed New England, Coke has received double the requests it got from schools last year, Dowd said. ``Schools are extremely cash-strapped and looking to corporate America to help out wherever possible,'' said Giangola. ``This is a great example of how businesses can help schools and schools can help businesses.'' Pepsi usually requires schools to install its vending machines in return for scoreboards, computer equipment or outright cash bonuses. Coca Cola, according to one vice president, does not make such deals. ``We don't hold anything over their head,'' said Donald Dowd, noting Coke sponsors high school athletic events, rewards athletes of the week and donates money to local Boys and Girls Clubs. But, he added, ``We've been very fortunate, because of our activities, to get the endorsement of these schools. That's business.'' For Pepsi, ``We're selling the product by virtue of the fact we have a vending machine on site,'' said Ken Kimmel, New England marketing director. Both companies say they are investing in America's future promoting education. They're also securing loyalty among a new generation of buyers. Said Pepsi's Giangola: ``In-school business is 1 percent of our business and 100 percent of our future.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Lead Crop Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices continued a recovery from recent lows Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, leading grain futures to higher levels as well. The rally extended a rebound in soybean and soybean meal futures that began Monday after near-term delivery prices for those commodities dipped to life-of-contract lows. ``By any standards we were a little oversold,'' said Michael Gazall, a research analyst with the commodities brokerage Refco Inc in Chicago. He said the markets drew strength from news that the Soviet parliament had granted President Mikhail Gorbachev broader powers. The reports helped to ease fears of a Gorbachev ouster that might threaten future sales of U.S. grain to Moscow. An announcement that Soviet and U.S. trade officials will meet Jan. 4 in Washington also supported the grain markets, Gazall said. At the close, wheat futures were \ cent to 2\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $2.66 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2 cents higher with March at $2.35 a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2\ cents higher with March at $1.14{ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 5\ cents higher with January at $5.66{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Find Offices Increasingly Automated
DOC.TEXT: Nearly all American offices have copiers and vast majorities have facsimile machines and personal computers, a survey released Wednesday by a leading office equipment company found. The Gallup survey, commissioned by the Ricoh Corp., also found that mid-level managers are increasingly heavy users of these machines, sometimes using them more than their support staff. The ``Issues in the Office'' survey found 78 percent of U.S. offices have fax machines, 94 percent have copiers, 87 percent have personal computers and 57 percent have laser printers. Twenty-nine percent of office managers use fax machines very often, vs. 15 percent for other office workers, and 48 percent of managers are heavy users of copiers, vs. 40 percent of other employees, the results showed. ``When first introduced, office automation products were intended largely to improve productivity among secretarial and clerical employees,'' said Mark A. Stanton, manager of production communications for Ricoh. ``However, we now see office equipment climbing the corporate ladder, so to speak.'' The study also showed larger offices are more likely to have office equipment. For example, 90 percent of large offices have fax machines, vs. 83 percent of medium and 60 percent of small offices. Ninety-four percent of large offices are equipped with personal computers, vs. 89 percent for medium and 78 percent for small. Ricoh said the survey was conducted this past June by The Gallup Organization, a leading poll conductor based in Princeton, N.J., and was based on 500 telephone interviews with full-time office workers from around the country. Ricoh also said findings concerning the use of specific equipment had a sampling error of plus or minus 11 percentage points. Based in West Caldwell, N.J., Ricoh is the U.S. subsidiary of Ricoh Co. Ltd in Tokyo, a $5.3 billion diversified automated office equipment, electronics and photographic equipment company. It is one of the largest manufacturers and marketers of copiers and fax machines.

DOC.HEAD: Barrel Up $1.30 to Over $27 on War Fears
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures posted the biggest gains in three weeks Wednesday, rising above $27 a barrel on increasing fears of a Middle East war. Contracts for home heating oil, unleaded gasoline and natural gas also rose sharply in subdued New York Mercantile Exchange trading after a four-day Christmas weekend. Light sweet crude oil for February delivery increased $1.30 to $27.22 per 42-gallon barrel. It was the biggest single-day gain since a $1.51 per barrel jump Dec. 4. Oil market strategists said increasing tension between the United States and Iraq since the market closed last Friday after three straight daily declines gave prices a boost. ``I think the market is starting to reinternalize the fact that war seems very, very likely at this point,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. On Wednesday, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said the American army would be defeated in any war because it doesn't have ``right on its side.'' In an interview broadcast by Mexican television, Saddam also said he would not allow the United States to set a date for a meeting to discuss the war. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. In the Arabian Sea, U.S. and other sailors enforcing a U.N. trade embargo fired warning shots in a fracas with crew members and activists aboard an Iraqi ship. Traders said other U.S. and British reports increased the prospects of war. ``All those things underscore what people are fearing: They're not moving any closer to any resolution by Jan 15.,'' said Randall Rothenberg, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The market discounted the importance of an Israeli newspaper report - later denied by the State Department - that a date had been set for talks. The oil market opened sharply higher, mimicking gains in trading in London on Monday after Saddam threatened to attack Israel first if Iraq were targeted. Volume on Wednesday was light, though, with less than half the typical number of crude oil contracts changing hands, traders said. Contracts for later-month delivery rose. Traders last week sold contracts to hedge against sudden changes in the gulf situation over the long weekend. In addition, a belief that diplomatic efforts to solve the crisis might bear fruit had depressed crude oil prices in recent weeks. If war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, oil prices are expected to rise sharply because of anticipated limited supplies from the region. Technical factors and cold weather around the country pushed up home heating oil futures prices. Heating oil rose 2.32 cents to 81.26 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January after rising 0.06 cent on Friday. Heating oil for delivery in later months was higher. Unleaded gasoline rose for all delivery months, with January contracts up 1.90 cents to 68.14 cents a gallon. Later months also rose. Natural gas prices rose for a third straight trading session. Natural gas for February delivery was up 3.7 cents at $1.999 per 1,000 cubic feet. Later months were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar drifted lower Wednesday in quiet post-holiday trading. Gold and silver prices rose. But they said market sentiment toward the dollar remained strong amid continued political and economic unrest overeas. ``Tensions in the Soviet Union and the Middle East continue to provide support for the dollar,'' said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president and trader for Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago. Johnson said trading was sluggish, with most dollar brokers reluctant to do any major buying or selling since the overseas markets were closed. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar closed at 136.25 yen, up 0.30 yen from Tuesday's close. The dollar stood at 136.10 yen in New York, up from 136.00 yen Monday. DOC.HEAD: OJ Futures Spurt Higher On California Citrus Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices spurted higher Wednesday on the New York Cotton Exchange, reflecting worries that heavy frost damage to the California orange crop will hurt juice supplies. On other markets, precious metal futures surged along with crude oil; livestock and meat futures were mostly higher; and grains and soybeans advanced. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled 1.7 cents to 3.9 cents higher with the contract for delivery in January at $1.181 a pound. The rally marked the fifth straight trading day of gains for most orange juice futures. The January contract's price soared about 12 percent last week in anticipation of frost damage to oranges over the Christmas weekend. Extremely cold temperatures on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights damaged most of the California navel orange crop, the nation's main source of fresh oranges. Florida's orange crop, which is used mainly for juice, escaped the freeze. But the disaster in California means a larger share of the Florida crop probably will end up in supermarket produce sections, analysts said. ``I believe we will need to bring in oranges from Florida for the fresh market,'' said Celeste Georkakis, an orange juice analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. Conversely, some of the damaged California oranges will be processed into frozen juice concentrate, she said. But that must be done quickly to avoid spoilage. ``The whole question is how much they can process in a short period of time because they're not geared to processing as much as Florida,'' where 90 percent of the crop ends up as juice, Georkakis said. Unusually cold weather is expected to return to Southern California this weekend, according to the National Weather Service. Analysts said few traders were willing to sell OJ futures ahead of another long holiday weekend with the threat of further crop damage in the air. Oil and precious metals futures rose sharply amid increasing fears of a Middle East war. The rising tensions partly reflected U.S. and Iraqi officials' inability to agree on a meeting date before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil futures settled 60 cents to $1.30 higher with February at $27.22 a barrel; heating oil was 1.6 cents to 2.32 cents higher with January at 81.26 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.55 cents to 1.9 cents higher with January at 68.14 cents a gallon; natural gas was 0.5 cent lower to 3.7 cents higher with February at $1.999 per 1,000 cubic feet. Gold futures settled $3.10 to $3.50 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with December at $385.60 a troy ounce; silver was 7 cents to 7.5 cents higher with December at $4.095 a troy ounce. Cattle futures rallied strongly on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pulling pork futures mostly higher, on fears that the fiercely cold weather in the Great Plains could slow the rate of cattle weight gain. Prices also were supported by expectations for stronger beef demand after the holidays, analysts said. Live cattle settled .25 cent lower to .80 cent higher with February at 77.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .40 cent to .68 cent higher with January at 89.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .17 cent higher with February at 48.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .60 cent to .98 cent higher with February at 64.80 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's, Chicago Exchange Settle Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. and the Chicago Board Options Exchange said Wednesday they had settled a lawsuit in which S&P charged the exchange with violating a 1983 licensing agreement. The two sides said they had signed anagreement extending the CBOE's exclusive license to trade options on the S&P 500 Index and the S&P 100 Index, two important measures of stock market activity. S&P, a subsidiary of McGraw-Hill Inc., in early November charged the Chicago exchange with wrongly asserting an exclusive right to use the indexes on financial products other than options contracts traded on the exchange. The CBOE denied any breach. A person familiar with the out-of-court settlement said it reaffirms S&P's ability to license debt instruments and other products using the S&P 100 and 500 indexes other than options contracts. There was no monetary settlement, said the official, who asked not to be identified by name. The lawsuit had been filed in Manhattan federal court. The new agreement also extends until 1998 the CBOE's exclusive right to trade options contracts based on the two indexes. A CBOE spokesman said the exchange would not comment on the terms or conditions of the agreement. McGraw-Hill spokeswoman Elizabeth Russo said the agreement was ``mutually satisfactory.'' The S&P 100 Index and S&P 500 Index measure stock performance and are traded in units on the nation's major options exchanges. Options give an investor the right to buy or sell a security at a specified time for a specific price. S&P had said its license limits the CBOE to options contracts on the two indexes that are traded on a securities exchange and settled through an established clearing house by payment of cash or the underlying security. S&P said the CBOE's rights do not apply to other financial instruments that offer a return based in whole or part on the two indexes. Those include notes, certificates of deposit and other debt instruments, products that trade over the counter and financial instruments issued by institutions other than an exchange. The dispute began when S&P withdrew a note offering for Denmark earlier this year that paid interest based on the S&P 500. Underwriters for the issue were said to have withdrawn from the deal because of challenges by CBOE officials to use of the index. S&P, a financial information and credit rating agency, for several years has licensed the rights to use its indexes in connection with financial products sold off of exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Pennzoil Receives IRS Extension to Buy More Chevron Shares
DOC.TEXT: Pennzoil Co. said Wednesday it had upped a stake in Chevron Corp. after the Internal Revenue Service granted a five-month extension for Pennzoil to invest proceeds from its 1988 court settlement with Texaco Inc. Pennzoil spent $2.1 billion of a net $2.6 billion settlement in 1989 to purchase 31.5 million common shares of Chevron, giving it 9 percent ownership in the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, Pennzoil said that as of Wednesday it owned 32.8 million shares - approximately 9.4 percent of the 350.8 million shares outstanding. Pennzoil said 1.27 million of those 32.8 million shares were purchased during the past 60 days on the New York Stock Exchangen at an average price of $69.75 per share. In July, Pennzoil notified the Federal Trade Commission of its intent to increase its ownership level to slightly under 10 percent by purchasing additional Chevron shares. Pennzoil said it needed the extension from the IRS because of delays in obtaining clearance from the FTC, which monitors business activity that is considered potentially anticompetitive. Under the IRS delay, Pennzoil said, the company now has until May 31, 1991 to invest proceeds from its historic 1988 Texaco litigation settlement. Pennzoil sued Texaco in 1985, claiming Texaco violated a contract when it purchased Getty Oil Co. at the same time Pennzoil was attempting to acquire part of Getty. A jury awarded Pennzoil more than $10 billion, the largest award in litigation history, but Texaco sought bankruptcy court protection afterward and the two oil companies settled on $3 billion, before expenses, as part of Texaco's re-emergence from the bankruptcy process. The net settlement to Pennzoil was about $2.6 billion. Under IRS rules, Pennzoil can defer taxes on the Texaco settlement if it is reinvested in similar or related property.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Gets U.S. Government Contract Worth Up To $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines has been given a U.S. government contract worth up to an estimated $100 million to carry federal employees traveling on business in 1991. Financially troubled Eastern was ``pleased that the government recognizes our fine record in providing safe, reliable transportation at a good value,'' its bankruptcy court-appointed trustee Martin R. Shugrue said. The award comes as the U.S. Justice Department pursues a 60-count criminal indictment against Eastern and nine of its top managers, charging that safety records and other maintenance documents were falsified to keep its planes flying on time. An affidavit quoted confidential informants as telling federal investigators that as recently as last month Eastern falsified safety and maintenance records. Eastern officials have denied the allegations. Eastern, which has lost millions of dollars and become a smaller carrier, has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since an unresolved strike began in March 1989. The contract was for more than 345 domestic and international routes. That's a large increase over the 220 routes the airline received in 1990, which were worth an estimated $52 million.

DOC.HEAD: Naming of Trade Minister Seen as Effort to Mend Trade Friction with U.S.
With AM-Korea, moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo's appointment Thursday of American-educated Lee Bong-suh as Trade and Industry Minister is seen as an effort to mend trade frictions between Seoul and Washington. The appointment was the only economic post changed in a cabinet shakeup that included a the naming of a new prime minister and foreign minister. The new Trade Minister is considered knowledgeable in U.S. affairs, having studied at American universities and worked in Washington. Observers hope he will be able to heal animosities between the two longtime allies on trade matters. The United States is South Korea's largest trading partner. Washington has pressured Seoul to open its markets wider to foreign goods and farm products. The Seoul government claims foreign imports will hurt the competitiveness of Korean goods and threaten the livelihood of Korean workers. Radical students and farmers have staged violent protests demanding a halt to U.S. trade pressure. Lee, 54, is a 1959 graduated of the University of Pennsylvania and received a doctorate in economics from Harvard in 1965. He worked in Washington during the 1960s for the U.S. Federal Reserve and the World Bank. He returned to South Korea in the early 1970s and entered a long term of government service.
